Above her, three beggars\r\nor hawkers have reckoned their day\xe2\x80\x99s earnings, amounting to 13s., and on\r\nthe right a tolerably correct sketch of a low hawker, or cadger, is\r\ndrawn. \xe2\x80\x9cTo Dover, the _nigh_ way,\xe2\x80\x9d is the exact phraseology; and \xe2\x80\x9chup\r\nhere,\xe2\x80\x9d a fair specimen of the self-acquired education of the\r\ndraughtsman. No key or explanation to the hieroglyphs was given in the\r\noriginal, because it would have been superfluous, when every inmate of\r\nthe lodging-house knew the marks from his cradle\xe2\x80\x94or rather his mother\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nback.\r\n\r\nShould there be no map, in most lodging-houses there is an old man who\r\nis guide to every \xe2\x80\x9cwalk\xe2\x80\x9d in the vicinity, and who can tell on every\r\nround each house that is \xe2\x80\x9cgood for a cold tatur.\xe2\x80\x9d The hieroglyphs that\r\nare used are:\xe2\x80\x94\r\n\r\n\xe2\x98\x93 ~No good~; too poor, and know too much.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x97\xa0+ ~Stop~,\xe2\x80\x94If you have what they want, they will buy. They are pretty\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cfly\xe2\x80\x9d (knowing).\r\n\r\n\xe2\x8a\x83\xe2\x80\x94 ~Go in this direction~, it is better than the other road. Nothing\r\nthat way.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x97\x87 ~Bone~ (good). Safe for a \xe2\x80\x9ccold tatur,\xe2\x80\x9d if for nothing else. \xe2\x80\x9cCheese\r\nyour patter\xe2\x80\x9d (don\xe2\x80\x99t talk much) here.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x96\xbd ~Cooper\xe2\x80\x99d~ (spoilt), by too many tramps calling there.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x96\xa1 ~Gammy~ (unfavourable), like to have you taken up. Mind the dog.\r\n\r\n\xe2\xa6\xbf ~Flummuxed~ (dangerous), sure of a month in \xe2\x80\x9cquod\xe2\x80\x9d (prison).\r\n\r\n\xe2\x8a\x95 ~Religious~, but tidy on the whole.\r\n\r\nWhere did these signs come from? and when were they first used? are\r\nquestions which have been asked again and again, and the answers have\r\nbeen many and various. Knowing the character of the Gipsies, and\r\nascertaining from a tramp that they are well acquainted with the\r\nhieroglyphs, \xe2\x80\x9cand have been as long ago as ever he could remember,\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nthere is little fear of being wrong in ascribing the invention to them.\r\nHow strange it would be if some modern Belzoni, or Champollion\xe2\x80\x94say Mr.\r\nGeorge Smith, for instance\xe2\x80\x94discovered in these beggars\xe2\x80\x99 marks traces of\r\nancient Egyptian or Hindoo sign-writing!\r\n\r\nThat the Gipsies were in the habit of leaving memorials of the road they\r\nhad taken, and the successes that had befallen them, is upon record. In\r\nan old book, _The Triumph of Wit_, 1724, there is a passage which\r\nappears to have been copied from some older work, and it runs\r\nthus:\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cThe Gipsies set out twice a year, and scatter all over England,\r\neach parcel having their appointed stages, that they may not interfere,\r\nnor hinder each other; and for that purpose, when they set forward in\r\nthe country, they stick up boughs in the way of divers kinds, according\r\nas it is agreed among them, that one company may know which way another\r\nis gone, and so take another road.\xe2\x80\x9d The works of Hoyland and Borrow\r\nsupply other instances.\r\n\r\nIt would be hardly fair to close this subject without drawing attention\r\nto the extraordinary statement that, actually on the threshold of the\r\ngibbet, the sign of the vagabond was to be met with! \xe2\x80\x9cThe murderer\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nsignal is even exhibited from the gallows; as a red handkerchief held in\r\nthe hand of the felon about to be executed is a token that he dies\r\nwithout having betrayed any professional secrets.\xe2\x80\x9d[30] Private\r\nexecutions have of course rendered this custom obsolete, even if it\r\never existed.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nSince the first editions of this work were published, the publishers\r\nhave received from various parts of England numerous evidences of the\r\nstill active use of beggars\xe2\x80\x99 marks and mendicant hieroglyphs. One\r\ngentleman writes from Great Yarmouth to say that, whilst residing in\r\nNorwich, he used frequently to see them on the houses and street corners\r\nin the suburbs. Another gentleman, a clergyman, states that he has so\r\nfar made himself acquainted with the meanings of the signs employed,\r\nthat by himself marking the characters \xe2\x97\xbb (gammy) and \xe2\xa6\xbf (flummuxed) on\r\nthe gate-posts of his parsonage, he enjoys a singular immunity from\r\nalms-seekers and cadgers on the tramp. This hint may not be lost on many\r\nother sufferers from importunate beggars, yet its publication may lead\r\nto the introduction of a new code.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nIn a popular constable\xe2\x80\x99s guide,[31] giving the practice of justices in\r\npetty sessions, the following interesting paragraph is found,\r\ncorroborating what has just been said on the hieroglyphs used by\r\nvagabonds:\xe2\x80\x94\r\n\r\n    \xe2\x80\x9cGipsies follow their brethren by numerous marks, such as strewing\r\n    handfuls of grass in the daytime at a four lane or cross roads; the\r\n    grass being strewn down the road the gang have taken; also, by a\r\n    cross being made on the ground with a stick or knife\xe2\x80\x94the longest\r\n    end of the cross denotes the route taken. In the night-time a cleft\r\n    stick is placed in the fence at the cross roads, with an arm\r\n    pointing down the road their comrades have taken. The marks are\r\n    always placed on the left-hand side, so that the stragglers can\r\n    easily and readily find them.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nFrom the cleft stick here alluded to, we learn the origin and use of \xe2\x8a\x83\xe2\x80\x94,\r\nthe third hieroglyph in the vagabond\xe2\x80\x99s private list. And the extract\r\nalso proves that the \xe2\x80\x9crule of the road\xe2\x80\x9d is the same with tramps as with\r\nthat body which is morally less but physically more dangerous, the\r\nLondon drivers.\r\n\r\n\r\nFOOTNOTES:\r\n\r\n[24] Mr. Rawlinson\xe2\x80\x99s _Report to the General Board of Health, Parish of\r\nHavant, Hampshire_.\r\n\r\n[25] Vol. v. p. 210.\r\n\r\n[26] Vol. i. pp. 218 and 247.\r\n\r\n[27] See Dictionary.\r\n\r\n[28] Sometimes, as appears from the following, the names of persons and\r\nhouses are written instead. \xe2\x80\x9cIn almost every one of the padding-kens, or\r\nlow lodging-houses in the country, there is a list of walks pasted up\r\nover the kitchen mantelpiece. Now at St. Albans, for instance, at the\r\n----, and at other places, there is a paper stuck up in each of the\r\nkitchens. This paper is headed, \xe2\x80\x98Walks out of this town\xe2\x80\x99 and underneath\r\nit is set down the names of the villages in the neighbourhood at which a\r\nbeggar may call when out on his walk, and they are so arranged as to\r\nallow the cadger to make a round of about six miles each day, and return\r\nthe same night. In many of these papers there are sometimes twenty walks\r\nset down. No villages that are in any way \xe2\x80\x98gammy\xe2\x80\x99 [bad] are ever\r\nmentioned in these papers, and the cadger, if he feels inclined to stop\r\nfor a few days in the town, will be told by the lodging-house keeper, or\r\nthe other cadgers that he may meet there, what gentlemen\xe2\x80\x99s seats or\r\nprivate houses are of any account on the walk that he means to take. The\r\nnames of the good houses are not set down in the paper, for fear of the\r\npolice.\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94_Mayhew_, vol. i. p. 418. [This business is also much altered\r\nin consequence of the increase in the surveillance of the kens, an\r\nincrease which, though nominally for sanitary purposes, has a strong\r\nmoral effect. Besides this, Mr. Mayhew\xe2\x80\x99s informants seem to have\r\npossessed a fair share of that romance which is inherent among\r\nvagabonds.\xe2\x80\x94ED.]\r\n\r\n[29] See Dictionary.\r\n\r\n[30] Mr. Rawlinson\xe2\x80\x99s _Report to the General Board of Health, Parish of\r\nHavant, Hampshire_.\r\n\r\n[31] Snowden\xe2\x80\x99s _Magistrate\xe2\x80\x99s Assistant_, 1852, p. 444.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nA SHORT HISTORY OF SLANG,\r\n\r\nOR\r\n\r\nTHE VULGAR LANGUAGE OF FAST LIFE.\r\n\r\nSlang is the language of street humour, of fast, high, and low life.\r\nCant, as was stated in the chapter upon that subject, is the vulgar\r\nlanguage of secrecy. It must be admitted, however, that within the past\r\nfew years they have become almost indivisible. They are both universal\r\nand ancient, and appear to have been, with certain exceptions, the\r\noffspring of gay, vulgar, or worthless persons in every part of the\r\nworld at every period of time. Indeed, if we are to believe implicitly\r\nthe saying of the wise man, that \xe2\x80\x9cthere is nothing new under the sun,\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nthe \xe2\x80\x9cbloods\xe2\x80\x9d of buried Nineveh, with their knotty and door-matty-looking\r\nbeards, may have cracked Slang jokes on the steps of Sennacherib\xe2\x80\x99s\r\npalace; while the stocks and stones of ancient Egypt, and the bricks of\r\nvenerable and used-up Babylon, may be covered with Slang hieroglyphs,\r\nwhich, being perfectly unknown to modern antiquaries, have long been\r\nstumbling-blocks to the philologist; so impossible is it at this day to\r\nsay what was then authorized, or what vulgar, language. The only\r\nobjection that can be raised to this idea is, that Slang was, so far as\r\ncan be discovered, traditional, and unwritten, until the appearance of\r\nthis volume, a state of things which accounts for its many changes, and\r\nthe doubtful orthography of even its best known and most permanent\r\nforms. Slang is almost as old as speech, and must date from the\r\ncongregating together of people in cities. It is the result of crowding,\r\nand excitement, and artificial life. We have traces of this as far as we\r\ncan refer back. Martial, the epigrammatist, is full of Slang. When an\r\nuninvited guest accompanied his friend, the Slang of the day styled him\r\nhis \xe2\x80\x9cumbra;\xe2\x80\x9d when a man was trussed, neck and heels, it called him\r\njocosely \xe2\x80\x9cquadrupus.\xe2\x80\x9d Slang is nowadays very often the only vehicle by\r\nwhich rodomontade may be avoided. It is often full of the most pungent\r\nsatire, and is always to the point. Without point Slang has no _raison\r\nd\xe2\x80\x99\xc3\xaatre_.\r\n\r\nOld English Slang was coarser, and depended more upon downright\r\nvulgarity than our modern Slang. It was a jesting speech, or humorous\r\nindulgence for the thoughtless moment or the drunken hour, and it acted\r\nas a vent-peg for a fit of temper or irritability; but it did not\r\ninterlard and permeate every description of conversation as now. It was\r\nconfined to nicknames and improper subjects, and encroached but to a\r\nvery small extent upon the domain of authorized speech. Indeed, it was\r\nexceedingly limited when compared with the vast territory of Slang in\r\nsuch general favour and complete circulation at the present day. Still,\r\nalthough not an extensive institution, as in our time, Slang certainly\r\ndid exist in this country centuries ago, as we may see if we look down\r\nthe page of any respectable History of England. Cromwell was familiarly\r\ncalled \xe2\x80\x9cOld Noll,\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94in much the same way as Bonaparte was termed\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBoney,\xe2\x80\x9d and Wellington \xe2\x80\x9cConkey\xe2\x80\x9d or \xe2\x80\x9cNosey,\xe2\x80\x9d only a few years ago.[32]\r\nHis Legislature, too, was spoken of in a high-flavoured way as the\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBarebones\xe2\x80\x9d or \xe2\x80\x9cRump\xe2\x80\x9d Parliament, and his followers were nicknamed\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cRoundheads,\xe2\x80\x9d and the peculiar religious sects of his protectorate were\r\nstyled \xe2\x80\x9cPuritans\xe2\x80\x9d and \xe2\x80\x9cQuakers.\xe2\x80\x9d[33] The Civil War pamphlets, and the\r\nsatirical hits of the Cavaliers and the Commonwealth men, originated\r\nnumerous Slang words and vulgar similes in full use at the present\r\nmoment. Here is a field of inquiry for the Philological Society, indeed\r\na territory, for there are thirty thousand of these partisan tracts.\r\nLater still, in the court of Charles II., the naughty ladies and the gay\r\nlords, with Rochester at their head, talked Slang; and very naughty\r\nSlang it was too. Fops in those days, when \xe2\x80\x9cover head and ears\xe2\x80\x9d in debt,\r\nand in continual fear of arrest, termed their enemies, the bailiffs,\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPhilistines\xe2\x80\x9d[34] or \xe2\x80\x9cMoabites.\xe2\x80\x9d At a later period, when collars were\r\nworn detached from shirts, in order to save the expense of washing\xe2\x80\x94an\r\nobject, it would seem, with needy \xe2\x80\x9cswells\xe2\x80\x9d in all ages\xe2\x80\x94they obtained\r\nthe name of \xe2\x80\x9cJacobites.\xe2\x80\x9d One-half of the coarse wit in Butler\xe2\x80\x99s\r\n_Hudibras_ lurks in the vulgar words and phrases which he was so fond of\r\nemploying. These Slang phrases contained the marrow of his arguments\r\nstripped of all superfluous matter, and they fell with ponderous weight\r\nand terrible effect upon his opponents. They were more homely and\r\nforcible than the mild and elegant sentences of Cowley, and the people,\r\ntherefore, hurrahed them, and pronounced Butler one of themselves,\xe2\x80\x94or,\r\nas we should say, in a joyful moment, \xe2\x80\x9ca jolly good fellow.\xe2\x80\x9d Orator\r\nHenley preached and prayed in Slang, and first charmed and then ruled\r\nthe dirty mobs in Lincoln\xe2\x80\x99s Inn Fields by vulgarisms. Burly Grose\r\nmentions Henley, with the remark that we owe a great many Slang phrases\r\nto him, though even the worst Slang was refinement itself compared with\r\nmany of Henley\xe2\x80\x99s most studied oratorical utterances, which proves that\r\nthe most blackguard parts of a blackguard speech may be perfectly free\r\nfrom either Slang or Cant. Swift, and old Sir Roger L\xe2\x80\x99Estrange, and\r\nArbuthnot, were all fond of vulgar or Slang language; indeed, we may see\r\nfrom a Slang word used by the latter how curious is the gradual adoption\r\nof vulgar terms in our standard dictionaries. The worthy doctor, in\r\norder to annihilate (or, as we should say, with a fitting respect to the\r\nsubject under consideration, to \xe2\x80\x9csmash\xe2\x80\x9d) an opponent, thought proper on\r\nan occasion to use the word \xe2\x80\x9ccabbage,\xe2\x80\x9d not in the ancient sense of a\r\nflatulent vegetable of the kitchen-garden, but in the at once Slang\r\nsense of purloining or cribbing. Johnson soon met with the word, looked\r\nat it, examined it, weighed it, and shook his head, but out of respect\r\nto a brother doctor inserted it in his dictionary, labelling it,\r\nhowever, prominently \xe2\x80\x9cCant;\xe2\x80\x9d whilst Walker and Webster, years after,\r\nwhen all over England \xe2\x80\x9cto cabbage\xe2\x80\x9d was to pilfer, placed the term in\r\ntheir dictionaries as an ancient and very respectable word. Another\r\nSlang term, \xe2\x80\x9cgull,\xe2\x80\x9d to cheat, or delude, sometimes varied to \xe2\x80\x9cgully,\xe2\x80\x9d is\r\nstated to be connected with the Dean of St. Patrick\xe2\x80\x99s. \xe2\x80\x9cGull,\xe2\x80\x9d a dupe,\r\nor a fool, is often used by our old dramatists, and is generally\r\nbelieved to have given rise to the verb; but a curious little edition of\r\n_Bamfylde Moore Carew_, published in 1827, says that \xe2\x80\x9cto gull,\xe2\x80\x9d or\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cgully,\xe2\x80\x9d is derived from the well-known Gulliver, the hero of the famous\r\nTravels. It may be from the phrase, \xe2\x80\x9cYou can\xe2\x80\x99t come Gulliver over me,\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nin use while the popularity of the book was hot. How crammed with Slang\r\nare the dramatic works of the last century! The writers of the comedies\r\nand farces in those days must have lived in the streets, and written\r\ntheir plays in the public-houses, so filled are they with vulgarisms and\r\nunauthorized words. The popular phrases, \xe2\x80\x9cI owe you one,\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9cThat\xe2\x80\x99s one\r\nfor his nob,\xe2\x80\x9d and \xe2\x80\x9cKeep moving, dad,\xe2\x80\x9d arose in this way.[35] The second\r\nof these sayings was, doubtless, taken from the card-table, for at\r\ncribbage the player who holds the knave of the suit turned up counts\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cone for his nob,\xe2\x80\x9d and the dealer who turns up a knave counts \xe2\x80\x9ctwo for\r\nhis heels.\xe2\x80\x9d From a dramatic point of view, the use of these phrases is\r\nperfectly correct, as they were in constant use among the people\r\nsupposed to be represented by the author\xe2\x80\x99s characters.\r\n\r\nIn Mrs. Centlivre\xe2\x80\x99s admirable comedy of _A Bold Stroke for a Wife_, we\r\nsee the origin of that popular phrase, the real Simon Pure. Simon Pure\r\nis the Quaker name adopted by Colonel Feignwell as a trick to obtain the\r\nhand of Mistress Anne Lovely in marriage. The veritable Quaker, the\r\n\xe2\x80\x9creal Simon Pure,\xe2\x80\x9d recommended by Aminadab Holdfast, of Bristol, as a\r\nfit sojourner with Obadiah Prim, arrives at last, to the discomfiture of\r\nthe Colonel, who, to maintain his position and gain time, concocts a\r\nletter in which the real Quaker is spoken of as a housebreaker who had\r\ntravelled in the \xe2\x80\x9cleather conveniency\xe2\x80\x9d from Bristol, and adopted the\r\ngarb and name of the western Quaker in order to pass off as the \xe2\x80\x9cReal\r\nSimon Pure,\xe2\x80\x9d but only for the purpose of robbing the house and cutting\r\nthe throat of the perplexed Obadiah. The scene in which the two Simon\r\nPures, the real and the counterfeit, meet, is one of the best in the\r\ncomedy.\r\n\r\nTom Brown, of \xe2\x80\x9cfacetious memory,\xe2\x80\x9d as his friends were wont to say, and\r\nNed Ward, who wrote humorous books, and when tired drew beer for his\r\ncustomers at his alehouse in Long Acre,[36] were both great producers of\r\nSlang in the last century, and to them we owe many popular current\r\nphrases and household words.\r\n\r\nWritten Slang was checked, rather than advanced, by the pens of\r\nAddison, Johnson, and Goldsmith; although Bee, the bottle-holder and\r\nhistoriographer of the pugilistic band of brothers in the youthful days\r\nof flat-nosed Tom Cribb, has gravely stated that Johnson, when young and\r\nrakish, contributed to an early volume of the _Gentleman\xe2\x80\x99s Magazine_ a\r\nfew pages, by way of specimen, of a slang dictionary, the result, Mr.\r\nBee says, \xe2\x80\x9cof his midnight ramblings!\xe2\x80\x9d[37] This statement is not only\r\nimprobable, but an investigation of the venerable magazine, though\r\nstrict and searching, produces no evidence in corroboration of Mr. Bee.\r\nGoldsmith, even, certainly coined a few words as occasion required,\r\nalthough as a rule his pen was pure and graceful, and adverse to\r\nneologisms. The word \xe2\x80\x9cfudge,\xe2\x80\x9d it has been stated, was first used by him\r\nin literary composition, although it probably originated with one\r\nCaptain Fudge, a notorious fibber, nearly a century before. Street\r\nphrases, nicknames, and vulgar words were continually being added\r\nto the great stock of popular Slang up to the commencement of\r\nthe present century, when it received numerous additions from pugilism,\r\nhorse-racing, and \xe2\x80\x9cfast\xe2\x80\x9d life generally, which suddenly came into great\r\npublic favour, and was at its height in the latter part of the reign of\r\nGeorge III., and in the early days of the Regency. Slang in those days\r\nwas generally termed \xe2\x80\x9cflash\xe2\x80\x9d language. It will thus be noted that the\r\nterm \xe2\x80\x9cflash\xe2\x80\x9d has in turn represented both Cant and Slang; now the word\r\nSlang has become perfectly generic. So popular was \xe2\x80\x9cflash\xe2\x80\x9d with the\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cbloods\xe2\x80\x9d of high life, that it constituted the best paying literary\r\ncapital for certain authors and dramatists. Pierce Egan issued\r\n_Boxiana_, and _Life in London_, six portly octavo volumes, crammed with\r\nSlang; and Moncrieff wrote the most popular farce of the day, _Tom and\r\nJerry_ (adapted from the latter work), which, to use newspaper Slang,\r\n\xe2\x80\x9ctook the town by storm,\xe2\x80\x9d and, with its then fashionable vulgarisms,\r\nmade the fortune of the old Adelphi Theatre, and was without exception\r\nthe most wonderful instance of a continuous theatrical run in ancient or\r\nmodern times. This also was brimful of Slang. Other authors helped to\r\npopularize and extend Slang down to our own time, and it has now taken a\r\nsomewhat different turn, dropping many of the Cant and old vulgar words,\r\nand assuming a certain quaint and fashionable phraseology\xe2\x80\x94familiar,\r\nutilitarian, and jovial. There can be no doubt that common speech is\r\ngreatly influenced by fashion, fresh manners, and that general change of\r\nideas which steals over a people once in a generation. But before\r\nproceeding further into the region of Slang, it will be well to say\r\nsomething on the etymology of the word.\r\n\r\nThe word Slang is only mentioned by two lexicographers\xe2\x80\x94Webster and\r\nOgilvie.[38] Johnson, Walker, and the older compilers of dictionaries\r\ngive \xe2\x80\x9cslang\xe2\x80\x9d as the preterite of \xe2\x80\x9csling,\xe2\x80\x9d but not a word about Slang in\r\nthe sense of low, vulgar, or unrecognised language. The origin of the\r\nword has often been asked for in literary journals and books, but only\r\none man, until recently, ever hazarded an etymology\xe2\x80\x94Jonathan Bee.[39]\r\nWith a recklessness peculiar to ignorance, Bee stated that Slang was\r\nderived from \xe2\x80\x9cthe _slangs_ or fetters worn by prisoners, having acquired\r\nthat name from the manner in which they were worn, as they required a\r\nsling of string to keep them off the ground.\xe2\x80\x9d Bee had just been nettled\r\nat Pierce Egan\xe2\x80\x99s producing a new edition of Grose\xe2\x80\x99s _Dictionary of the\r\nVulgar Tongue_, and was determined to excel in a vulgar dictionary of\r\nhis own, which should be more racy, more pugilistic, and more original.\r\nHow far he succeeded in this latter particular, his ridiculous etymology\r\nof Slang will show. Slang is not an English word; it is the Gipsy term\r\nfor their secret language, and its synonym is Gibberish\xe2\x80\x94another word\r\nwhich was believed to have had no distinct origin.[40] Grose\xe2\x80\x94stout and\r\nburly Captain Grose\xe2\x80\x94whom we may characterize as the greatest antiquary,\r\njoker, and porter-drinker of his day, was the first lexicographer to\r\nrecognise the word \xe2\x80\x9cSlang.\xe2\x80\x9d It occurs in his _Classical Dictionary of\r\nthe Vulgar Tongue_, of 1785, with the statement that it implies \xe2\x80\x9cCant or\r\nvulgar language.\xe2\x80\x9d Grose was a great favourite with Burns, and so pleased\r\nhim by his extensive powers of story-telling and grog-imbibing, that the\r\ncompanionable and humour-loving Scotch bard wrote for his fat\r\nfriend\xe2\x80\x94or, to use his own words, \xe2\x80\x9cthe fine, fat, fodgel wight\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94the\r\nimmortal poem of _Tam O\xe2\x80\x99 Shanter_.\r\n\r\nIt is not worth while troubling the reader with a long account of the\r\ntransformation into an English term of the word Slang, as it is easily\r\nseen how we obtained it. Hucksters and beggars on tramp, or at fairs and\r\nraces, associate and frequently join in any rough enterprise with the\r\nGipsies. The word would be continually heard by them, and would in this\r\nmanner soon become part of their vocabulary,[41] and, when carried by\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cfast\xe2\x80\x9d or vulgar fashionables from the society of thieves and low\r\ncharacters to their own drawing-rooms, would as quickly become Slang,\r\nand the representative term for all vulgar language. Modern philologists\r\ngive the word Slang as derived from the French _langue_. This is, at all\r\nevents, as likely as any other derivative.\r\n\r\nAny sudden excitement or peculiar circumstance is quite sufficient to\r\noriginate and set going a score of Slang words. Nearly every election or\r\npublic agitation throws out offshoots of excitement, or scintillations\r\nof humour in the shape of Slang terms\xe2\x80\x94vulgar at first, but at length\r\nadopted, if possessing sufficient hold on the public mind, as\r\nsemi-respectable from sheer force of habit. There is scarcely a\r\ncondition or calling in life that does not possess its own peculiar\r\nSlang. The professions, legal and medical, have each familiar and\r\nunauthorized terms for peculiar circumstances and things, and it is\r\nquite certain that the clerical calling, or \xe2\x80\x9cthe cloth\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94in itself a\r\nSlang term given at a time when the laity were more distinguished by\r\ntheir gay dress from the clergy than they are now\xe2\x80\x94is not entirely free\r\nfrom this peculiarity. Every workshop, warehouse, factory, and mill\r\nthroughout the country has its Slang, and so have the public schools and\r\nthe Universities of Oxford and Cambridge. Sea Slang constitutes the\r\nprincipal charm of a sailor\xe2\x80\x99s \xe2\x80\x9cyarn;\xe2\x80\x9d and our soldiers have in turn\r\ntheir peculiar nicknames and terms for things and subjects, proper and\r\nimproper. A writer in _Household Words_ (No. 183) has gone so far as to\r\nremark, that a person \xe2\x80\x9cshall not read one single parliamentary debate,\r\nas reported in a first-class newspaper, without meeting scores of Slang\r\nwords,\xe2\x80\x9d and \xe2\x80\x9cthat from Mr. Speaker in his chair, to the Cabinet\r\nMinisters whispering behind it\xe2\x80\x94from mover to seconder, from true blue\r\nProtectionist to extremest Radical\xe2\x80\x94Mr. Barry\xe2\x80\x99s New House echoes and\r\nre-echoes with Slang.\xe2\x80\x9d This statement is most worthy of notice, as\r\nshowing how, with a very small sub-stratum of fact, a plausible, though\r\nnot the less gigantic, mis-statement may be built up.\r\n\r\nThe universality of Slang is extraordinary. Let any person for a short\r\ntime narrowly examine the conversation of his dearest and nearest\r\nfriends, or even analyse his own supposed correct talk, and he shall be\r\namazed at the numerous unauthorized, and what we can only call vulgar,\r\nwords in constant use. One peculiarity of the growth of Slang is the\r\nfinding of new meanings for old words. Take, for instance, the verbs\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cdo,\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9ccut,\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9cgo,\xe2\x80\x9d and \xe2\x80\x9ctake,\xe2\x80\x9d and see how they are used to express\r\nfresh ideas, and then let us ask ourselves how is it possible for a\r\nFrenchman or German, be he never so well educated, to avoid continually\r\nblundering and floundering amongst our little words when trying to make\r\nhimself understood in an ordinary conversation? He may have studied our\r\nlanguage the required time, and have gone through the usual amount of\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cgrinding,\xe2\x80\x9d and practised the common allotment of patience, but all to\r\nno purpose as far as accuracy is concerned. As, however, we do not make\r\nour language, nor for the matter of that our Slang, for the convenience\r\nor inconvenience of foreigners, we need not pursue this portion of the\r\nsubject further. \xe2\x80\x9cJabber\xe2\x80\x9d and \xe2\x80\x9choax\xe2\x80\x9d were Slang and Cant terms in\r\nSwift\xe2\x80\x99s time; so, indeed, were \xe2\x80\x9cmob\xe2\x80\x9d and \xe2\x80\x9csham.\xe2\x80\x9d[42] Words directly from\r\nthe Latin and Greek, framed in accordance with the rules which govern\r\nthe construction of the language, are not Slang, but are good English,\r\nif not Saxon,\xe2\x80\x94a term, by the way, which is as much misused as any\r\nunfortunate word that can be remembered just now. Sound contributes many\r\nSlang words\xe2\x80\x94a source that etymologists frequently overlook. Nothing\r\npleases an ignorant person so much as a high-sounding term, \xe2\x80\x9cfull of\r\nfury.\xe2\x80\x9d How melodious and drum-like are those vulgar coruscations\r\n\xe2\x80\x9crumbumptious,\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9cslantingdicular,\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9csplendiferous,\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9crumbustious,\xe2\x80\x9d and\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cferricadouzer.\xe2\x80\x9d What a \xe2\x80\x9cpull\xe2\x80\x9d the sharp-nosed lodging-house-keeper\r\nthinks she has over her victims if she can but hurl such testimonies of\r\na liberal education at them when they are disputing her charges, and\r\nthreatening to \xe2\x80\x9cabsquatulate!\xe2\x80\x9d In the United States the vulgar-genteel\r\neven excel the poor \xe2\x80\x9cstuck-up\xe2\x80\x9d Cockneys in their formation of a native\r\nfashionable language. How charming to a refined ear are \xe2\x80\x9cabskize,\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\xe2\x80\x9ccatawampously,\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9cexflunctify,\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9cobscute,\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9ckeslosh,\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9ckesouse,\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\xe2\x80\x9ckeswollop,\xe2\x80\x9d and \xe2\x80\x9ckewhollux!\xe2\x80\x9d[43] It must not be forgotten, however,\r\nthat a great many new \xe2\x80\x9cAmericanisms\xe2\x80\x9d are perfectly unknown in America,\r\nand in this respect they resemble the manners and customs of our cousins\r\nas found in books, and in books only. Vulgar words representing action\r\nand brisk movement often owe their origin to sound, as has before been\r\nremarked. Mispronunciation, too, is another great source of vulgar or\r\nSlang words, and of this \xe2\x80\x9cramshackle,\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9cshackly,\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9cnary-one\xe2\x80\x9d for neither\r\nor neither one, \xe2\x80\x9cottomy\xe2\x80\x9d or \xe2\x80\x9catomy\xe2\x80\x9d for anatomy, \xe2\x80\x9crench\xe2\x80\x9d for rinse, are\r\nspecimens. The commonalty dislike frequently-occurring words difficult\r\nof pronunciation, and so we have the street abridgments of \xe2\x80\x9cbimeby\xe2\x80\x9d for\r\nby-and-by, \xe2\x80\x9ccaze\xe2\x80\x9d for because, \xe2\x80\x9cgin\xe2\x80\x9d for given, \xe2\x80\x9chankercher\xe2\x80\x9d for\r\nhandkerchief, \xe2\x80\x9cruma tiz\xe2\x80\x9d for rheumatism, \xe2\x80\x9cbacker\xe2\x80\x9d for tobacco, and many\r\nothers, not perhaps Slang, but certainly, all vulgarisms. Whately, in\r\nhis _Remains of Bishop Copleston_, has inserted a leaf from the bishop\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nnote-book on the popular corruption of names, mentioning, among others,\r\n\xe2\x80\x9ckickshaws,\xe2\x80\x9d as from the French _quelques choses_; \xe2\x80\x9cbeefeater,\xe2\x80\x9d the\r\ngrotesque guardian of royalty in a procession, and the envied devourer\r\nof enormous beefsteaks, as but a vulgar pronunciation of the French\r\n_buffetier_, and \xe2\x80\x9cGeorge and Cannon,\xe2\x80\x9d the sign of a public-house, as\r\nnothing but a corruption (although so soon!) of the popular premier of\r\nthe last generation, George Canning.[44] Literature has its Slang terms;\r\nand the desire on the part of writers to say funny and startling things\r\nin a novel and curious way contributes many unauthorized words to the\r\ngreat stock of Slang.\r\n\r\nFashionable or Upper-class Slang is of several varieties. There is the\r\nBelgravian, military and naval, parliamentary, dandy, and the reunion\r\nand visiting Slang. English officers, civilians, and their families,\r\nwho have resided long in India, have contributed many terms from the\r\nHindostanee to our language. Several of these, such as \xe2\x80\x9cchit,\xe2\x80\x9d a letter,\r\nand \xe2\x80\x9ctiffin,\xe2\x80\x9d lunch, are fast losing their Slang character, and becoming\r\nregularly-recognised English words. \xe2\x80\x9cJungle,\xe2\x80\x9d as a term for a forest or\r\nwilderness, is now an English phrase; a few years past, however, it was\r\nmerely the Hindostanee \xe2\x80\x9cjunkul.\xe2\x80\x9d This, being a perfectly legal\r\ntransition, having no other recognised form, can hardly be characterized\r\nas Slang. The extension of trade in China, and the English settlement of\r\nHong Kong, have introduced among us several examples of Canton jargon,\r\nthat exceedingly curious Anglo-Chinese dialect spoken in the seaports of\r\nthe Celestial Empire. While these words have been carried as it were\r\ninto the families of the upper and middle classes, persons in a humbler\r\nrank of life, through the sailors and soldiers and Lascar and Chinese\r\nbeggars that haunt the metropolis, have also adopted many Anglo-Indian\r\nand Anglo-Chinese phrases. As this dictionary would have been incomplete\r\nwithout them, they are carefully recorded in its pages. Concerning the\r\nSlang of the fashionable world, it has been remarked that it is mostly\r\nimported from France; and that an unmeaning gibberish of Gallicisms runs\r\nthrough English fashionable conversation and fashionable novels, and\r\naccounts of fashionable parties in the fashionable newspapers. Yet,\r\nludicrously enough, immediately the fashionable magnates of England\r\nseize on any French idiom, the French themselves not only universally\r\nabandon it to us, but positively repudiate it altogether from their\r\nidiomatic vocabulary. If you were to tell a well-bred Frenchman that\r\nsuch and such an aristocratic marriage was on the _tapis_, he would\r\nstare with astonishment, and look down on the carpet in the startled\r\nendeavour to find a marriage in so unusual a place. If you were to talk\r\nto him of the _beau monde_, he would imagine you meant the world which\r\nGod made, not half-a-dozen streets and squares between Hyde Park Corner\r\nand Chelsea Bun House. The _th\xc3\xa9 dansant_ would be completely\r\ninexplicable to him. If you were to point out to him the Dowager Lady\r\nGrimgriffin acting as _chaperon_ to Lady Amanda Creamville, he would\r\nimagine you were referring to the _petit Chaperon rouge_\xe2\x80\x94to little\r\nRed-Riding Hood. He might just understand what was meant by _vis-\xc3\xa0-vis_,\r\n_entremets_, and some others of the flying horde of frivolous little\r\nforeign slangisms hovering about fashionable cookery and fashionable\r\nfurniture; but three-fourths of them would seem to him as barbarous\r\nFrench provincialisms, or, at best, but as antiquated and obsolete\r\nexpressions, picked out of the letters of Mademoiselle Scuderi, or the\r\ntales of Crebillon \xe2\x80\x9cthe younger.\xe2\x80\x9d Servants, too, appropriate the scraps\r\nof French conversation which fall from their masters\xe2\x80\x99 guests at the\r\ndinner table, and forthwith in the world of flunkeydom the word \xe2\x80\x9cknow\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nis disused, and the lady\xe2\x80\x99s-maid, in doubt on a particular point, asks\r\nJohn whether or no he \xe2\x80\x9csaveys\xe2\x80\x9d it?[45] What, too, can be more abominable\r\nthan that heartless piece of fashionable newspaper Slang, regularly\r\nemployed when speaking of the successful courtship of young people in\r\nthe aristocratic world:\xe2\x80\x94\r\n\r\n    MARRIAGE IN HIGH LIFE.\xe2\x80\x94We understand that a marriage is ARRANGED (!)\r\n    betwixt the Lady, &c. &c., and the Honourable, &c. &c.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cArranged!\xe2\x80\x9d Is that cold-blooded Smithfield or Mark Lane term for a sale\r\nor a purchase the proper word to express the hopeful, joyous, golden\r\nunion of young and trustful hearts? Possibly, though, the word is often\r\nused with a due regard to facts, for marriages, especially amongst our\r\nupper classes, are not always \xe2\x80\x9cmade in heaven.\xe2\x80\x9d Which is the proper way\r\nto pronounce the names of great people, and what the correct authority?\r\nLord Cowper, we are often assured, is Lord _Cooper_\xe2\x80\x94on this principle\r\nLord Cowley would certainly be Lord _Cooley_\xe2\x80\x94and Mr. Carew, we are\r\ntold, should be Mr. _Carey_, Ponsonby should be _Punsunby_, Eyre should\r\nbe _Aire_, Cholmondeley should be _Chumley_, St. John _Sinjen_,\r\nBeauchamp should be _Beachem_, Majoribanks _Marshbanks_, and Powell\r\nshould always be _Poel_. The pronunciation of proper names has long been\r\nan anomaly in the conversation of the upper classes of this country.\r\nHodge and Podge, the clodhoppers of Shakspeare\xe2\x80\x99s time, talked in their\r\nmug-houses of the great Lords _Darbie_, _Barkelie_, and _Bartie_. In\r\nPall Mall and May Fair these personages are spoken of in exactly the\r\nsame manner at the present day, whilst in the City, and amongst the\r\n_middle_ classes, we only hear of Derby, Berkeley, &c.,\xe2\x80\x94the correct\r\npronunciations, if the spelling is worth aught. It must not be\r\nforgotten, however, that the pronunciation of the upper classes, as\r\nregards the names of places just mentioned, is a relic of old times when\r\nthe orthography was different. The middle-class man is satisfied to take\r\nmatters the modern way, but even he, when he wishes to be thought a\r\nswell, alters his style. In fact, the old rule as to proper names being\r\npronounced according to individual taste, is, and ever will be, of\r\nabsolute necessity, not only as regards the upper and middle, but the\r\nlower classes. A costermonger is ignorant of such a place as Birmingham,\r\nbut understands you in a moment if you talk of _Brummagem_. Why do not\r\nPall Mall exquisites join with the costermongers in this pronunciation?\r\nIt is the ancient one.[46]\r\n\r\n_Parliamentary Slang_, excepting a few peculiar terms connected with\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c_the_ House\xe2\x80\x9d (scarcely Slang), is mainly composed of fashionable,\r\nliterary, and learned Slang. When members get excited, and wish to be\r\nforcible, they are now and again, but not very often, found guilty of\r\nvulgarisms, and then may be not particular which of the street terms\r\nthey select, providing it carries, as good old Dr. South said, plenty of\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cwildfire\xe2\x80\x9d in it. Lord Cairns when Sir Hugh, and a member of the Lower\r\nHouse, spoke of \xe2\x80\x9cthat homely but expressive phrase, \xe2\x80\x98dodge.\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d Out of\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cthe House,\xe2\x80\x9d several Slang terms are used in connexion with Parliament\r\nor members of Parliament. If Lord Palmerston was familiar by name to the\r\ntribes of the Caucasus and Asia Minor as a great foreign diplomatist,\r\nwhen the name of our Queen was unknown to the inhabitants of those\r\nparts\xe2\x80\x94as was once stated in the _Times_\xe2\x80\x94it is worthy of remark that,\r\namongst the costers and the wild inhabitants of the streets, he was at\r\nthat time better known as \xe2\x80\x9cPam.\xe2\x80\x9d The cabmen on the \xe2\x80\x9cranks\xe2\x80\x9d in Piccadilly\r\nhave been often heard to call each other\xe2\x80\x99s attention to the great\r\nleader of the Opposition in the following expressive manner\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cHollo,\r\nthere! de yer see old \xe2\x80\x98Dizzy\xe2\x80\x99 doing a stump?\xe2\x80\x9d A \xe2\x80\x9cplumper\xe2\x80\x9d is a single\r\nvote at an election\xe2\x80\x94not a \xe2\x80\x9csplit-ticket;\xe2\x80\x9d and electors who had occupied\r\na house, no matter how small, and boiled a pot in it, thus qualifying\r\nthemselves for voting, used in the good old days to be termed\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cpotwallopers.\xe2\x80\x9d A quiet \xe2\x80\x9cwalk over\xe2\x80\x9d is a re-election without opposition\r\nand much cost; and is obtained from the sporting vocabulary, in which\r\nthe term is not Slang. A \xe2\x80\x9ccaucus\xe2\x80\x9d meeting refers to the private\r\nassembling of politicians before an election, when candidates are\r\nchosen, and measures of action agreed upon. The term comes from America,\r\nwhere caucus means a meeting simply. A \xe2\x80\x9cjob,\xe2\x80\x9d in political phraseology,\r\nis a Government office or contract obtained by secret influence or\r\nfavouritism; and is not a whit more objectionable in sound than is the\r\nnefarious proceeding offensive to the sense of those who pay but do not\r\nparticipate. The _Times_ once spoke of \xe2\x80\x9cthe patriotic member of\r\nParliament \xe2\x80\x98potted out\xe2\x80\x99 in a dusty little lodging somewhere about Bury\r\nStreet.\xe2\x80\x9d But then the _Times_ was not always the mildly respectable\r\nhigh-class paper it now is, as a reference to the columns devoted by it\r\nto Macaulay\xe2\x80\x99s official career will alone determine. These, which\r\nappeared during the present reign, would be far below the lowest\r\njournalistic taste nowadays; yet they are in keeping with the rest of\r\nthe political references made at that time by the now austere and\r\nhigh-principled \xe2\x80\x9cleading journal.\xe2\x80\x9d The term \xe2\x80\x9cquockerwodger,\xe2\x80\x9d although\r\nreferring to a wooden toy figure which jerks its limbs about when pulled\r\nby a string, has been supplemented with a political meaning. A\r\npseudo-politician, whose strings of action are pulled by somebody else,\r\nis often termed a \xe2\x80\x9cquockerwodger.\xe2\x80\x9d From an early period politics and\r\npartyism have attracted unto themselves quaint Slang terms. Horace\r\nWalpole quotes a party nickname of February, 1742, as a Slang word of\r\nthe day:\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cThe Tories declare against any further prosecution, if Tories\r\nthere are, for now one hears of nothing but the \xe2\x80\x98broad-bottom;\xe2\x80\x99 it is\r\nthe reigning Cant word, and means the taking all parties and people,\r\nindifferently, into the Ministry.\xe2\x80\x9d Thus \xe2\x80\x9cbroad-bottom\xe2\x80\x9d in those days was\r\nSlang for \xe2\x80\x9ccoalition.\xe2\x80\x9d The term \xe2\x80\x9crat,\xe2\x80\x9d too, in allusion to rats\r\ndeserting vessels about to sink, has long been employed towards those\r\nturncoat politicians who change their party for interest. Who that\r\noccasionally passes near the Houses of Parliament has not often noticed\r\nstout or careful M.P.\xe2\x80\x99s walk briskly through the Hall, and on the\r\nkerb-stone in front, with umbrella or walking-cane uplifted, shout to\r\nthe cabmen on the rank, \xe2\x80\x9cFour-wheeler!\xe2\x80\x9d The term is both useful and\r\nexpressive; but it is none the less Slang, though of a better kind than\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cgrowler,\xe2\x80\x9d used to denominate the same kind of vehicle, or \xe2\x80\x9cshoful,\xe2\x80\x9d the\r\nstreet term for a hansom cab.\r\n\r\nMilitary Slang is on a par, and of a character, with dandy Slang.\r\nInconvenient friends, or elderly and lecturing relatives, are pronounced\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cdreadful bores.\xe2\x80\x9d This affectionate term, like most other Slang phrases\r\nwhich have their rise in a certain section of society, has spread and\r\nbecome of general application. Four-wheeled cabs are called \xe2\x80\x9cbounders;\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nand a member of the Four-in-hand Club, driving to Epsom on the Derby\r\nDay, would, using fashionable phraseology, speak of it as \xe2\x80\x9ctooling his\r\ndrag down to the Derby.\xe2\x80\x9d A vehicle, if not a \xe2\x80\x9cdrag\xe2\x80\x9d (or dwag), is a\r\n\xe2\x80\x9ctrap,\xe2\x80\x9d or a \xe2\x80\x9ccask;\xe2\x80\x9d and if the \xe2\x80\x9cturn-out\xe2\x80\x9d happens to be in other than a\r\ntrim condition, it is pronounced at once as not \xe2\x80\x9cdown the road,\xe2\x80\x9d unless\r\nthe critic should prefer to characterize the equipage as \xe2\x80\x9cdickey.\xe2\x80\x9d Your\r\nCity swell would say it is not \xe2\x80\x9cup to the mark;\xe2\x80\x9d whilst the costermonger\r\nwould call it a \xe2\x80\x9cwery snide affair.\xe2\x80\x9d In the army a barrack or military\r\nstation is known as a \xe2\x80\x9clobster-box;\xe2\x80\x9d to \xe2\x80\x9ccram\xe2\x80\x9d for an examination is to\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cmug-up\xe2\x80\x9d (this same term is much in vogue among actors, who regard\r\nmugging-up as one of the fine arts of the profession); to reject from\r\nthe examination is to \xe2\x80\x9cspin;\xe2\x80\x9d and that part of the barrack occupied by\r\nsubalterns is frequently spoken of as the \xe2\x80\x9crookery.\xe2\x80\x9d In dandy or swell\r\nSlang, any celebrity, from the Poet-Laureate to the Pope of Rome, is a\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cswell,\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cthe old swell\xe2\x80\x9d now occupies the place once held by the\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cguv\xe2\x80\x99nor.\xe2\x80\x9d Wrinkled-faced old professors, who hold dress and fashionable\r\ntailors in abhorrence, are called \xe2\x80\x9cawful swells,\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94if they happen to be\r\nvery learned or clever. In this upper-class Slang, a title is termed a\r\n\xe2\x80\x9chandle;\xe2\x80\x9d trousers, \xe2\x80\x9cinexpressibles,\xe2\x80\x9d and bags, or \xe2\x80\x9chowling bags,\xe2\x80\x9d when\r\nof a large pattern;\xe2\x80\x94a superior appearance, or anything above the common\r\ncut, is styled \xe2\x80\x9cextensive;\xe2\x80\x9d a four-wheeled cab is called a \xe2\x80\x9cbirdcage;\xe2\x80\x9d a\r\ndance, a \xe2\x80\x9chop;\xe2\x80\x9d dining at another man\xe2\x80\x99s table, \xe2\x80\x9csitting under his\r\nmahogany;\xe2\x80\x9d anything flashy or showy, \xe2\x80\x9cloud;\xe2\x80\x9d the peculiar make or cut of\r\na coat, its \xe2\x80\x9cbuild;\xe2\x80\x9d full dress, \xe2\x80\x9cfull fig;\xe2\x80\x9d wearing clothes which\r\nrepresent the very extreme of fashion, \xe2\x80\x9cdressing to death;\xe2\x80\x9d a dinner or\r\nsupper party, a \xe2\x80\x9cspread;\xe2\x80\x9d a friend (or a \xe2\x80\x9cgood fellow\xe2\x80\x9d), a \xe2\x80\x9ctrump;\xe2\x80\x9d a\r\ndifficulty, a \xe2\x80\x9cscrew loose;\xe2\x80\x9d and everything that is unpleasant, \xe2\x80\x9cfrom\r\nbad sherry to a writ from a tailor,\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9cjeuced infernal.\xe2\x80\x9d The phrase, \xe2\x80\x9cto\r\nsend a man to Coventry,\xe2\x80\x9d or permit no person \xe2\x80\x9cin the set\xe2\x80\x9d to speak to\r\nhim, although an ancient saying, must still be considered Slang.\r\n\r\nThe Universities of Oxford and Cambridge, and the great public schools,\r\nare the hotbeds of fashionable Slang. Growing boys and high-spirited\r\nyoung fellows detest restraint of all kinds, and prefer making a dash at\r\nlife in a Slang phraseology of their own to all the set forms and\r\nsyntactical rules of _Alma Mater_. Many of the most expressive words in\r\na common chit-chat, or free-and-easy conversation, are old university\r\nvulgarisms. \xe2\x80\x9cCut,\xe2\x80\x9d in the sense of dropping an acquaintance, was\r\noriginally a Cambridge form of speech; and \xe2\x80\x9choax,\xe2\x80\x9d to deceive or\r\nridicule, we are informed by Grose, was many years since an Oxford term.\r\nAmong the words that fast society has borrowed from our great\r\nscholastic\xe2\x80\x94not establishments (they are sacred to linendrapery and\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cgentlemanly assistants\xe2\x80\x9d)\xe2\x80\x94institutions, is found \xe2\x80\x9ccrib,\xe2\x80\x9d a house or\r\napartments; \xe2\x80\x9cdead men,\xe2\x80\x9d empty wine bottles; \xe2\x80\x9cdrawing teeth,\xe2\x80\x9d[47]\r\nwrenching off knockers,\xe2\x80\x94an obsolete amusement; \xe2\x80\x9cfizzing,\xe2\x80\x9d first-rate,\r\nor splendid; \xe2\x80\x9cgovernor,\xe2\x80\x9d or \xe2\x80\x9crelieving-officer,\xe2\x80\x9d the general term for a\r\nmale parent; \xe2\x80\x9cplucked,\xe2\x80\x9d defeated or turned back, now altered to\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cplough;\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9cquiz,\xe2\x80\x9d to scrutinize, or a prying old fellow; and \xe2\x80\x9crow,\xe2\x80\x9d a\r\nnoisy disturbance. The Slang words in use at Oxford and Cambridge would\r\nalone fill a volume. As examples let us take \xe2\x80\x9cscout,\xe2\x80\x9d which at Oxford\r\nrefers to an undergraduate\xe2\x80\x99s valet, whilst the same menial at Cambridge\r\nis termed a \xe2\x80\x9cgyp,\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94popularly derived by the Cantabs from the Greek,\r\n\xce\xb3\xe1\xbd\xba\xcf\x88, a vulture; \xe2\x80\x9cskull,\xe2\x80\x9d the head, or master, of a college; \xe2\x80\x9cbattles,\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nthe Oxford term for rations, changed at Cambridge into \xe2\x80\x9ccommons.\xe2\x80\x9d The\r\nterm \xe2\x80\x9cdickey,\xe2\x80\x9d a half-shirt, it is said, originated with the students of\r\nTrinity College, Dublin, who at first styled it a \xe2\x80\x9ctommy,\xe2\x80\x9d from the\r\nGreek \xcf\x84\xce\xbf\xce\xbc\xe1\xbd\xb4, a section,\xe2\x80\x94the change from \xe2\x80\x9ctommy\xe2\x80\x9d to \xe2\x80\x9cdickey\xe2\x80\x9d requires no\r\nexplanation. \xe2\x80\x9cCrib,\xe2\x80\x9d a literal translation, is now universal; \xe2\x80\x9cgrind\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nrefers to \xe2\x80\x9cworking up\xe2\x80\x9d for an examination, also to a walk or\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cconstitutional;\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9cHivite\xe2\x80\x9d is a student of St. Begh\xe2\x80\x99s (St. Bee\xe2\x80\x99s)\r\nCollege, Cumberland; to \xe2\x80\x9cjapan,\xe2\x80\x9d in this Slang speech, is to ordain;\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cmortar board\xe2\x80\x9d is a square college cap; \xe2\x80\x9csim,\xe2\x80\x9d a student of a\r\nMethodistical turn\xe2\x80\x94in allusion to the Rev. Charles Simeon; \xe2\x80\x9csloggers,\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nat Cambridge, refers to the second division of race-boats, known at\r\nOxford as \xe2\x80\x9ctorpids;\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9csport\xe2\x80\x9d is to show or exhibit; \xe2\x80\x9ctrotter\xe2\x80\x9d is the\r\njocose term for a tailor\xe2\x80\x99s man who goes round for orders; and \xe2\x80\x9ctufts\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nare privileged students who dine with the \xe2\x80\x9cdons,\xe2\x80\x9d and are distinguished\r\nby golden tufts, or tassels, in their caps. Hence we get the world-wide\r\nSlang term \xe2\x80\x9ctuft-hunter,\xe2\x80\x9d one whose pride it is to be acquainted with\r\nscions of the nobility\xe2\x80\x94a sycophantic race unfortunately not confined\r\nto any particular place or climate, nor peculiar to any age or either\r\nsex. There are many terms in use at Oxford not known at Cambridge; and\r\nsuch Slang names as \xe2\x80\x9ccoach,\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9cgulf,\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9charry-soph,\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9cpoker,\xe2\x80\x9d or\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cpost-mortem,\xe2\x80\x9d common enough at Cambridge, are seldom or never heard\r\nat the great sister University. For numerous other examples of college\r\nSlang the reader is referred to the Dictionary.\r\n\r\nReligious Slang, strange as the compound may appear, exists with other\r\ndescriptions of vulgar speech at the present day. _Punch_, in one of\r\nthose half-humorous, half-serious articles, once so characteristic of\r\nthe wits engaged on that paper, who were, as a rule, fond of lecturing\r\nany national abuse or popular folly, remarked\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cSlang has long since\r\npenetrated into the Forum, and now we meet it in the Senate, and even\r\nthe pulpit itself is no longer free from its intrusion.\xe2\x80\x9d There is no\r\nwish here, for one moment, to infer that the practice is general. On the\r\ncontrary, and in justice to the clergy, it must be said that the\r\nprincipal disseminators of pure English throughout the country are the\r\nministers of our Established Church. Yet it cannot be denied that a\r\ngreat deal of Slang phraseology and expressive vulgarism have gradually\r\ncrept into the very pulpits which should give forth as pure speech as\r\ndoctrine. This is an error which, however, has only to be noticed, to be\r\ncured.\r\n\r\nDean Conybeare, in his able \xe2\x80\x9cEssay on Church Parties,\xe2\x80\x9d[48] has noticed\r\nthis addition of Slang to our pulpit speech. As stated in his Essay, the\r\npractice appears to confine itself mainly to the exaggerated forms of\r\nthe High and Low Church\xe2\x80\x94the Tractarians and the \xe2\x80\x9cRecordites.\xe2\x80\x9d[49] By\r\nway of illustration, the Dean cites the evening parties, or social\r\nmeetings, common amongst the wealthier lay members of the Recordite\r\nchurches, where the principal topics discussed\xe2\x80\x94one or more favourite\r\nclergymen being present in a quasi-official manner\xe2\x80\x94are \xe2\x80\x9cthe merits and\r\ndemerits of different preachers, the approaching restoration of the\r\nJews, the date of the Millennium, the progress of the \xe2\x80\x98Tractarian\r\nheresy,\xe2\x80\x99 and the anticipated \xe2\x80\x98perversion\xe2\x80\x99 of High Church neighbours.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nThese subjects are canvassed in a dialect differing considerably from\r\nEnglish, as the word is generally understood. The terms \xe2\x80\x9cfaithful,\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\xe2\x80\x9ctainted,\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9cacceptable,\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9cdecided,\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9clegal,\xe2\x80\x9d and many others,\r\nare used in a sense different from that given to any of them by the\r\nlexicographers. We hear that Mr. A. has been more \xe2\x80\x9cowned\xe2\x80\x9d than Mr. B.;\r\nand that Mr. C. has more \xe2\x80\x9cseals\xe2\x80\x9d[50] than Mr. D. Again, the word\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cgracious\xe2\x80\x9d is invested with a meaning as extensive as that attached by\r\nyoung ladies to nice. Thus, we hear of a \xe2\x80\x9cgracious sermon,\xe2\x80\x9d a \xe2\x80\x9cgracious\r\nmeeting,\xe2\x80\x9d a \xe2\x80\x9cgracious child,\xe2\x80\x9d and even a \xe2\x80\x9cgracious whipping.\xe2\x80\x9d The word\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cdark\xe2\x80\x9d has also a new and peculiar usage. It is applied to every person,\r\nbook, or place not impregnated with Recordite principles. A ludicrous\r\nmisunderstanding resulting from this phraseology is on record (this is\r\nnot a joke). \xe2\x80\x9cWhat did you mean,\xe2\x80\x9d said A. to B., \xe2\x80\x9cby telling me that\r\n---- was such a very \xe2\x80\x98dark\xe2\x80\x99 village? I rode over there to-day, and found\r\nthe street particularly broad and cheerful, and there is not a tree in\r\nthe place.\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9cThe gospel is not preached there,\xe2\x80\x9d was B\xe2\x80\x99s. laconic reply.\r\nThe conclusion of one of these singular evening parties is generally\r\nmarked by an \xe2\x80\x9cexposition\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94an unseasonable sermon of nearly one hour\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nduration, circumscribed by no text, and delivered from the table by one\r\nof the clerical visitors with a view to \xe2\x80\x9cimprove the occasion.\xe2\x80\x9d This\r\nsame term, \xe2\x80\x9cimprove the occasion,\xe2\x80\x9d is of Slang slangy, and is so mouthed\r\nby Stigginses and Chadbands, and their followers, that it has become\r\npeculiarly objectionable to persons of broad views. In the Essay to\r\nwhich reference has been made, the religious Slang terms for the two\r\ngreat divisions of the Established Church receive some explanation. The\r\nold-fashioned High Church party\xe2\x80\x94rich and \xe2\x80\x9cstagnant,\xe2\x80\x9d noted for its\r\n\xe2\x80\x9csluggish mediocrity, hatred of zeal, dread of innovation, abuse of\r\nDissent, blundering and languid utterance\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94is called the \xe2\x80\x9chigh and\r\ndry;\xe2\x80\x9d whilst the opposing division, known as the Low Church\xe2\x80\x94equally\r\nstagnant with the former, but poorer, and more lazily inclined (from\r\nabsence of education) towards Dissent\xe2\x80\x94receives the nickname of the \xe2\x80\x9clow\r\nand slow.\xe2\x80\x9d These terms are among persons learned in the distinctions\r\nshortened, in ordinary conversation, to the \xe2\x80\x9cdry\xe2\x80\x9d and the \xe2\x80\x9cslow.\xe2\x80\x9d The\r\nBroad Church, or moderate division, is often spoken of as the \xe2\x80\x9cbroad\r\nand shallow.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nWhat can be more objectionable than the irreverent and offensive manner\r\nin which many Dissenting ministers continually pronounce the names of\r\nthe Deity\xe2\x80\x94God and Lord? God, instead of pronouncing in the plain and\r\nbeautiful simple old English way, \xe2\x80\x9cG\xe2\x80\x91o\xe2\x80\x91d,\xe2\x80\x9d they drawl out into \xe2\x80\x9cGorde\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nor \xe2\x80\x9cGaude;\xe2\x80\x9d and Lord, instead of speaking in the proper way, they\r\ndesecrate into \xe2\x80\x9cLoard\xe2\x80\x9d or \xe2\x80\x9cLoerd,\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94lingering on the _u_, or the _r_, as\r\nthe case may be, until an honest hearer feels disgusted, and almost\r\ninclined to run the gauntlet of beadles and deacons, and pull the vulgar\r\npreacher from his pulpit. This is, though a Christian impulse, hardly in\r\naccordance with our modern times and tolerant habits. Many young\r\npreachers strive hard to acquire this peculiar pronunciation, in\r\nimitation of the older ministers. What, then, can more properly be\r\ncalled Slang, or, indeed, the most objectionable of Slang, than this\r\nstudious endeavour to pronounce the most sacred names in a uniformly\r\nvulgar and unbecoming manner? If the old-fashioned preacher whistled\r\nCant through his nose, the modern vulgar reverend whines Slang from the\r\nmore natural organ. These vagaries of speech will, perhaps, by an\r\napologist, be termed \xe2\x80\x9cpulpit peculiarities,\xe2\x80\x9d and the writer may be\r\nimpugned for having dared to intermeddle with a subject that is or\r\nshould be removed from his criticisms. Honesty of purpose and evident\r\ntruthfulness of remark will, however, overcome the most virulent\r\nopposition. The terms used by the mob towards the Church, however\r\nilliberal and satirically vulgar, are fairly within the province of an\r\ninquiry such as the present. A clergyman, in vulgar language, is spoken\r\nof as a \xe2\x80\x9cchoker,\xe2\x80\x9d a \xe2\x80\x9ccushion-thumper,\xe2\x80\x9d a \xe2\x80\x9cdominie,\xe2\x80\x9d an \xe2\x80\x9cearwig,\xe2\x80\x9d a\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cgospel-grinder,\xe2\x80\x9d a \xe2\x80\x9cgrey-coat parson;\xe2\x80\x9d a \xe2\x80\x9cspouter,\xe2\x80\x9d a \xe2\x80\x9cwhite-choker,\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nor a \xe2\x80\x9cwarming-pan rector,\xe2\x80\x9d if he only holds the living _pro tempore_. If\r\nhe is a lessee of the great tithes, \xe2\x80\x9cone in ten;\xe2\x80\x9d or if spoken of by an\r\nAnglo-Indian, a \xe2\x80\x9crook.\xe2\x80\x9d If a Tractarian, his outer garment is rudely\r\nspoken of as a \xe2\x80\x9cpygostole,\xe2\x80\x9d or \xe2\x80\x9cM. B. (mark of the beast) coat.\xe2\x80\x9d His\r\nprofession is termed \xe2\x80\x9cthe cloth\xe2\x80\x9d (this item of Slang has been already\r\nreferred to), and his practice is called \xe2\x80\x9ctub-thumping.\xe2\x80\x9d This latter\r\nterm has of late years been almost peculiarly confined to itinerant\r\npreachers. Should he belong to the Dissenting body, he is probably\r\nstyled a \xe2\x80\x9cpantiler,\xe2\x80\x9d or a \xe2\x80\x9cpsalm smiter,\xe2\x80\x9d or perhaps, a \xe2\x80\x9cswaddler.\xe2\x80\x9d[51]\r\nHis chapel, too, is spoken of as a \xe2\x80\x9cschism shop.\xe2\x80\x9d A Roman Catholic is\r\ncoarsely named a \xe2\x80\x9cbrisket-beater.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nParticular as lawyers generally are about the meanings of words, they\r\nhave not prevented an unauthorized phraseology from arising, which may\r\nbe termed legal Slang. So forcibly did this truth impress a late writer,\r\nthat he wrote in a popular journal, \xe2\x80\x9cYou may hear Slang every day in\r\nterm from barristers in their robes, at every mess-table, at every\r\nbar-mess, at every college commons, and in every club dining-room.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nSwift, in his _Art of Polite Conversation_ (p. 15), published a century\r\nand a half ago, states that \xe2\x80\x9cvardi\xe2\x80\x9d was the Slang in his time for\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cverdict.\xe2\x80\x9d A few of the most common and well-known terms used out of\r\ndoors, with reference to legal matters, are \xe2\x80\x9ccook,\xe2\x80\x9d to hash or make up a\r\nbalance-sheet; \xe2\x80\x9cdipped,\xe2\x80\x9d mortgaged; \xe2\x80\x9cdun\xe2\x80\x9d (from a famous writ or\r\nprocess-server named Dunn), to solicit payment; \xe2\x80\x9cfullied,\xe2\x80\x9d to be \xe2\x80\x9cfully\r\ncommitted for trial;\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9cland shark,\xe2\x80\x9d a sailor\xe2\x80\x99s definition of a lawyer;\r\n\xe2\x80\x9climb of the law,\xe2\x80\x9d a milder term for the same \xe2\x80\x9cprofessional;\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9cmonkey\r\nwith a long tail,\xe2\x80\x9d a mortgage; \xe2\x80\x9cmouthpiece,\xe2\x80\x9d the thief\xe2\x80\x99s term for his\r\ncounsel; \xe2\x80\x9cto run through the ring,\xe2\x80\x9d to take advantage of the Insolvency\r\nAct; \xe2\x80\x9csmash,\xe2\x80\x9d to become bankrupt; \xe2\x80\x9csnipe,\xe2\x80\x9d an attorney with a long bill;\r\nand \xe2\x80\x9cwhitewash,\xe2\x80\x9d to take the benefit of the Insolvent Act. Comparatively\r\nrecent legislation has rendered many of these terms obsolete, and \xe2\x80\x9cin\r\nliquidation\xe2\x80\x9d is now the most ominous sound a creditor can hear. Lawyers,\r\nfrom their connexion with the police courts, and transactions with\r\npersons in every grade of society, have ample opportunities for\r\nacquiring street Slang, of which, in cross-questioning and wrangling,\r\nthey frequently avail themselves.\r\n\r\nIt has been said there exists a literary Slang, or the Slang of\r\nCriticism\xe2\x80\x94dramatic, artistic, and scientific. This is composed of such\r\nwords as \xe2\x80\x9c\xc3\xa6sthetic,\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9ctranscendental,\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9cthe harmonies,\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9cthe unities,\xe2\x80\x9d a\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cmyth;\xe2\x80\x9d such phrases as \xe2\x80\x9can exquisite _morceau_ on the big drum,\xe2\x80\x9d a\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cscholarlike rendering of John the Baptist\xe2\x80\x99s great toe,\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9ckeeping\r\nharmony,\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9cmiddle distance,\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9ca\xc3\xabrial perspective,\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9cdelicate handling,\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cnervous chiaroscuro,\xe2\x80\x9d and the like. It is easy to find fault with this\r\nsystem of doing work, whilst it is not easy to discover another at once\r\nso easily understood by educated readers, and so satisfactory to artists\r\nthemselves. Discretion must, of course, always be used, in fact always\r\nis used by the best writers, with regard to the quantity of technical\r\nSlang an article will hold comfortably. Overdone mannerism is always a\r\nmistake, and generally defeats its own end. Properly used, these\r\ntechnicalities are allowable as the generous inflections and bendings of\r\na bountiful language, for the purpose of expressing fresh phases of\r\nthought, and ideas not yet provided with representative words.[52]\r\n_Punch_ often employs a Slang term to give point to a joke, or humour to\r\na line of satire. In his best day he gave an original etymology of the\r\nschoolboy-ism \xe2\x80\x9cslog.\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9cSlog,\xe2\x80\x9d said the classical and then clever\r\n_Punch_, is derived from the Greek word \xe2\x80\x9cslogo,\xe2\x80\x9d to baste, to wallop, to\r\nslaughter. To show his partiality to the subject, he once amused his\r\nreaders with two columns on Slang and Sanscrit, from which the following\r\nis taken:\xe2\x80\x94\r\n\r\n    \xe2\x80\x9cThe allegory which pervades the conversation of all Eastern nations\r\n    is the foundation of Western Slang; and the increased number of\r\n    students of the Oriental languages, especially since Sanscrit and\r\n    Arabic have been made subjects for the Indian Civil Service\r\n    examinations, may have contributed to supply the English language\r\n    with a large portion of its new dialect. While, however, the spirit\r\n    of allegory comes from the East, there is so great a difference\r\n    between the brevity of Western expression and the more cumbrous\r\n    diction of the Oriental, that the origin of a phrase becomes\r\n    difficult to trace. Thus, for instance, whilst the Turkish merchant\r\n    might address his friend somewhat as follows\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x98That which seems good\r\n    to my father is to his servant as the perfumed breath of the west\r\n    wind in the calm night of the Arabian summer;\xe2\x80\x99 the Western\r\n    negotiator observes more briefly, \xe2\x80\x98all serene!\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d[53]\r\n\r\nBut the vulgar term, \xe2\x80\x9cbrick,\xe2\x80\x9d _Punch_ remarks in illustration,\r\n\r\n    \xe2\x80\x9cmust be allowed to be an exception, its Greek derivation being\r\n    universally admitted, corresponding so exactly as it does in its\r\n    rectangular form and compactness to the perfection of manhood,\r\n    according to the views of Plato and Simonides; but any deviation\r\n    from the simple expression, in which locality is indicated\xe2\x80\x94as, for\r\n    instance, \xe2\x80\x98a genuine Bath\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x94decidedly breathes the Oriental spirit.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nIt is singular that what _Punch_ says unwittingly and in humour\r\nrespecting the Slang expression \xe2\x80\x9cbosh,\xe2\x80\x9d should be quite true. \xe2\x80\x9cBosh,\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nremarks _Punch_, after speaking of it as belonging to the stock of words\r\npilfered from the Turks, \xe2\x80\x9cis one whose innate force and beauty the\r\nslangographer is reluctantly compelled to admit. It is the only word\r\nwhich seems a proper appellation for a great deal which we are obliged\r\nto hear and to read every day of our life.\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9cBosh,\xe2\x80\x9d nonsense or\r\nstupidity, is derived from the Gipsy and the Persian. The universality\r\nof Slang is proved by its continual use in the pages of _Punch_. Who\r\never thinks, unless belonging to a past generation, of asking a friend\r\nto explain the stray vulgar words employed by the _London Charivari_?\r\nSome of the jokes, though, might nowadays be accompanied by explanatory\r\nnotes, in similar style to that adopted by youthful artists who write \xe2\x80\x9ca\r\nman,\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9ca horse,\xe2\x80\x9d &c., when rather uncertain as to whether or not their\r\nefforts will meet with due appreciation.\r\n\r\nThe _Athen\xc3\xa6um_, the _Saturday Review_, and other kindred \xe2\x80\x9cweeklies,\xe2\x80\x9d\r\noften indulge in Slang words when force of expression or a little humour\r\nis desired, or when the various writers wish to say something which is\r\nbetter said in Slang, or so-called vulgar speech, than in the authorized\r\nlanguage. Bartlett, the compiler of the _Dictionary of Americanisms_,\r\ncontinually cites the _Athen\xc3\xa6um_ as using Slang and vulgar expressions;\r\nbut the magazine the American refers to is not the literary journal of\r\nthe present day,\xe2\x80\x94it was a smaller, and now defunct, \xe2\x80\x9cweekly.\xe2\x80\x9d The\r\npresent possessor of the classic title is, though, by no means\r\nbehindhand in its devotion to colloquialisms. Many other highly\r\nrespectable journals often use Slang words and phrases. The _Times_ (or,\r\nin Slang, the \xe2\x80\x9cThunderer\xe2\x80\x9d) frequently employs unauthorized terms; and,\r\nfollowing a \xe2\x80\x9cleader\xe2\x80\x9d[54] of the purest and most eloquent composition, may\r\nsometimes be seen another \xe2\x80\x9carticle\xe2\x80\x9d[54] on a totally different subject,\r\ncontaining, perhaps, a score or more of exceedingly questionable words.\r\nAmong the words and phrases which may be included under the head of\r\nLiterary Slang are, \xe2\x80\x9cbalaam,\xe2\x80\x9d matter kept constantly in type about\r\nmonstrous productions of nature, to fill up spaces in newspapers;\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cbalaam-box,\xe2\x80\x9d the term given in _Blackwood_ to the repository for\r\nrejected articles; and \xe2\x80\x9cslate,\xe2\x80\x9d to pelt with abuse, or \xe2\x80\x9ccut up\xe2\x80\x9d in a\r\nreview. \xe2\x80\x9cHe\xe2\x80\x99s the fellow to slate a piece\xe2\x80\x9d is often said of dramatic\r\ncritics, especially of those who through youth, inexperience, and the\r\nprocess of unnatural selection which causes them to be critics, imagine\r\nthat to abuse all that is above their comprehension is to properly\r\nexercise the critical faculty. This is, however, dangerous ground. The\r\nSlang names given to newspapers are curious;\xe2\x80\x94thus, the _Morning\r\nAdvertiser_ is known as the \xe2\x80\x9cTap-tub,\xe2\x80\x9d the \xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x99Tizer,\xe2\x80\x9d and was until\r\nrecently the \xe2\x80\x9cGin and Gospel Gazette.\xe2\x80\x9d The _Morning Post_ has obtained\r\nthe suggestive sobriquet of \xe2\x80\x9cJeames;\xe2\x80\x9d whilst the _Morning Herald_ was\r\nlong caricatured as \xe2\x80\x9cMrs. Harris,\xe2\x80\x9d and the _Standard_ as \xe2\x80\x9cMrs.\r\nGamp.\xe2\x80\x9d[55]\r\n\r\nThe _Stage_, of course, has its Slang\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cboth before and behind the\r\ncurtain,\xe2\x80\x9d as a journalist remarks. The stage-manager is familiarly\r\ntermed \xe2\x80\x9cdaddy;\xe2\x80\x9d and an actor by profession, or a \xe2\x80\x9cprofessional,\xe2\x80\x9d is\r\ncalled a \xe2\x80\x9cpro.\xe2\x80\x9d It is amusing at times to hear a young actor\xe2\x80\x94who struts\r\nabout padded with copies of all newspapers that have mentioned his\r\nname\xe2\x80\x94talking, in a mixed company, of the stage as _the_ profession.\r\nThis is after all but natural, for to him \xe2\x80\x9call the world\xe2\x80\x99s a stage.\xe2\x80\x9d A\r\nman who is occasionally hired at a trifling remuneration to come upon\r\nthe stage as one of a crowd, or when a number of actors are wanted to\r\ngive effect, is named a \xe2\x80\x9csupe,\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94an abbreviation of \xe2\x80\x9csupernumerary.\xe2\x80\x9d A\r\n\xe2\x80\x9csurf\xe2\x80\x9d is a third-rate actor, who frequently pursues another calling;\r\nand the band, or orchestra between the pit and the stage, is generally\r\nspoken of as the \xe2\x80\x9cmenagerie.\xe2\x80\x9d A \xe2\x80\x9cben\xe2\x80\x9d is a benefit; and \xe2\x80\x9csal\xe2\x80\x9d is the\r\nSlang abbreviation of \xe2\x80\x9csalary.\xe2\x80\x9d Should no money be forthcoming on the\r\nSaturday night, it is said that the \xe2\x80\x9cghost doesn\xe2\x80\x99t walk;\xe2\x80\x9d or else the\r\nstatement goes abroad that there is \xe2\x80\x9cno treasury,\xe2\x80\x9d as though the coffers\r\nthemselves had departed. The travelling or provincial theatricals, who\r\nperform in any large room that can be rented in a country village, are\r\ncalled \xe2\x80\x9cbarn-stormers.\xe2\x80\x9d A \xe2\x80\x9clength\xe2\x80\x9d is forty-two lines of any dramatic\r\ncomposition; and a \xe2\x80\x9crun\xe2\x80\x9d is the continuous term of a piece\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nperformance. A \xe2\x80\x9csaddle\xe2\x80\x9d is the additional charge made by a manager to an\r\nactor or actress upon his or her benefit night. To \xe2\x80\x9cmug up\xe2\x80\x9d is to paint\r\none\xe2\x80\x99s face, or arrange the person, to represent a particular character;\r\nto \xe2\x80\x9ccorpse,\xe2\x80\x9d or to \xe2\x80\x9cstick,\xe2\x80\x9d is to balk, or put the other actors out in\r\ntheir parts by forgetting yours. A performance is spoken of as either a\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cgooser\xe2\x80\x9d or a \xe2\x80\x9cscreamer,\xe2\x80\x9d should it be a failure or a great success;\xe2\x80\x94if\r\nthe latter, it is not infrequently termed a \xe2\x80\x9chit.\xe2\x80\x9d To \xe2\x80\x9cgoose\xe2\x80\x9d a\r\nperformance is to hiss it; and continued \xe2\x80\x9cgoosing\xe2\x80\x9d generally ends, or\r\ndid end before managers refused to accept the verdict of audiences, in\r\nthe play or the players being \xe2\x80\x9cdamned.\xe2\x80\x9d To \xe2\x80\x9cstar it\xe2\x80\x9d is to perform as\r\nthe centre of attraction, with your name in large type, and none but\r\nsubordinates and indifferent actors in the same performance. The\r\nexpressive term \xe2\x80\x9cclap-trap,\xe2\x80\x9d high-sounding nonsense, is nothing but an\r\nancient theatrical term, and signified a \xe2\x80\x9ctrap\xe2\x80\x9d to catch a \xe2\x80\x9cclap\xe2\x80\x9d by way\r\nof applause. \xe2\x80\x9cUp amongst the \xe2\x80\x98gods,\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d refers to being among the\r\nspectators in the gallery,\xe2\x80\x94termed in French Slang \xe2\x80\x9cparadis.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThere exists, too, in the great territory of vulgar speech what may not\r\ninappropriately be termed Civic Slang. It consists of mercantile and\r\nStock Exchange terms, and the Slang of good living and wealth. A turkey\r\nhung with sausages is facetiously styled an \xe2\x80\x9calderman in chains,\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94a\r\nterm which has spread from the City and become general; and a\r\nhalf-crown, perhaps from its rotundity, is often termed an \xe2\x80\x9calderman.\xe2\x80\x9d A\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cbear\xe2\x80\x9d is a speculator on the Exchange; and a \xe2\x80\x9cbull,\xe2\x80\x9d although of an\r\nopposite order, follows a like profession. There is something very\r\nhumorous and applicable in the Slang term \xe2\x80\x9clame duck,\xe2\x80\x9d a defaulter in\r\nstock-jobbing speculations. The allusion to his \xe2\x80\x9cwaddling out of the\r\nAlley,\xe2\x80\x9d as they say, is excellent. \xe2\x80\x9cBreaking shins,\xe2\x80\x9d in City Slang, is\r\nborrowing money; a rotten or unsound scheme is spoken of as \xe2\x80\x9cfishy;\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\xe2\x80\x9crigging the market\xe2\x80\x9d means playing tricks with it; and \xe2\x80\x9cstag\xe2\x80\x9d was a\r\ncommon term during the railway mania for a speculator without capital, a\r\nseller of \xe2\x80\x9cscrip\xe2\x80\x9d in \xe2\x80\x9cDiddlesex Junction\xe2\x80\x9d and other equally safe lines.\r\nAt Tattersall\xe2\x80\x99s a \xe2\x80\x9cmonkey\xe2\x80\x9d is 500_l._, and in the City a \xe2\x80\x9cplum\xe2\x80\x9d is\r\n100,000_l._, and a \xe2\x80\x9cmarygold\xe2\x80\x9d is one million sterling. But before\r\nproceeding further in a sketch of the different kinds of Slang, it may\r\nbe as well to speak here of the extraordinary number of Cant and Slang\r\nterms in use to represent money\xe2\x80\x94from farthings to bank-notes the value\r\nof fortunes. Her Majesty\xe2\x80\x99s coin, collectively or in the piece, is known\r\nby more than one hundred and thirty distinct Slang words, from the\r\nhumble \xe2\x80\x9cbrown\xe2\x80\x9d (a halfpenny) to \xe2\x80\x9cflimsies,\xe2\x80\x9d or \xe2\x80\x9clong-tailed ones\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n(bank-notes).\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMoney,\xe2\x80\x9d it has been well remarked, \xe2\x80\x9cthe bare, simple word itself, has a\r\nsonorous, significant ring in its sound,\xe2\x80\x9d and might have sufficed, one\r\nwould have imagined, for all ordinary purposes, excepting, of course,\r\nthose demanded by direct reference to specific sums. But a vulgar or\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cfast\xe2\x80\x9d society has thought differently; and so we have the Slang\r\nsynonyms\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cbeans,\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9cblunt\xe2\x80\x9d (_i.e._, specie,\xe2\x80\x94not soft or rags,\r\nbank-notes), \xe2\x80\x9cbrads,\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9cbrass,\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9cbustle,\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9ccoppers\xe2\x80\x9d (copper money, or\r\nmixed pence), \xe2\x80\x9cchink,\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9cchinkers,\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9cchips,\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9ccorks,\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9cdibbs,\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9cdinarly,\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cdimmock,\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9cdust,\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9cfeathers,\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9cgent\xe2\x80\x9d (silver,\xe2\x80\x94from argent), \xe2\x80\x9chaddock\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n(a purse of money), \xe2\x80\x9chorse nails,\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9chuckster,\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9cloaver,\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9clour\xe2\x80\x9d (the\r\noldest Cant term for money), \xe2\x80\x9cmopusses,\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9cneedful,\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9cnobbings\xe2\x80\x9d (money\r\ncollected in a hat by street-performers), \xe2\x80\x9cochre\xe2\x80\x9d (gold), \xe2\x80\x9cpewter,\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cpalm oil,\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9cpieces,\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9cposh,\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9cqueen\xe2\x80\x99s pictures,\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9cquids,\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9crags\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n(bank-notes), \xe2\x80\x9cready,\xe2\x80\x9d or \xe2\x80\x9cready gilt,\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9credge\xe2\x80\x9d (gold), \xe2\x80\x9crhino,\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\xe2\x80\x9crowdy,\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9cshiners\xe2\x80\x9d (sovereigns), \xe2\x80\x9cskin\xe2\x80\x9d (a purse of money), \xe2\x80\x9cstiff\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n(checks, or bills of acceptance), \xe2\x80\x9cstuff,\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9cstumpy,\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9ctin\xe2\x80\x9d (silver),\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cwedge\xe2\x80\x9d (silver), and \xe2\x80\x9cyellow-boys\xe2\x80\x9d (sovereigns);\xe2\x80\x94just forty-three\r\nvulgar equivalents for the simple word money. So attentive is Slang\r\nspeech to financial matters, that there are seven terms for bad, or\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cbogus,\xe2\x80\x9d coin (as our friends the Americans call it): a \xe2\x80\x9ccase\xe2\x80\x9d is a\r\ncounterfeit five-shilling piece; \xe2\x80\x9chalf a case\xe2\x80\x9d represents half that sum;\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cgrays\xe2\x80\x9d are halfpence made specially for unfair gambling purposes;\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cqueer-soft\xe2\x80\x9d is counterfeit or lead coin; \xe2\x80\x9cschofel\xe2\x80\x9d refers to coated or\r\nspurious coin; \xe2\x80\x9csheen\xe2\x80\x9d is bad money of any description; and \xe2\x80\x9csinkers\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nbears the same and not inappropriate meaning. \xe2\x80\x9cSnide\xe2\x80\x9d is now the generic\r\nterm for all bad money, whether coined or in notes; and \xe2\x80\x9csnide-pitching\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nor \xe2\x80\x9cschoful-tossing\xe2\x80\x9d is the term in use among the professors of that\r\npursuit for what is more generally known as \xe2\x80\x9csmashing.\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9cFlying the\r\nkite,\xe2\x80\x9d or obtaining money on bills and promissory-notes, is closely\r\nconnected with the allegorical expression of \xe2\x80\x9craising the wind,\xe2\x80\x9d which\r\nis a well-known phrase for procuring money by immediate sale, pledging,\r\nor by a forced loan. In winter or in summer any elderly gentleman who\r\nmay have prospered in life is pronounced \xe2\x80\x9cwarm;\xe2\x80\x9d whilst an equivalent is\r\nimmediately at hand in the phrase \xe2\x80\x9chis pockets are well lined,\xe2\x80\x9d or \xe2\x80\x9che\r\nis well breeched.\xe2\x80\x9d Each separate piece of money has its own Slang term,\r\nand often half a score of synonyms. To begin with that extremely humble\r\ncoin, a farthing: first we have \xe2\x80\x9cfadge,\xe2\x80\x9d then \xe2\x80\x9cfiddler;\xe2\x80\x9d then \xe2\x80\x9cgig,\xe2\x80\x9d and\r\nlastly \xe2\x80\x9cquartereen.\xe2\x80\x9d A halfpenny is a \xe2\x80\x9cbrown\xe2\x80\x9d or a \xe2\x80\x9cmadzer (pronounced\r\n\xe2\x80\x98medzer\xe2\x80\x99) saltee\xe2\x80\x9d (Cant), or a \xe2\x80\x9cmag,\xe2\x80\x9d or a \xe2\x80\x9cposh,\xe2\x80\x9d or a \xe2\x80\x9crap,\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94whence\r\nthe popular phrase, \xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t care a rap.\xe2\x80\x9d The useful and universal penny\r\nhas for Slang equivalents a \xe2\x80\x9ccopper,\xe2\x80\x9d a \xe2\x80\x9csaltee\xe2\x80\x9d (Cant), and a \xe2\x80\x9cwinn.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nTwopence is a \xe2\x80\x9cdeuce,\xe2\x80\x9d and threepence is either \xe2\x80\x9cthrums\xe2\x80\x9d or \xe2\x80\x9cthrups.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThrums\xe2\x80\x9d has a special peculiarity; for while \xe2\x80\x9cthrums-buskin\xe2\x80\x9d represents\r\nthreepence-halfpenny, the term \xe2\x80\x9cbuskin\xe2\x80\x9d is not used in connexion with\r\nany other number of pence.
