Fourpence, or a groat, may in vulgar speech\r\nbe termed a \xe2\x80\x9cbit,\xe2\x80\x9d a \xe2\x80\x9cflag,\xe2\x80\x9d or a \xe2\x80\x9cjoey.\xe2\x80\x9d Sixpence is well represented\r\nin street talk, and some of the slangisms are very comical\xe2\x80\x94for\r\ninstance, \xe2\x80\x9cbandy,\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9cbender,\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9ccripple,\xe2\x80\x9d and \xe2\x80\x9cdowner;\xe2\x80\x9d then we have\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cbuck,\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9cfye-b\xe2\x80\x99ck,\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9chalf a hog,\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9ckick\xe2\x80\x9d (thus \xe2\x80\x9ctwo and a \xe2\x80\x98kick,\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d or\r\n2_s._ 6_d._), \xe2\x80\x9clord of the manor,\xe2\x80\x9d[56] \xe2\x80\x9cpig,\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9cpot\xe2\x80\x9d (the price of a pot\r\nof ale\xe2\x80\x94thus half-a-crown is a \xe2\x80\x9cfive \xe2\x80\x98pot\xe2\x80\x99 piece\xe2\x80\x9d), \xe2\x80\x9csnid,\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9csprat,\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\xe2\x80\x9csow\xe2\x80\x99s baby,\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9ctanner,\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9ctester,\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9ctizzy,\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94seventeen vulgar words to\r\none coin. Sevenpence being an uncommon amount has only one Slang\r\nsynonym, \xe2\x80\x9csetter.\xe2\x80\x9d The same remark applies to eightpence and ninepence,\r\nthe former being only represented by \xe2\x80\x9cotter,\xe2\x80\x9d and the latter by the\r\nCant phrase \xe2\x80\x9cnobba-saltee.\xe2\x80\x9d Tenpence is \xe2\x80\x9cdacha-saltee,\xe2\x80\x9d and elevenpence\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cdacha-one,\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94both Cant expressions. It is noticeable that coined\r\npieces, and sums which from their smallness or otherwise are mostly in\r\nuse, receive a commensurate amount of attention from promoters of Slang.\r\nOne shilling boasts eleven Slang equivalents; thus we have \xe2\x80\x9cbeong,\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cbob,\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9cbreaky-leg,\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9cdeener,\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9cgen\xe2\x80\x9d (from the back Slang), \xe2\x80\x9chog,\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\xe2\x80\x9clevy,\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9cpeg,\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9cstag,\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9cteviss,\xe2\x80\x9d and \xe2\x80\x9ctwelver.\xe2\x80\x9d One shilling and\r\nsixpence is a \xe2\x80\x9ckye,\xe2\x80\x9d now and then an \xe2\x80\x9ceighteener.\xe2\x80\x9d It is noticeable that\r\nso far the florin has escaped, and only receives the shilling titles\r\nwith the required numeral adjective prefixed. Half-a-crown is known as\r\nan \xe2\x80\x9calderman,\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9chalf a bull,\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9chalf a wheel,\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9chalf a tusheroon,\xe2\x80\x9d and a\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cmadza (medzer) caroon;\xe2\x80\x9d whilst a crown piece, or five shillings, may be\r\ncalled either a \xe2\x80\x9cbull,\xe2\x80\x9d a \xe2\x80\x9ccaroon,\xe2\x80\x9d a \xe2\x80\x9ccartwheel,\xe2\x80\x9d or a \xe2\x80\x9ccoachwheel,\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nor, more generally than either, a \xe2\x80\x9cwheel\xe2\x80\x9d or a \xe2\x80\x9ctusheroon.\xe2\x80\x9d The word\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cdollar\xe2\x80\x9d is in general use among costermongers and their customers, and\r\nsignifies exactly five shillings. Any term representing this amount\r\n\xe2\x80\x9ctakes in two,\xe2\x80\x9d and represents the half-crown by the addition of the\r\nusual prefix. The next advance in Slang money is ten shillings, or\r\nhalf-a-sovereign, which may be either pronounced as \xe2\x80\x9chalf a bean,\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9chalf\r\na couter,\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9ca madza poona,\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9chalf a quid,\xe2\x80\x9d or \xe2\x80\x9chalf a thick \xe2\x80\x99un.\xe2\x80\x9d A\r\nsovereign, or twenty shillings, is a \xe2\x80\x9cbean,\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9ccanary,\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9ccouter,\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cfoont,\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9cgoldfinch,\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9cJames\xe2\x80\x9d (from Jacobus), \xe2\x80\x9cpoona,\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9cportrait,\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cquid,\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9cthick-un,\xe2\x80\x9d or \xe2\x80\x9cyellow-boy.\xe2\x80\x9d Guineas are nearly obsolete, yet\r\nthe terms \xe2\x80\x9cneds\xe2\x80\x9d and \xe2\x80\x9chalf neds\xe2\x80\x9d are still in use. Bank-notes are\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cflimsies,\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9clong-tailed ones,\xe2\x80\x9d or \xe2\x80\x9csoft.\xe2\x80\x9d A \xe2\x80\x9cfin,\xe2\x80\x9d or a \xe2\x80\x9cfinnuf,\xe2\x80\x9d is a\r\nfive-pound note. Twenty-five pounds is a \xe2\x80\x9cpony,\xe2\x80\x9d and a hundred a\r\n\xe2\x80\x9ccentury.\xe2\x80\x9d One hundred pounds (or any other \xe2\x80\x9cround sum\xe2\x80\x9d), quietly handed\r\nover as payment for services performed, is curiously termed \xe2\x80\x9ca \xe2\x80\x98cool\xe2\x80\x99\r\nhundred.\xe2\x80\x9d Thus ends, with several necessary omissions, this long list of\r\nSlang terms for the coins of the realm which, for copiousness, it is not\r\ntoo much to say, is not equalled by any other vulgar or unauthorized\r\nlanguage in Europe.\r\n\r\nThe antiquity of many of these Slang names is remarkable. \xe2\x80\x9cWinn\xe2\x80\x9d was the\r\nvulgar term for a penny in the days of Queen Elizabeth; and \xe2\x80\x9ctester,\xe2\x80\x9d a\r\nsixpence (formerly a shilling), was the correct name in the days of\r\nHenry VIII. The reader, too, will have remarked the frequency of\r\nanimals\xe2\x80\x99 names as Slang terms for money. Little, as a modern writer has\r\nremarked, do the persons using these phrases know of their remote and\r\nsomewhat classical origin, which may, indeed, be traced to a period\r\nanterior to that when monarchs monopolized the surface of coined money\r\nwith their own images and superscriptions. They are identical with the\r\nvery name of money among the early Romans, which was _pecunia_, from\r\n_pecus_, a flock. The collections of coin-dealers amply show that the\r\nfigure of a \xe2\x80\x9chog\xe2\x80\x9d was anciently placed on a small silver coin; and that\r\nthat of a \xe2\x80\x9cbull\xe2\x80\x9d decorated larger ones of the same metal. These coins\r\nwere frequently deeply crossed on the reverse; this was for the\r\nconvenience of easily breaking them into two or more pieces, should the\r\nbargain for which they were employed require it, and the parties making\r\nit had no smaller change handy to complete the transaction. Thus we find\r\nthat the \xe2\x80\x9chalf bull\xe2\x80\x9d of the itinerant street-seller, or \xe2\x80\x9ctraveller,\xe2\x80\x9d so\r\nfar from being a phrase of modern invention, as is generally supposed,\r\nis in point of fact referable to an era extremely remote. This remark\r\nwill safely apply to most descriptions of money; and it must not be\r\nforgotten that farthing is but a corruption of fourthing, or, literally,\r\nfourth part of a penny. The representative coin of the realm was often\r\nin olden times made to break up,\xe2\x80\x94but this by the way. It is a reminder,\r\nhowever, that the word \xe2\x80\x9csmash,\xe2\x80\x9d as used by the classes that speak Slang\r\nfrom motives other than those of affectation, has nothing whatever to do\r\nwith base coin, as is generally supposed. It simply means to give\r\nchange. Thus:\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cCan you smash a thick \xe2\x80\x99un for me?\xe2\x80\x9d means simply, \xe2\x80\x9cCan\r\nyou give me change for a sovereign?\xe2\x80\x9d We learn from Erizzo, in his\r\n_Discorso_, a further illustration of the proverb \xe2\x80\x9cthat there is nothing\r\nnew under the sun;\xe2\x80\x9d for he says that the Roman boys at the time of\r\nHadrian tossed up their coppers and cried, \xe2\x80\x9cHead or ship;\xe2\x80\x9d of which\r\ntradition our \xe2\x80\x9cheads or tails,\xe2\x80\x9d and \xe2\x80\x9cman or woman,\xe2\x80\x9d or \xe2\x80\x9ca tanner I heads\r\n\xe2\x80\x99em,\xe2\x80\x9d is certainly a less refined version. We thence gather, however,\r\nthat the prow of a vessel would appear to have been the more ordinary\r\ndevice of the reverse of the brass coin of that ancient period. There\r\nare many other Cant words directly from a classic source, as will be\r\nseen in the dictionary.\r\n\r\nShopkeepers\xe2\x80\x99 Slang is perhaps the most offensive of all Slang, though\r\nthis is not intended to imply that shopkeepers are perhaps the most\r\noffensive of people. This kind of Slang is not a casual eyesore, as\r\nnewspaper Slang, neither is it an occasional discomfort to the ear, as\r\nin the case of some vulgar byword of the street; but it is a perpetual\r\nnuisance, and stares you in the face on tradesmen\xe2\x80\x99s invoices, on labels\r\nin the shop-windows, and placards on the hoardings, in posters against\r\nthe house next to your own\xe2\x80\x94if it happen to be empty for a few\r\nweeks\xe2\x80\x94and in bills thrust into your hand, as you peaceably walk through\r\nthe streets. Under your door, and down your area, Slang handbills are\r\ndropped by some \xe2\x80\x9cpushing\xe2\x80\x9d tradesman; and for the thousandth time you are\r\ncalled upon to learn that an \xe2\x80\x9calarming sacrifice\xe2\x80\x9d is taking place in the\r\nnext street; that prices are \xe2\x80\x9cdown again;\xe2\x80\x9d that, in consequence of some\r\nother tradesman not \xe2\x80\x9cdriving a roaring trade,\xe2\x80\x9d being in fact, \xe2\x80\x9csold up,\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nand for the time being a resident in \xe2\x80\x9cBurdon\xe2\x80\x99s Hotel\xe2\x80\x9d (Whitecross-Street\r\nPrison), the \xe2\x80\x9cpushing\xe2\x80\x9d tradesman wishes to sell out at \xe2\x80\x9cawfully low\r\nprices,\xe2\x80\x9d to \xe2\x80\x9cthe kind patrons, and numerous customers,\xe2\x80\x9d &c. &c., \xe2\x80\x9cthat\r\nhave on every occasion,\xe2\x80\x9d &c. &c. These are, though, very venial\r\noffenders compared with those ghouls, the advertising undertakers, who\r\nemploy boys, loaded with ghastly little books, to follow up the parish\r\ndoctor, and leave their horrible wares wherever he calls. But what can\r\nbe expected of ignorant undertakers when a London newspaper of large\r\ncirculation actually takes out the death records from the _Times_, and\r\nsends a circular to each address therein, informing the bereaved persons\r\nthat the \xe2\x80\x9c----\xe2\x80\x9d charges so much per line for similar notices, and that\r\nits circulation is most extensive? Surely the typical \xe2\x80\x9cdeath-hunter,\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nhardened though he may be, is hardly down to that level. In shopkeeping\r\nSlang any occupation or calling is termed a \xe2\x80\x9cline,\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94thus, the \xe2\x80\x9cbuilding\r\nline.\xe2\x80\x9d A tailor usurps to himself a good deal of Slang. Amongst\r\noperatives he is called a \xe2\x80\x9csnip,\xe2\x80\x9d a \xe2\x80\x9csteel-bar driver,\xe2\x80\x9d a \xe2\x80\x9ccabbage\r\ncontractor,\xe2\x80\x9d or a \xe2\x80\x9cgoose persuader;\xe2\x80\x9d by the world, a \xe2\x80\x9cninth part of a\r\nman;\xe2\x80\x9d and by the young collegian, or \xe2\x80\x9cfast\xe2\x80\x9d man, a \xe2\x80\x9csufferer.\xe2\x80\x9d If he\r\ntakes army contracts, it is \xe2\x80\x9csank work;\xe2\x80\x9d if he is a \xe2\x80\x9cslop\xe2\x80\x9d tailor, he is\r\na \xe2\x80\x9cspringer up,\xe2\x80\x9d and his garments are \xe2\x80\x9cblown together.\xe2\x80\x9d Perquisites with\r\nhim are \xe2\x80\x9cspiffs,\xe2\x80\x9d and remnants of cloth \xe2\x80\x9cpeaking, or cabbage.\xe2\x80\x9d The\r\nper-centage he allows to his assistants (or \xe2\x80\x9ccounter jumpers\xe2\x80\x9d) on the\r\nsale of old-fashioned articles is termed \xe2\x80\x9ctinge.\xe2\x80\x9d If he pays his workmen\r\nin goods, or gives them tickets upon other tradesmen, with whom he\r\nshares the profit, he is soon known as a \xe2\x80\x9ctommy master.\xe2\x80\x9d If his business\r\nsucceeds, it \xe2\x80\x9ctakes;\xe2\x80\x9d if neglected, it becomes \xe2\x80\x9cshaky,\xe2\x80\x9d and \xe2\x80\x9cgoes to\r\npot;\xe2\x80\x9d if he is deceived by a debtor (a by no means unusual\r\ncircumstance), he is \xe2\x80\x9clet in,\xe2\x80\x9d or, as it is sometimes varied, \xe2\x80\x9ctaken\r\nin.\xe2\x80\x9d It need scarcely be remarked that any credit he may give is termed\r\n\xe2\x80\x9ctick.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nOperatives\xe2\x80\x99 or workmen\xe2\x80\x99s Slang, in quality, is but slightly removed from\r\ntradesmen\xe2\x80\x99s Slang. When belonging to the same shop or factory, they\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cgraft\xe2\x80\x9d there, and are \xe2\x80\x9cbrother chips.\xe2\x80\x9d Among printers the favourite\r\nterm is \xe2\x80\x9ccomps,\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94not compositors, though the same contraction is used\r\nfor that word,\xe2\x80\x94but companions, whether so in actual fact, or as members\r\nof the same \xe2\x80\x9ccompanionship.\xe2\x80\x9d A companionship is the number of men\r\nengaged on any one work, and this is in turn reduced to \xe2\x80\x9cship:\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nsometimes it is a \xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x99stab ship,\xe2\x80\x9d _i.e._, paid by the week, therefore on\r\nthe establishment; sometimes it is \xe2\x80\x9con the piece,\xe2\x80\x9d and anyhow it is an\r\nextremely critical organization, so perhaps it would be better to\r\nbroaden the subject. Workmen generally dine at \xe2\x80\x9cslap-bang shops,\xe2\x80\x9d and\r\nare often paid at \xe2\x80\x9ctommy shops.\xe2\x80\x9d At the nearest \xe2\x80\x9cpub,\xe2\x80\x9d or public-house,\r\nthey generally have a \xe2\x80\x9cscore chalked up\xe2\x80\x9d against them, which has to be\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cwiped off\xe2\x80\x9d regularly on the Saturday night. This is often known as a\r\n\xe2\x80\x9clight.\xe2\x80\x9d When credit is bad the \xe2\x80\x9clight\xe2\x80\x9d is said to be out. When out of\r\nwork, they describe themselves as being \xe2\x80\x9cout of collar.\xe2\x80\x9d They term each\r\nother \xe2\x80\x9cflints\xe2\x80\x9d and \xe2\x80\x9cdungs,\xe2\x80\x9d if they are \xe2\x80\x9csociety\xe2\x80\x9d or \xe2\x80\x9cnon-society\xe2\x80\x9d men.\r\nTheir salary is a \xe2\x80\x9cscrew,\xe2\x80\x9d and to be discharged is to \xe2\x80\x9cget the sack,\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nvaried by the expression \xe2\x80\x9cget the bullet,\xe2\x80\x9d the connexion of which with\r\ndischarge is obvious, as the small lecturers\xe2\x80\x94those at the Polytechnic\r\nfor instance\xe2\x80\x94say, to the meanest capacity. When they quit work, they\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cknock off;\xe2\x80\x9d and when out of employ, they ask if any \xe2\x80\x9chands\xe2\x80\x9d are, or any\r\nassistance is, wanted. \xe2\x80\x9cFat\xe2\x80\x9d is the vulgar synonym for perquisites;\r\n\xe2\x80\x9celbow grease\xe2\x80\x9d signifies labour; and \xe2\x80\x9cSaint Monday\xe2\x80\x9d is the favourite day\r\nof the week. Names of animals figure plentifully in the workman\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nvocabulary; thus we have \xe2\x80\x9cgoose,\xe2\x80\x9d a tailor\xe2\x80\x99s smoothing-iron;\r\n\xe2\x80\x9csheep\xe2\x80\x99s-foot,\xe2\x80\x9d an iron hammer; \xe2\x80\x9csow,\xe2\x80\x9d a receptacle for molten iron,\r\nwhilst the metal poured from it is termed \xe2\x80\x9cpig.\xe2\x80\x9d Many of the Slang terms\r\nfor money may have originally come from the workshop, thus\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cbrads,\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nfrom the ironmonger; \xe2\x80\x9cchips,\xe2\x80\x9d from the carpenter; \xe2\x80\x9cdust,\xe2\x80\x9d from the\r\ngoldsmith; \xe2\x80\x9cfeathers,\xe2\x80\x9d from the upholsterer; \xe2\x80\x9chorse-nails,\xe2\x80\x9d from the\r\nfarrier; \xe2\x80\x9chaddock,\xe2\x80\x9d from the fishmonger; and \xe2\x80\x9ctanner and skin\xe2\x80\x9d from the\r\nleather-dresser.\r\n\r\nIf society, as has been remarked, is a sham, from the vulgar foundation\r\nof commonalty to the crowning summit of royalty, then do we perceive the\r\njustness of the remark in that most peculiar of peculiarities, the Slang\r\nof makeshifts for oaths, and sham exclamations for passion and temper.\r\nThese apologies for feeling are an addition to our vernacular, and\r\nthough some argue that they are a disgrace, for the reason that no man\r\nshould pretend to swear or curse who does not do so, it is some\r\nsatisfaction to know that they serve the purpose of reducing the stock\r\nof national profanity. \xe2\x80\x9cYou be blowed,\xe2\x80\x9d or \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ll be blowed if,\xe2\x80\x9d &c., is\r\nan exclamation often heard in the streets. \xe2\x80\x9cBlazes,\xe2\x80\x9d or \xe2\x80\x9clike blazes,\xe2\x80\x9d\r\ncame probably from the army, unless, indeed, it came from the original\r\nmetaphor, afterwards corrupted, to serve all turns, \xe2\x80\x9cto smoke like\r\nblazes.\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9cBlast,\xe2\x80\x9d too, although in general vulgar use, may have had an\r\nengineering or military origin, and the phrase, \xe2\x80\x9cI wish I may be shot,\r\nif,\xe2\x80\x9d smacks much of powder. \xe2\x80\x9cBlow me tight\xe2\x80\x9d is a very windy and common\r\nexclamation. The same may be said of \xe2\x80\x9cstrike me lucky,\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9cnever trust\r\nme,\xe2\x80\x9d and \xe2\x80\x9cso help me Davy;\xe2\x80\x9d the latter being evidently derived from the\r\ntruer old phrase, \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ll take my Davy on\xe2\x80\x99t\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94_i.e._, my affidavit,\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDavy,\xe2\x80\x9d and sometimes \xe2\x80\x9cAlfred Davy,\xe2\x80\x9d being a corruption of that word.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBy Golly,\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9cGol darn it,\xe2\x80\x9d and \xe2\x80\x9cso help\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94generally pronounced \xe2\x80\x9cselp\xe2\x80\x9d or\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cswelp\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cme Bob,\xe2\x80\x9d are evident shams for profane oaths. \xe2\x80\x9cTarnation\xe2\x80\x9d is\r\nbut a softening of damnation; and \xe2\x80\x9cod,\xe2\x80\x9d whether used in \xe2\x80\x9cod drat it,\xe2\x80\x9d or\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cod\xe2\x80\x99s blood,\xe2\x80\x9d is but an apology for the name of the Deity. \xe2\x80\x9cMarry,\xe2\x80\x9d a\r\nterm of asseveration in common use, was originally, in Popish times, a\r\nmode of swearing by the Virgin Mary;\xe2\x80\x94so also \xe2\x80\x9cmarrow-bones,\xe2\x80\x9d for the\r\nknees. \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ll bring him down upon his marrow-bones,\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94_i.e._, I\xe2\x80\x99ll make\r\nhim bend his knees as he does to the Virgin Mary. The Irish phrase, \xe2\x80\x9cBad\r\nscran to yer!\xe2\x80\x9d is equivalent to wishing a person bad food. \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m\r\nsniggered if you will,\xe2\x80\x9d and \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m jiggered,\xe2\x80\x9d are other mild forms of\r\nswearing among men fearful of committing an open profanity, yet slily\r\nnibbling at the sin. Maybe, some day one of these adventurers will meet\r\nwith the object of his desires, and then when fairly \xe2\x80\x9cjiggered,\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nwhatever it may ultimately turn out to be, it is to be hoped he will\r\nprove a fearful example to all persons with the will, but not the pluck,\r\nto swear fierce oaths. Both \xe2\x80\x9cdeuce\xe2\x80\x9d and \xe2\x80\x9cdickens\xe2\x80\x9d are vulgar old\r\nsynonyms for the devil; and \xe2\x80\x9czounds\xe2\x80\x9d is an abbreviation of \xe2\x80\x9cGod\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nwounds,\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94a very ancient oath.\r\n\r\nIn a casual survey of the territory of Slang, it is curious to observe\r\nhow well represented are the familiar wants and failings of life. First,\r\nthere is money, with one hundred and odd Slang terms and synonyms; then\r\ncomes drink, from small beer to champagne; and next as a very natural\r\nsequence, intoxication, and fuddlement generally, with some half a\r\nhundred vulgar terms, graduating the scale of drunkenness, from a slight\r\ninebriation to the soaky state which leads to the gutter, sometimes to\r\nthe stretcher, the station-house, the fine, and, most terrible of all,\r\nthe \xe2\x80\x9ccaution.\xe2\x80\x9d The Slang synonyms for mild intoxication are certainly\r\nvery choice,\xe2\x80\x94they are \xe2\x80\x9cbeery,\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9cbemused,\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9cboozy,\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9cbosky,\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9cbuffy,\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\xe2\x80\x9ccorned,\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9cfoggy,\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9cfou,\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9cfresh,\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9chazy,\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9celevated,\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9ckisky,\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9clushy,\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cmoony,\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9cmuggy,\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9cmuzzy,\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9con,\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9cscrewed,\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9cstewed,\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9ctight,\xe2\x80\x9d and\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cwiney.\xe2\x80\x9d A higher or more intense state of beastliness is represented by\r\nthe expressions, \xe2\x80\x9cpodgy,\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9cbeargered,\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9cblued,\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9ccut,\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9cprimed,\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\xe2\x80\x9clumpy,\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9cploughed,\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9cmuddled,\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9cobfuscated,\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9cswipey,\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9cthree sheets in\r\nthe wind,\xe2\x80\x9d and \xe2\x80\x9ctop-heavy.\xe2\x80\x9d But the climax of fuddlement is only\r\nobtained when the \xe2\x80\x9cdisguised\xe2\x80\x9d individual \xe2\x80\x9ccan\xe2\x80\x99t see a hole in a ladder,\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nor when he is all \xe2\x80\x9cmops and brooms,\xe2\x80\x9d or \xe2\x80\x9coff his nut,\xe2\x80\x9d or with his\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cmain-brace well spliced,\xe2\x80\x9d or with the \xe2\x80\x9csun in his eyes,\xe2\x80\x9d or when he\r\nhas \xe2\x80\x9clapped the gutter,\xe2\x80\x9d and got the \xe2\x80\x9cgravel rash,\xe2\x80\x9d or is on the\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cran-tan,\xe2\x80\x9d or on the \xe2\x80\x9cree-raw,\xe2\x80\x9d or when \xe2\x80\x9csewed up,\xe2\x80\x9d and regularly\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cscammered,\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94then, and not till then, is he entitled, in vulgar\r\nsociety, to the title of \xe2\x80\x9clushington,\xe2\x80\x9d or recommended to \xe2\x80\x9cput in the\r\npin,\xe2\x80\x9d _i.e._, the linch-pin, to keep his legs steady.\r\n\r\n\r\nFOOTNOTES:\r\n\r\n[32] An outgrowth of this latter peculiarity consisted in anyone with a\r\nhigh or prominent nose being, a few years back, called by the street\r\nboys \xe2\x80\x9cDuke.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n[33] This term, with a singular literal downrightness, which would be\r\nremarkable in any other people than the French, is translated by them as\r\nthe sect of _Trembleurs_.\r\n\r\n[34] Swift alludes to this term in his _Art of Polite Conversation_, p.\r\n14, 1738.\r\n\r\n[35] See _Notes and Queries_, vol. i. p. 185. 1850.\r\n\r\n[36] He afterwards kept a tavern at Wapping, mentioned by Pope in the\r\n_Dunciad_.\r\n\r\n[37] _Sportsman\xe2\x80\x99s Dictionary_, 1825, p. 15.\r\n\r\n[38] This introduction was written in 1859, before the new edition of\r\n_Worcester_, and Nuttall\xe2\x80\x99s recent work, were published.\r\n\r\n[39] Introduction to Bee\xe2\x80\x99s _Sportsman\xe2\x80\x99s Dictionary_, 1825.\r\n\r\n[40] The Gipsies use the word Slang as the Anglican synonym for Romany,\r\nthe Continental (or rather Spanish) term for the Cingari or Gipsy\r\ntongue. Crabb, who wrote the _Gipsies\xe2\x80\x99 Advocate_ in 1831, thus mentions\r\nthe word:\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cThis language [Gipsy] _called by themselves_ Slang, or\r\nGibberish, invented, as they think, by their forefathers for secret\r\npurposes, is not merely the language of one or a few of these wandering\r\ntribes, which are found in the European nations, but is adopted by the\r\nvast numbers who inhabit the earth.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n[41] The word Slang assumed various meanings amongst costermongers,\r\nbeggars, and vagabonds of all orders. It was, and is still, used to\r\nexpress \xe2\x80\x9ccheating by false weights,\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9ca raree show,\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9cretiring by a back\r\ndoor,\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9ca watch-chain,\xe2\x80\x9d their \xe2\x80\x9csecret language,\xe2\x80\x9d &c.\r\n\r\n[42] North, in his _Examen_, p. 574, says, \xe2\x80\x9cI may note that the rabble\r\nfirst changed their title, and were called the \xe2\x80\x9cmob\xe2\x80\x9d in the assemblies\r\nof this [Green Ribbon] club. It was their beasts of burden, and called\r\nfirst _mobile vulgus_, but fell naturally into the contraction of one\r\nsyllable, and ever since is become proper English.\xe2\x80\x9d In the same work, p.\r\n231, the disgraceful origin of SHAM is given.\r\n\r\n[43] I am afraid my predecessor was of a somewhat satirical turn of\r\nmind, or else he had peculiar notions of melody.\xe2\x80\x94ED.\r\n\r\n[44] This latter is, as I take it, an error, as the sign was originally\r\nintended to represent the king\xe2\x80\x99s head and cross guns, and may still be\r\nseen in parts of the country.\xe2\x80\x94ED.\r\n\r\n[45] Savez-vous cela?\xe2\x80\x94[I fancy this is from the Spanish _sabe_. The\r\nword is in great use in the Pacific States of America, and is obtained\r\nthrough constant intercourse with the original settlers.\xe2\x80\x94ED.]\r\n\r\n[46] At page 24 of a curious old Civil War tract, entitled, _The Oxonian\r\nAntippodes_, by I. B., Gent., 1644, the town is called Brummidgham, and\r\nthis was the general rendering in the printed literature of the\r\nseventeenth century.\xe2\x80\x94[This must have been the first known step towards\r\nthe present vulgar style of spelling, for properly the word is\r\nBromwich-ham, which has been corrupted into Brummagem, a term used to\r\nexpress worthless or inferior goods, from the spurious jewellery, plate,\r\n&c., manufactured there expressly for \xe2\x80\x9cduffers.\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94ED.]\r\n\r\n[47] This was more especially an amusement with medical students,\r\nafter the modern Mohocks had discarded it. The students are now a\r\ncomparatively mild and quiet race, with very little of the style of a\r\ngeneration ago about them.\r\n\r\n[48] _Edinburgh Review_, October, 1853.\r\n\r\n[49] A term derived from the _Record_ newspaper, the exponent of this\r\nsingular section of the Low, or so-called Evangelical Church.\r\n\r\n[50] A preacher is said, in this phraseology, to be \xe2\x80\x9cowned\xe2\x80\x9d when he\r\nmakes many converts, and his converts are called his \xe2\x80\x9cseals.\xe2\x80\x9d This is\r\nCant in its most objectionable form.\r\n\r\n[51] \xe2\x80\x9cSwaddler\xe2\x80\x9d is also a phrase by which the low Irish Roman Catholics\r\ndenominate those of their body who in winter become Protestants, _pro\r\ntem._, for the sake of the blankets, coals, &c., given by proselytizing\r\nProtestants. It is hard to say which are the worse, those who refuse to\r\ngive unless the objects of their charity become converted, or those who\r\nsham conversion to save themselves from starving, or the tender mercies\r\nof the relieving officer. I am much afraid my sympathies are with the\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cswaddlers,\xe2\x80\x9d who are also called \xe2\x80\x9csoupers.\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94ED.\r\n\r\n[52] \xe2\x80\x9cAll our newspapers contain more or less colloquial words; in fact,\r\nthere seems no other way of expressing certain ideas connected with\r\npassing events of every-day life with the requisite force and piquancy.\r\nIn the English newspapers the same thing is observable, and certain of\r\nthem contain more of the class denominated Slang words than our\r\nown.\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94_Bartlett\xe2\x80\x99s Americanisms_, p. 10, edit. 1859.\r\n\r\n[53] When this appeared, \xe2\x80\x9call serene\xe2\x80\x9d was one of those street phrases\r\nwhich periodically spring up, have their rage, and depart as suddenly as\r\nthey come into popularity. These sayings are generally of a most idiotic\r\nnature, as their latest specimens, \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ll warm yer,\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9cAll serene,\xe2\x80\x9d and\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ll \xe2\x80\x99ave your hi\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94used without any premonitory notice or regard to\r\ncontext, and screeched out at the top of the voice\xe2\x80\x94will testify. I\r\nsuppose we shall soon have another of these \xe2\x80\x9cebullitions of popular\r\nfeeling.\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94ED.\r\n\r\n[54] The terms \xe2\x80\x9cleader\xe2\x80\x9d and \xe2\x80\x9carticle\xe2\x80\x9d can scarcely be called Slang, yet\r\nit would be desirable to know upon what authority they were first\r\nemployed in their present peculiar sense.\r\n\r\n[55] The _Morning Herald_ was called \xe2\x80\x9cMrs. Harris,\xe2\x80\x9d because it was said\r\nthat no one ever saw it, a peculiarity which, in common with its general\r\ndisregard for veracity, made it uncommonly like \xe2\x80\x9cMrs. Gamp\xe2\x80\x99s\xe2\x80\x9d invisible\r\nfriend as portrayed by Dickens. But the _Herald_ has long since departed\r\nthis life, and with it has gone the title of \xe2\x80\x9cMrs. Gamp,\xe2\x80\x9d as applied to\r\nthe _Standard_, which is, though, as impulsive and Conservative as\r\never.\xe2\x80\x94ED.\r\n\r\n[56] This is rhyming slang, and is corrupted into \xe2\x80\x9clord\xe2\x80\x9d only.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTouch-me,\xe2\x80\x9d a common term for a shilling, is also derived from the same\r\nsource, it being short for \xe2\x80\x9ctouch-me-on-the-nob,\xe2\x80\x9d which is rhyming slang\r\nfor \xe2\x80\x9cbob\xe2\x80\x9d or shilling.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nTHE\r\n\r\nSLANG DICTIONARY.\r\n\r\n\r\n~A\xc2\xa01~, first-rate, the very best; \xe2\x80\x9cshe\xe2\x80\x99s a prime girl, she is; she is\r\nA\xc2\xa01.\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94_Sam Slick_. The highest classification of ships at Lloyd\xe2\x80\x99s; common\r\nterm in the United States; also at Liverpool and other English seaports.\r\nAnother, even more intensitive form is \xe2\x80\x9cfirst-class, letter A, No. 1.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nSome people choose to say A\xc2\xa0I, for no reason, however, beyond that of\r\nbeing different from others.\r\n\r\n~Abigail~, a lady\xe2\x80\x99s-maid; perhaps obtained from old comedies. Used in an\r\nuncomplimentary sense. Some think the term is derived from Abigail Hill\r\n(Mrs. Masham), lady-in-waiting to Queen Anne, and a typical ABIGAIL in\r\nthe way of intrigue.\r\n\r\n~About Right~, \xe2\x80\x9cto do the thing ABOUT RIGHT,\xe2\x80\x9d _i.e._, to do it\r\nproperly, soundly, correctly; \xe2\x80\x9che guv it \xe2\x80\x99im ABOUT RIGHT,\xe2\x80\x9d _i.e._, he\r\nbeat him severely.\r\n\r\n~Abraham-man~, a vagabond, such as were driven to beg about the country\r\nafter the dissolution of the monasteries.\xe2\x80\x94_See_ BESS O\xe2\x80\x99 BEDLAM,\r\n_infra_. They are well described under the title of _Bedlam\r\nBeggars_.\xe2\x80\x94_Shakspeare\xe2\x80\x99s K. Lear_, ii. 3.\r\n\r\n    \xe2\x80\x9cAnd these, what name or title e\xe2\x80\x99er they bear,\r\n    Jarkman, or Patrico, Cranke, or Clapper-dudgeon,\r\n    Frater, or ABRAM-MAN; I speak to all\r\n    That stand in fair election for the title\r\n    Of king of beggars.\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94_Beaumont and Fletcher\xe2\x80\x99s Begg. Bush._ II. 1.\r\n\r\nIt appears to have been the practice in former days to allow certain\r\ninmates of Bethlehem Hospital to have fixed days \xe2\x80\x9cto go begging:\xe2\x80\x9d hence\r\nimpostors were said to \xe2\x80\x9cSHAM ABRAHAM\xe2\x80\x9d (the Abraham Ward in Bedlam having\r\nfor its inmates these mendicant lunatics) when they pretended they were\r\nlicensed beggars in behalf of the hospital.\r\n\r\n~Abraham-sham~, or SHAM ABRAHAM, to feign sickness or distress. From\r\nABRAHAM-MAN, the _ancient Cant_ term for a begging impostor, or one who\r\npretended to have been mad.\xe2\x80\x94_Burton\xe2\x80\x99s Anatomy of Melancholy_, vol. i.\r\np. 360. When Abraham Newland was Cashier to the Bank of England, and\r\nsigned their notes, it was sung:\xe2\x80\x94\r\n\r\n        \xe2\x80\x9cI have heard people say\r\n        That SHAM ABRAHAM you may,\r\n    But you mustn\xe2\x80\x99t SHAM ABRAHAM Newland.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n~Absquatulate~, to run away, or abscond; a hybrid _American_ expression,\r\nfrom the Latin _ab_, and \xe2\x80\x9csquat\xe2\x80\x9d to settle.\r\n\r\n~Acres~, a coward. From Bob Acres, in Sheridan\xe2\x80\x99s _Rivals_.\r\n\r\n~Adam\xe2\x80\x99s Ale~, water.\xe2\x80\x94_English._ The _Scotch_ term is ADAM\xe2\x80\x99S WINE.\r\n\r\n~Added to the List~, a euphuism current among sporting writers implying\r\nthat a horse has been gelded. As, \xe2\x80\x9cSabinus has been ADDED TO THE LIST.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nAnother form of expression in reference to this matter is that \xe2\x80\x9cthe\r\nknife has been brought into requisition.\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9cADDED TO THE LIST\xe2\x80\x9d is simply\r\na contraction for \xe2\x80\x9cadded to the list of geldings in training.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n~Addlepate~, a foolish fellow, a dullard.\r\n\r\n~Admiral of the Red~, a person whose very red face evinces a fondness\r\nfor strong potations.\r\n\r\n~Affygraphy.~ \xe2\x80\x9cIt fits to an AFFYGRAPHY,\xe2\x80\x9d _i.e._, to a nicety\xe2\x80\x94to a _T_.\r\n\r\n~Afternoon Farmer~, one who wastes his best opportunity, and drives off\r\nthe large end of his work to the little end of his time.\r\n\r\n~Against the Grain~, in opposition to the wish. \xe2\x80\x9cIt went AGAINST THE\r\nGRAIN to do it, but I knew I must,\xe2\x80\x9d is a common expression.\r\n\r\n~Aggerawators~ (corruption of _Aggravators_), the greasy locks of hair\r\nin vogue among costermongers and other street folk, worn twisted from\r\nthe temple back towards the ear. They are also, from a supposed\r\nresemblance in form, termed NEWGATE KNOCKERS, and sometimes NUMBER\r\nSIXES. This style of adorning the head is, however, fast dying out, and\r\nthe everyday costermonger or street thief has his hair cut like any one\r\nelse. The yearly militia drill may have had a good deal to do with this\r\nalteration.\r\n\r\n~Akeybo~, a slang phrase used in the following manner:\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cHe beats\r\nAKEYBO, and AKEYBO beat the devil.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n~Albertopolis~, a facetious appellation given by the Londoners to the\r\nKensington Gore district. Now obsolete.\r\n\r\n~Alderman~, a half-crown\xe2\x80\x94possibly from its rotundity. Also a long pipe.\r\n\r\n~Alderman~, a turkey; \xe2\x80\x9cALDERMAN IN CHAINS,\xe2\x80\x9d a turkey hung with sausages.\r\n\r\n~All of a Hugh!~ all on one side; falling with a thump; the word HUGH\r\nbeing pronounced with a grunt.\xe2\x80\x94_Suffolk._\r\n\r\n~All my Eye~, a remark of incredulity made in reference to an improbable\r\nstory; condensation of \xe2\x80\x9cALL MY EYE AND BETTY MARTIN,\xe2\x80\x9d a vulgar phrase\r\nconstructed from the commencement of a Roman Catholic prayer to St.\r\nMartin, \xe2\x80\x9cOh, mihi, beate Martine,\xe2\x80\x9d which in common with many another\r\nfell into discredit and ridicule after the Reformation.\r\n\r\n~All out~, by far;\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9che was ALL OUT the best of the lot.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n_Old_\xe2\x80\x94frequently used by Burton in his _Anatomy of Melancholy_.\r\n\r\n~All-overish~, neither sick nor well; the premonitory symptoms of\r\nillness. Also the feeling which comes over a man at a critical moment,\r\nsay just when he is about to \xe2\x80\x9cpop the question.\xe2\x80\x9d Sometimes this is\r\ncalled, \xe2\x80\x9cfeeling all over alike, and touching nowhere.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n~All-rounder~, a shirt collar going all round the neck and meeting in\r\nfront. Once fashionable, but little worn now.\r\n\r\n~All Serene~, an ejaculation of acquiescence. Some years back a popular\r\nstreet cry. With or without application to actual fact, the words ALL\r\nSERENE were bawled from morning to night without any reference to the\r\nserenity of the unfortunate hearers.\xe2\x80\x94_See_ SERENE.\r\n\r\n~Alls~, tap-droppings, refuse spirits sold at a cheap rate in\r\ngin-palaces.\r\n\r\n~All There~, in strict fashion, first-rate, \xe2\x80\x9cup to the mark;\xe2\x80\x9d a vulgar\r\nperson would speak of a handsome, well-dressed woman as being ALL THERE.\r\nAn artisan would use the same phrase to express the capabilities of a\r\nskillful fellow-workman. Sometimes ALL THE WAY THERE. Always used as a\r\nterm of encomium.\r\n\r\n~All to Pieces~, utterly, excessively; \xe2\x80\x9che beat him ALL TO PIECES,\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n_i.e._, excelled or surpassed him exceedingly. Also a term much in use\r\namong sporting men and expressing want of form, or decadence. A boat\xe2\x80\x99s\r\ncrew are said to \xe2\x80\x9cgo ALL TO PIECES\xe2\x80\x9d when they through distress lose\r\ntheir regularity. A woman is vulgarly said to \xe2\x80\x9cfall to pieces,\xe2\x80\x9d or\r\n\xe2\x80\x9ctumble to pieces,\xe2\x80\x9d when she is confined.\r\n\r\n~All to Smash~, or \xe2\x80\x9cGONE ALL TO PIECES,\xe2\x80\x9d bankrupt, ruined.\r\n\r\n~Almighty Dollar~, an _American_ expression representing the manner in\r\nwhich money is worshipped. Modernly introduced by Washington Irving in\r\n1837. The _idea_ of this phrase is, however, far older than the time of\r\n_Irving_. _Ben Jonson\xe2\x80\x99s Epistle to Elizabeth, Countess of Rutland_,\r\ncommences thus\xe2\x80\x94\r\n\r\n    \xe2\x80\x9cWhilst that for which all virtue now is sold,\r\n    And almost every vice, _almightie gold_.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nIt seems almost obvious that the term must have been applied, not to\r\ndollars certainly, but to money, long before the time of Irving.\r\n\r\n~American Tweezers~, an instrument used by an hotel-sneak which nips the\r\nwards end of a key, and enables him to open a door from the opposite\r\nside to that on which it has been locked.\r\n\r\n~Andrew Millar~, a ship of war.\xe2\x80\x94_Sea._\r\n\r\n~Ain\xe2\x80\x99t~, the vulgar abbreviation of \xe2\x80\x9cam not,\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9care not,\xe2\x80\x9d or \xe2\x80\x9cis not.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n~Anointed~, _i.e._, eminent; used to express great rascality in any one;\r\n\xe2\x80\x9can ANOINTED scoundrel,\xe2\x80\x9d king among scoundrels.\xe2\x80\x94_Irish._\r\n\r\n~Anointing~, a good beating. A case for the application of salve.\r\n\r\n~Anonyma~, a lady of the _demi-monde_, or worse; a \xe2\x80\x9cpretty\r\nhorsebreaker.\xe2\x80\x9d INCOGNITA was the term at first. Product of the\r\nsqueamishness of the age which tries to thrust away fact by the use of\r\nfine words.\r\n\r\n~Antiscriptural~, oaths, foul language. Anything unfit for ordinary\r\nsociety conversation.\r\n\r\n~Apartments to Let~, a term used in reference to one who has a somewhat\r\nempty head. As, \xe2\x80\x9cHe\xe2\x80\x99s got APARTMENTS TO LET.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n~Apostle\xe2\x80\x99s Grove~, the London district known as St. John\xe2\x80\x99s Wood. Also\r\ncalled GROVE OF THE EVANGELIST.\r\n\r\n~Apostles~, THE TWELVE, the last twelve names on the Poll, or \xe2\x80\x9cOrdinary\r\nDegree\xe2\x80\x9d List at the Cambridge Examinations, when it was arranged in\r\norder of merit, and not alphabetically, and in classes, as at present;\r\nso called from their being _post alios_, after the others.\xe2\x80\x94_See_ POLL.\r\nThe last of all was called ST. PAUL (or Saint Poll), as being the least\r\nof the apostles, and \xe2\x80\x9cnot meet to be called an apostle\xe2\x80\x9d (_see_ 1 Cor.\r\nxv. 9). As in the \xe2\x80\x9cHonour\xe2\x80\x9d list (_see_ GULF), students who had failed\r\nonly slightly in one or more subjects were occasionally allowed their\r\ndegrees, and these were termed ELEGANT EXTRACTS.\xe2\x80\x94_Camb. Univ. Slang._\r\n\r\n~Apple-pie Bed~, a trick played at schools on new comers, or on any boy\r\ndisliked by the rest. One of the sheets is removed, and the other is\r\ndoubled in the middle, so that both edges are brought to the top, and\r\nlook as if both sheets were there; but the unhappy occupant is prevented\r\ngetting more than half-way down, and he has to remake his bed as best he\r\ncan. This trick is sometimes played by children of a larger growth.\r\n\r\n~Apple-Cart~, the human structure, so far as the phrases with which it\r\nis connected are concerned. As \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ll upset your APPLE-CART,\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9cdown with\r\nhis APPLE-CART.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n~Apple-pie Order~, in exact or very nice order.\r\n\r\n~Appro~, contraction of approbation, a word much in use among jewellers.\r\nMost of the extensive show of chains, watches, and trinkets in a shop\r\nwindow is obtained \xe2\x80\x9cON APPRO,\xe2\x80\x9d _i.e._, \xe2\x80\x9con sale or return.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n~Area Sneak~, a thief who commits depredations upon kitchens and\r\ncellars.\r\n\r\n~Argol-bargol~, to bandy words.\xe2\x80\x94_Scotch._\r\n\r\n~Article~, derisive term for a weak or insignificant specimen of\r\nhumanity.\r\n\r\n~Atomy~, a diminutive or deformed person. From ANATOMY, or ATOM.\r\n\r\n~Attack~, to carve, or commence operations; \xe2\x80\x9cATTACK that beef, and\r\noblige!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n~Attic~, the head; \xe2\x80\x9cqueer in the ATTIC,\xe2\x80\x9d intoxicated or weak-minded.\r\nSometimes ATTIC is varied by \xe2\x80\x9cupper story.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n~Attic Salt~, wit, humour, pleasantry. Partly a reference to a\r\nsuggestive portion of Grecian literature, and partly a sly hit at the\r\nwell-known poverty of many writers.\r\n\r\n~Auctioneer~, to \xe2\x80\x9ctip him the AUCTIONEER,\xe2\x80\x9d is to knock a man down. Tom\r\nSayers\xe2\x80\x99s right hand was known to pugilistic fame as the AUCTIONEER.\r\n\r\n~Audit Ale~, extra strong ale supposed to be drunk when the accounts are\r\naudited.\xe2\x80\x94_Camb. Univ._\r\n\r\n~Auld-Reekie~, an affectionate term for the old town of Edinburgh.\r\nDerived from its dingy appearance.\r\n\r\n~Aunt Sally~, a favourite figure on racecourses and at fairs, consisting\r\nof a wooden head mounted on a stick, firmly fixed in the ground; in the\r\nnose of which, or rather where the nose should be, a tobacco-pipe is\r\ninserted. The fun consists in standing at a distance and demolishing\r\nAUNT SALLY\xe2\x80\x99S pipe-clay projection with short bludgeons, very similar to\r\nthe halves of broom-handles. The Duke of Beaufort is a \xe2\x80\x9ccrack hand\xe2\x80\x9d at\r\nsmashing pipe noses; and his performances some years ago on Brighton\r\nracecourse, which brought the game into notoriety, are yet fresh in\r\nremembrance. AUNT SALLY has, however, had her day, and once again the\r\ninevitable \xe2\x80\x9cthree shies a penny!\xe2\x80\x9d is chief among our outdoor amusements.\r\n\r\n~Avast~, a sailor\xe2\x80\x99s phrase for stop, shut up, go away,\xe2\x80\x94apparently\r\nconnected with the _old Cant_, BYNGE A WASTE; or from the _Italian_,\r\nBASTA, hold! enough.\r\n\r\n~Awake~, or FLY, knowing, thoroughly understanding. \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m awake,\xe2\x80\x9d _i.e._,\r\nI know all. The phrase WIDE-AWAKE carries a similar meaning in ordinary\r\nconversation, but has a more general reference.\r\n\r\n~Awful~, a senseless expletive, used to intensify a description of\r\nanything good or bad; \xe2\x80\x9cwhat an AWFUL fine woman!\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9cawfully jolly,\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cawfully sorry,\xe2\x80\x9d &c. The phrase is not confined to any section of\r\nsociety.\r\n\r\n~Ax~, to ask. Sometimes pronounced arks.\r\n\r\n~Babes~, the lowest order of KNOCK-OUTS (which _see_), who are prevailed\r\nupon not to give opposing biddings at auctions, in consideration of\r\ntheir receiving a small sum (from one shilling to half-a-crown), and a\r\ncertain quantity of beer. They can, however, even after this agreement,\r\nbe secured on the other side for a little longer price. There is no\r\nhonour among thieves\xe2\x80\x94at all events not among auction thieves\xe2\x80\x94nowadays.\r\n\r\n~Back~, to support by means of money, on the turf or otherwise.\xe2\x80\x94_See_\r\nLAY.\r\n\r\n~Back~, \xe2\x80\x9cto get one\xe2\x80\x99s BACK UP,\xe2\x80\x9d to annoy or enrage. Probably from the\r\naction of a cat when preparing to give battle to an enemy.\r\n\r\n~Back-end~, that portion of the year which commences with October. This\r\nphrase is peculiar to the turf, and has its origin in the fact that\r\nOctober was actually, and is now nearly, the finishing portion of the\r\nracing season. Towards BACK-END the punters and \xe2\x80\x9clittle men\xe2\x80\x9d generally\r\nbegin to look forward with anxiety to their winter prospects, and \xe2\x80\x9cgoing\r\nfor the gloves\xe2\x80\x9d is not only a frequent phrase, but a frequently\r\nrecurring practice.\r\n\r\n~Back Out~, to retreat from a difficulty; reverse of GO AHEAD. Metaphor\r\nborrowed from the stables.\r\n\r\n~Back Slang It~, to go out the back way. Equivalent to \xe2\x80\x9cSling your hook\r\nout of the back-door,\xe2\x80\x9d _i.e._, get away quickly.\r\n\r\n~Backslums~, the byeways and disreputable portions of a town.\r\n\r\n~Back-Hander~, a blow on the face with the back of the hand, a\r\nback-handed tip. Also a drink out of turn, as when a greedy person\r\ndelays the decanter to get a second glass. Anything done slyly or\r\nsecretly is said to be done in a back-handed manner.\r\n\r\n~Backer~, one who places his money on a particular man or animal; a\r\nsupporter of one side in a contest. The great body of betting men is\r\ndivided into BOOKMAKERS and BACKERS.\r\n\r\n~Back Jump~, a back window.\xe2\x80\x94_Prison term._\r\n\r\n~Bacon~, the body, \xe2\x80\x9cto save one\xe2\x80\x99s BACON,\xe2\x80\x9d to escape.\r\n\r\n~Bad~, \xe2\x80\x9cto go to the bad,\xe2\x80\x9d to deteriorate in character, to be ruined.\r\n_Virgil_ has an almost similar phrase, _in pejus ruere_, which means, by\r\nthe way, to go to the worse.\r\n\r\n~Bad~, hard, difficult. Word in use among sporting men who say, \xe2\x80\x9cHe will\r\nbe BAD to beat,\xe2\x80\x9d when they mean that the man or horse to whom they refer\r\nwill about win.\r\n\r\n~Bad Egg~, a scoundrel or rascal.\r\n\r\n~Badger~, to tease, to annoy by \xe2\x80\x9cchaffing.\xe2\x80\x9d Suggestive of drawing a\r\nbadger.\r\n\r\n~Bad Lot~, a term derived from auctioneering slang, and now generally\r\nused to describe a man or woman of indifferent morals.\r\n\r\n~Badminton~, blood,\xe2\x80\x94properly a peculiar kind of claret-cup invented at\r\nthe Duke of Beaufort\xe2\x80\x99s seat of that name. BADMINTON proper is made of\r\nclaret, sugar, spice, cucumber peel, and ice, and was sometimes used by\r\nthe patrons of the Prize Ring as a synonym for blood.\r\n\r\n~Bad Words~, words not always bad of themselves but unpleasant to \xe2\x80\x9cears\r\npolite,\xe2\x80\x9d from their vulgar associations.\r\n\r\n~Baffaty~, calico. Term used in the drapery trade.\r\n\r\n~Bag~, to seize or steal, equivalent to \xe2\x80\x9ccollar.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n~Bagman~, a commercial traveller. This word is used more in reference to\r\nthe old style of commercial travellers than to the present.\r\n\r\n~Bags~, trousers. Trousers of an extensive pattern, or exaggerated\r\nfashion, have sometimes been termed HOWLING-BAGS, but only when the\r\nstyle has been very \xe2\x80\x9cloud.\xe2\x80\x9d The word is probably an abbreviation of\r\nbumbags. \xe2\x80\x9cTo have the BAGS off,\xe2\x80\x9d to be of age and one\xe2\x80\x99s own master, to\r\nhave plenty of money. BAGS OF MYSTERY is another phrase in frequent use,\r\nand refers to sausages and saveloys. BAG OF TRICKS, refers to the whole\r\nof a means towards a result. \xe2\x80\x9cThat\xe2\x80\x99s the whole bag of tricks.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n~Baked~, seasoned, \xe2\x80\x9che\xe2\x80\x99s only HALF-BAKED,\xe2\x80\x9d _i.e._, soft, inexperienced.\r\n\r\n~Baker\xe2\x80\x99s Dozen~, thirteen. Originally the London bakers supplied the\r\nretailers, _i.e._, chandlers\xe2\x80\x99 shopkeepers and itinerants, with thirteen\r\nloaves to the dozen, so as to make up what is known as the overweight,\r\nthe surplus number, called the _inbread_, being thrown in for fear of\r\nincurring a penalty for short weight. To \xe2\x80\x9cgive a man a BAKER\xe2\x80\x99S DOZEN,\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nin a slang sense, sometimes means to give him an extra good beating or\r\npummelling.\r\n\r\n~Balaam~, printers\xe2\x80\x99 slang for matter kept in type about monstrous\r\nproductions of nature, &c., to fill up spaces in newspapers that would\r\notherwise be vacant. The term BALAAM-BOX has often been used as the name\r\nof a depository for rejected articles. Evidently from Scripture, and\r\nreferring to the \xe2\x80\x9cspeech of an ass.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n~Bald-Faced Stag~, a term of derision applied to a person with a bald\r\nhead. Also, still more coarsely, \xe2\x80\x9cBLADDER-OF-LARD.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n~Bale up~, an Australian term equivalent to our \xe2\x80\x9cShell out.\xe2\x80\x9d A demand\r\nfor instantaneous payment.\r\n\r\n~Ballambangjang.~ The Straits of BALLAMBANGJANG, though unnoticed by\r\ngeographers, are frequently mentioned in sailors\xe2\x80\x99 yarns as being so\r\nnarrow, and the rocks on each side so crowded with trees inhabited by\r\nmonkeys, that the ship\xe2\x80\x99s yards cannot be squared, on account of the\r\nmonkey\xe2\x80\x99s tails getting jammed into, and choking up, the brace\r\nblocks.\xe2\x80\x94_Sea._\r\n\r\n~Ballast~, money. A rich man is said to be well-ballasted. If not proud\r\nand over-bearing he is said to carry his ballast well.\r\n\r\n~Balmy~, weak-minded or idiotic (not insane).\r\n\r\n~Balmy~, sleep; \xe2\x80\x9chave a dose of the BALMY.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n~Bamboozle~, to deceive, make fun of, or cheat a person; abbreviated to\r\nBAM, which is sometimes used also as a substantive\xe2\x80\x94a deception, a sham,\r\na \xe2\x80\x9csell.\xe2\x80\x9d _Swift_ says BAMBOOZLE was invented by a nobleman in the reign\r\nof Charles II.; but this is very likely an error. The probability is\r\nthat a nobleman then first _used_ it in polite society. The term is\r\nderived from the _Gipsies_.\r\n\r\n~Bandannah~, originally a peculiar kind of silk pocket-handkerchief, now\r\nslang used to denote all sorts of \xe2\x80\x9cstooks,\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9cwipes,\xe2\x80\x9d and \xe2\x80\x9cfogles,\xe2\x80\x9d and\r\nin fact the generic term for a kerchief, whether neck or pocket.\r\n\r\n~Banded~, hungry. From the habit hungry folks have of tying themselves\r\ntight round the middle.\r\n\r\n~Bandy~, or CRIPPLE, a sixpence, so called from this coin being\r\ngenerally bent or crooked; old term for flimsy or bad cloth, temp. Q.\r\nElizabeth.\r\n\r\n~Bang~, to excel or surpass; BANGING, great or thumping.\r\n\r\n~Bang-up~, first-rate, in the best possible style.\r\n\r\n~Bank~, to put in a place of safety. \xe2\x80\x9cBANK the rag,\xe2\x80\x9d _i.e._, secure the\r\nnote. Also \xe2\x80\x9cto bank\xe2\x80\x9d is to go shares.\r\n\r\n~Bank~, the total amount possessed by any one, \xe2\x80\x9cHow\xe2\x80\x99s the BANK?\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9cNot\r\nvery strong; about one and a buck.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n~Bantling~, a child; stated in _Bacchus and Venus_, 1737, and by\r\n_Grose_, to be a cant term. This is hardly slang now-a-days, and modern\r\netymologists give its origin as that of bands or swaddling clothes.\r\n\r\n~Banyan-Day~, a day on which no meat is served out for rations; probably\r\nderived from the BANIANS, a Hindoo caste, who abstain from animal food.\r\nQuite as probably from the sanitary arrangements which have in hot\r\nclimates counselled the eating of BANYANS and other fruits in preference\r\nto meat on certain days.\xe2\x80\x94_Sea._\r\n\r\n~Bar~, or BARRING, excepting; in common use in the betting-ring; \xe2\x80\x9cTwo to\r\none bar one,\xe2\x80\x9d _i.e._, two to one against any horse with the exception of\r\none. The Irish use of BARRIN\xe2\x80\x99 is very similar, and the words BAR and\r\nBARRING may now be regarded as general.\r\n\r\n~Barber\xe2\x80\x99s Cat~, a half-starved sickly-looking person. Term used in\r\nconnexion with an expression too coarse to print.\r\n\r\n~Barber\xe2\x80\x99s Clerk~, an overdressed shopboy who apes the manners of, and\r\ntries to pass himself off as, a gentleman; a term of reproach applied\r\nnot to an artisan but to one of those who, being below, assume airs of\r\nsuperiority over, handicraftsmen.\r\n\r\n~Barge~, a term used among printers (compositors) to denote a case in\r\nwhich there is an undue proportion of some letters and a corresponding\r\nshortness of those which are most valuable.\r\n\r\n~Bark~, an Irish person of either sex. From this term, much in use among\r\nthe London lower orders, but for which no etymology can be found,\r\nIreland is now and then playfully called Barkshire.\r\n\r\n~Barker~, a man employed to cry at the doors of \xe2\x80\x9cgaffs,\xe2\x80\x9d shows, and\r\npuffing shops, to entice people inside. Among touting photographers he\r\nis called a doorsman.\r\n\r\n~Barking-Iron~, or BARKER, a pistol. Term used by footpads and thieves\r\ngenerally.\r\n\r\n~Barnacles~, spectacles; possibly a corruption of binoculi; but derived\r\nby some from the barnacle (_Lepas Anatifera_), a kind of conical shell\r\nadhering to ships\xe2\x80\x99 bottoms. Hence a marine term for goggles, which they\r\nresemble in shape, and for which they are used by sailors in case of\r\nophthalmic derangement.\r\n\r\n~Barney~, an unfair race of any kind: a sell or cross. Also a lark,\r\njollification, or outing. The word BARNEY is sometimes applied to a\r\nswindle unconnected with the sporting world.\r\n\r\n~Barn Stormers~, theatrical performers who travel the country and act in\r\nbarns, selecting short and tragic pieces to suit the rustic taste.\r\n\r\n~Barrikin~, jargon, speech, or discourse; \xe2\x80\x9cWe can\xe2\x80\x99t tumble to that\r\nBARRIKIN,\xe2\x80\x9d _i.e._, we don\xe2\x80\x99t understand what he says. \xe2\x80\x9cCheese your\r\nBARRIKIN,\xe2\x80\x9d shut up. _Miege_ calls it \xe2\x80\x9ca sort of stuff;\xe2\x80\x9d _Old French_,\r\nBARACAN.\r\n\r\n~Bash~, to beat, thrash; \xe2\x80\x9cBASHING a dona,\xe2\x80\x9d beating a woman; originally a\r\nprovincial word, applied to the practice of beating walnut trees, when\r\nin bud, with long poles, to increase their productiveness. Hence the\r\nWest country proverb\xe2\x80\x94\r\n\r\n    \xe2\x80\x9cA woman, a whelp, and a walnut tree,\r\n    The more you BASH \xe2\x80\x99em, the better they be.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe word BASH, among thieves, signifies to flog with the cat or birch.\r\nThe worst that can happen to a brutal ruffian is to receive \xe2\x80\x9ca BASHING\r\nin, and a BASHING out,\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94a flogging at the commencement and another at\r\nthe close of his term of enforced virtue.\r\n\r\n~Baste~, to beat, properly to pour gravy on roasting meat to keep it\r\nfrom burning, and add to its flavour. Also a sewing term.\r\n\r\n~Bastile~, the workhouse. General name for \xe2\x80\x9cthe Union\xe2\x80\x9d amongst the lower\r\norders of the _North_. Formerly used to denote a prison, or \xe2\x80\x9clock-up;\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nbut its abbreviated form, STEEL, is now the favourite expression with\r\nthe dangerous classes, some of whom have never heard of BASTILE,\r\nfamiliar as they are with \xe2\x80\x9csteel.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n~Bat~, \xe2\x80\x9con his own BAT,\xe2\x80\x9d on his own account. Evident modification of the\r\ncricket term, \xe2\x80\x9coff his own bat,\xe2\x80\x9d though not connected therewith.\xe2\x80\x94_See_\r\nHOOK.\r\n\r\n~Bat~, to take an innings at cricket. To \xe2\x80\x9ccarry out one\xe2\x80\x99s BAT\xe2\x80\x9d is to be\r\nlast in, _i.e._, to be \xe2\x80\x9cnot out.\xe2\x80\x9d A man\xe2\x80\x99s individual score is said to be\r\nmade \xe2\x80\x9coff his own BAT.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n~Bat~, pace at walking or running. As, \xe2\x80\x9cHe went off at a good BAT.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n~Bats~, a pair of bad boots.\r\n\r\n~Battells~, the weekly bills at Oxford. Probably originally wooden\r\ntallies, and so a diminutive of b\xc3\xa2ton.\xe2\x80\x94_University._\r\n\r\n~Batter~, wear and tear; \xe2\x80\x9ccan\xe2\x80\x99t stand the BATTER,\xe2\x80\x9d _i.e._, not equal to\r\nthe task; \xe2\x80\x9con the BATTER,\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9con the streets,\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9con the town,\xe2\x80\x9d or given up\r\nto roystering and debauchery.\r\n\r\n~Batty~, wages, perquisites. Derived from BATTA, an extra pay given to\r\nsoldiers while serving in _India_.\r\n\r\n~Batty-Fang~, to beat; BATTY-FANGING, a beating; also BATTER-FANG. Used\r\nmetaphorically as early as 1630.\r\n\r\n    \xe2\x80\x9cSo _batter-fanged_ and belabour\xe2\x80\x99d with tongue mettle, that he was\r\n    weary of his life.\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94_Taylor\xe2\x80\x99s Works._\r\n\r\n~Beach-Comber~, a fellow who prowls about the sea-shore to plunder\r\nwrecks, and pick up waifs and strays of any kind.\xe2\x80\x94_Sea._\r\n\r\n~Beak~, originally a magistrate, judge, or policeman; now a magistrate\r\nonly; \xe2\x80\x9cto baffle the BEAK,\xe2\x80\x9d to get remanded. _Ancient Cant_, BECK.\r\n_Saxon_, BEAG, a necklace or gold collar\xe2\x80\x94emblem of authority. Sir John\r\nFielding was called the BLIND-BEAK in the last century. Maybe connected\r\nwith the Italian BECCO, which means a (bird\xe2\x80\x99s) _beak_, and also a\r\n_blockhead_.\xe2\x80\x94_See_ WALKER.\r\n\r\n~Beaker-Hunter~, or BEAK-HUNTER, a stealer of poultry.\r\n\r\n~Beans~, money; \xe2\x80\x9ca haddock of BEANS,\xe2\x80\x9d a purse of money; formerly, BEAN\r\nmeant a guinea; _French_, BIENS, property.\r\n\r\n~Bear~, one who contracts to deliver or sell a certain quantity of stock\r\nin the public funds on a forthcoming day at a stated place, but who does\r\nnot possess it, trusting to a decline in public securities to enable him\r\nto fulfil the agreement and realize a profit.\xe2\x80\x94_See_ BULL. Both words\r\nare slang terms on the Stock Exchange, and are frequently used in the\r\nbusiness columns of newspapers.\r\n\r\n    \xe2\x80\x9cHe who sells that of which he is not possessed is proverbially said\r\n    to sell the skin before he has caught the BEAR. It was the practice\r\n    of stock-jobbers, in the year 1720, to enter into a contract for\r\n    transferring South Sea stock at a future time for a certain price;\r\n    but he who contracted to sell had frequently no stock to transfer,\r\n    nor did he who bought intend to receive any in consequence of his\r\n    bargain; the seller was, therefore, called a BEAR, in allusion to\r\n    the proverb, and the buyer a BULL, perhaps only as a similar\r\n    distinction. The contract was merely a wager, to be determined by\r\n    the rise or fall of stock; if it rose, the seller paid the\r\n    difference to the buyer, proportioned to the sum determined by the\r\n    same computation to the seller.\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94_Dr. Warton on Pope._\r\n\r\nThese arrangements are nowadays called \xe2\x80\x9ctime bargains,\xe2\x80\x9d and are as\r\nfairly (or unfairly) gambling as any transactions at the Victoria Club\r\nor Tattersall\xe2\x80\x99s, or any of the doings which call for the intervention of\r\nthe police and the protestations of pompous City magistrates, who,\r\nduring their terms of office, try to be virtuous and make their names\r\nimmortal. Certainly BULLING and BEARING are as productive of bankruptcy\r\nand misery as are BACKING and LAYING.\r\n\r\n~Be-argered~, drunk. (The word is divided here simply to convey the\r\npronunciation.)\r\n\r\n~Bear-Leader~, a tutor in a private family. In the old days of the\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cgrand tour\xe2\x80\x9d the term was much more in use and of course more\r\nsignificant than it is now.\r\n\r\n~Bear-up~ and ~Bearer-up~.\xe2\x80\x94_See_ BONNET.\r\n\r\n~Beat~, the allotted range traversed by a policeman on duty.\r\n\r\n~Beat~, or BEAT-HOLLOW, to surpass or excel; also \xe2\x80\x9cBEAT into fits,\xe2\x80\x9d and\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBEAT badly.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n~Beat~, \xe2\x80\x9cDEAD-BEAT,\xe2\x80\x9d wholly worn out, done up.\r\n\r\n~Beater-Cases~, boots. _Nearly obsolete._ TROTTER CASES is the term\r\nnowadays.\r\n\r\n~Beaver~, old street term for a hat; GOSS is the modern word, BEAVER,\r\nexcept in the country, having fallen into disuse.\r\n\r\n~Bebee~, a lady.\xe2\x80\x94_Anglo-Indian._\r\n\r\n~Be-Blowed~, a derisive instruction never carried into effect, as, \xe2\x80\x9cYou\r\nBE-BLOWED.\xe2\x80\x9d Used similarly to the old \xe2\x80\x9cGo to.\xe2\x80\x9d _See_ BLOW ME.\r\n\r\n~Bed-Fagot~, a contemptuous term for a woman; generally applied to a\r\nprostitute.\xe2\x80\x94_See_ FAGOT.\r\n\r\n~Bed-Post~, \xe2\x80\x9cin the twinkling of a BED-POST,\xe2\x80\x9d in a moment, or very\r\nquickly. Originally BED-STAFF, a stick placed vertically in the frame of\r\na bed to keep the bedding in its place, and used sometimes as a\r\ndefensive weapon.\r\n\r\n~Bee~, \xe2\x80\x9cto have a BEE in one\xe2\x80\x99s bonnet,\xe2\x80\x9d _i.e._, to be not exactly sane;\r\nto have a craze in one particular direction. Several otherwise sensible\r\nand excellent M.P.\xe2\x80\x99s are distinguished by the \xe2\x80\x9cBEE in his bonnet\xe2\x80\x9d each\r\ncarries.\r\n\r\n~Beef-Headed~, stupid, fat-headed, dull.\r\n\r\n~Beefy~, unduly thick or fat, commonly said of women\xe2\x80\x99s ankles; also\r\nrich, juicy, plenteous. To take the whole pool at loo, or to have any\r\nparticular run of luck at cards generally is said by players to be \xe2\x80\x9cvery\r\nBEEFY.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n~Beeline~, the straightest possible line of route to a given point. When\r\na bee is well laden, it makes a straight flight for home. Originally an\r\nAmericanism, but now general.\r\n\r\n~Beery~, intoxicated, or fuddled with beer.\r\n\r\n~Beeswax~, poor, soft cheese. Sometimes called \xe2\x80\x9csweaty-toe cheese.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n~Beeswing~, the film which forms on the sides of bottles which contain\r\ngood old port wine. This breaks up into small pieces in the process of\r\ndecanting, and looks like BEES\xe2\x80\x99 WINGS. Hence the term.\r\n\r\n~Beetle-Crusher~, or SQUASHER, a large flat foot. The expression was\r\nmade popular by being once used by Leech.\r\n\r\n~Beetle-Sticker~, an entomologist.\r\n\r\n~Beggars\xe2\x80\x99 Velvet~, downy particles which accumulate under furniture from\r\nthe negligence of housemaids. Otherwise called SLUTS\xe2\x80\x99-WOOL.\r\n\r\n~Belcher~, a blue bird\xe2\x80\x99s-eye handkerchief.\xe2\x80\x94_See_ BILLY.\r\n\r\n~Bell~, a song. Tramps\xe2\x80\x99 term. Simply diminutive of BELLOW.\r\n\r\n~Bellows~, the lungs. BELLOWSER, a blow in the \xe2\x80\x9cwind,\xe2\x80\x9d or pit of the\r\nstomach, taking one\xe2\x80\x99s breath away.\r\n\r\n~Bellowsed~, or LAGGED, transported.\r\n\r\n~Bellows to Mend~, a person out of breath; especially a pugilist is said\r\nto be \xe2\x80\x9cBELLOWS TO MEND\xe2\x80\x9d when winded. With the P.R., the word has fallen\r\ninto desuetude.\r\n\r\n~Belly-Timber~, food, or \xe2\x80\x9cgrub.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n~Belly-Vengeance~, small sour beer, apt to cause gastralgia.\r\n\r\n~Bemuse~, to fuddle one\xe2\x80\x99s self with drink, \xe2\x80\x9cBEMUSING himself with beer,\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n&c.\r\n\r\n~Ben~, a benefit.\xe2\x80\x94_Theatrical._\r\n\r\n~Ben Cull~, a friend, or \xe2\x80\x9cpal.\xe2\x80\x9d Expression used by thieves.\r\n\r\n~Bend~, \xe2\x80\x9cthat\xe2\x80\x99s above my bend,\xe2\x80\x9d _i.e._, beyond my power, too expensive or\r\ntoo difficult for me to perform.\r\n\r\n~Bender~, a sixpence. Probably from its liability to bend. In the days\r\nwhen the term was most in use sixpences were not kept in the excellent\r\nstate of preservation peculiar to the currency of the present day.\r\n\r\n~Bender~, the arm; \xe2\x80\x9cover the BENDER,\xe2\x80\x9d synonymous with \xe2\x80\x9cover the\r\nleft.\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94_See_ OVER.\r\n\r\n~Bendigo~, a rough fur cap worn in the midland counties, called after a\r\nnoted pugilist of that name. \xe2\x80\x9cHard Punchers\xe2\x80\x9d are caps worn by London\r\nroughs and formerly by men in training. They are a modification of the\r\ncommon Scotch cap, and have peaks.\r\n\r\n~Bene~, good.\xe2\x80\x94_Ancient Cant_; BENAR was the comparative.\xe2\x80\x94_See_ BONE.\r\n_Latin._\r\n\r\n~Benedick~, a married man. _Shakspeare._\r\n\r\n~Benjamin~, coat. Formerly termed a JOSEPH, in allusion, perhaps, to\r\nJoseph\xe2\x80\x99s coat of many colours.\xe2\x80\x94_See_ UPPER-BENJAMIN.\r\n\r\n~Ben Joltram~, brown bread and skimmed milk; a Norfolk term for a\r\nploughboy\xe2\x80\x99s breakfast.\r\n\r\n~Benjy~, a waistcoat, diminutive of BENJAMIN.\r\n\r\n~Beong~, a shilling.\xe2\x80\x94_See_ SALTEE.\xe2\x80\x94_Lingua Franca._\r\n\r\n~Bess-o\xe2\x80\x99-Bedlam~, a lunatic vagrant.\xe2\x80\x94_Norfolk._\r\n\r\n~Best~, to get the better or BEST of a man in any way\xe2\x80\x94not necessarily\r\nto cheat\xe2\x80\x94to have the best of a bargain. BESTED, taken in, or defrauded,\r\nin reality worsted. BESTER, a low betting cheat, a fraudulent bookmaker.\r\n\r\n~Better~, more; \xe2\x80\x9chow far is it to town?\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9cOh, BETTER \xe2\x80\x99n a mile.\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94_Saxon_\r\nand _Old English_, now a vulgarism.\r\n\r\n~Betting Round~, laying fairly and equally against nearly all the horses\r\nin a race so that no great risk can be run. Commonly called getting\r\nround. _See_ BOOK, and BOOKMAKING.\r\n\r\n~Betty~, a skeleton key, or picklock.\xe2\x80\x94_Old Prison Cant._\r\n\r\n~B Flats~, bugs.\xe2\x80\x94_Compare_ F SHARPS.\r\n\r\n~Bible-Carrier~, a person who sells songs without singing them.\xe2\x80\x94_Seven\r\nDials._\r\n\r\n~Biddy~, a general name applied to Irish stallwomen and milkmaids, in\r\nthe same manner that Mike is given to the labouring men. A big red-faced\r\nIrish servant girl is known as a Bridget.\r\n\r\n~Big~, \xe2\x80\x9cto look BIG,\xe2\x80\x9d to assume an inflated air or manner; \xe2\x80\x9cto talk\r\nBIG,\xe2\x80\x9d _i.e._, boastingly.\r\n\r\n~Big-Bird~, TO GET THE, _i.e._, to be hissed, as actors occasionally are\r\nby the \xe2\x80\x9cgods.\xe2\x80\x9d BIG-BIRD is simply a metaphor for goose.\xe2\x80\x94_Theat. Slang._\r\n\r\n~Big House~, or LARGE HOUSE, the workhouse,\xe2\x80\x94a phrase used by the very\r\npoor.\r\n\r\n~Big-wig~, a person in authority or office. Exchangeable with \xe2\x80\x9cGREAT\r\nGUN.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n~Bilbo~, a sword; abbrev. of \xe2\x80\x9cBILBAO blade.\xe2\x80\x9d Spanish swords were\r\nanciently very celebrated, especially those of Toledo, Bilbao, &c.\r\n\r\n~Bilk~, a cheat, or a swindler. Formerly in general use, now confined to\r\nthe streets, where it is common, and mostly used in reference to\r\nprostitutes. _Gothic_, BILAICAN.\r\n\r\n~Bilk~, to defraud, or obtain goods, &c., without paying for them; \xe2\x80\x9cto\r\nBILK the schoolmaster,\xe2\x80\x9d to get information or experience without paying\r\nfor it.\r\n\r\n~Billingsgate~ (when applied to speech), foul and coarse language. Many\r\nyears since people used to visit Thames Street to hear the Billingsgate\r\nfishwomen abuse each other. The anecdote of Dr. Johnson and the\r\nBillingsgate virago is well known.\r\n\r\n~Billingsgate Pheasant~, a red herring or bloater. This is also called a\r\n\xe2\x80\x9ctwo-eyed steak.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n~Billy~, a silk pocket-handkerchief.\xe2\x80\x94_Scotch._\xe2\x80\x94_See_ WIPE.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x81\x82 A list of slang terms descriptive of the various patterns of\r\nhandkerchiefs, pocket and neck, is here subjoined:\xe2\x80\x94\r\n\r\n    BELCHER, darkish blue ground, large round white spots, with a spot\r\n    in the centre of darker blue than the ground. This was adopted by\r\n    Jem Belcher, the pugilist, as his \xe2\x80\x9ccolours,\xe2\x80\x9d and soon became popular\r\n    amongst \xe2\x80\x9cthe fancy.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n    BIRD\xe2\x80\x99S-EYE WIPE, a handkerchief of any colour, containing white\r\n    spots. The blue bird\xe2\x80\x99s-eye is similar to the Belcher except in the\r\n    centre. Sometimes a BIRD\xe2\x80\x99S-EYE WIPE has a white ground and blue\r\n    spots.\r\n\r\n    BLOOD-RED FANCY, red.\r\n\r\n    BLUE BILLY, blue ground, generally with white figures.\r\n\r\n    CREAM FANCY, any pattern on a white ground.\r\n\r\n    KING\xe2\x80\x99S MAN, yellow pattern on a green ground.\r\n\r\n    RANDAL\xe2\x80\x99S MAN, green, with white spots; named after the favourite\r\n    colours of Jack Randal, pugilist.\r\n\r\n    WATER\xe2\x80\x99S MAN, sky coloured.\r\n\r\n    YELLOW FANCY, yellow, with white spots.\r\n\r\n    YELLOW MAN, all yellow.\r\n\r\n~Billy~, a policeman\xe2\x80\x99s staff. Also stolen metal of any kind.\r\nBILLY-HUNTING is buying old metal. A BILLY-FENCER is a marine-store\r\ndealer.\r\n\r\n~Billy-Barlow~, a street clown; sometimes termed a JIM CROW, or\r\nSALTIMBANCO,\xe2\x80\x94so called from the hero of a slang song. Billy was a real\r\nperson, semi-idiotic, and though in dirt and rags, fancied himself a\r\nswell of the first water. Occasionally he came out with real witticisms.\r\nHe was a well-known street character about the East-end of London, and\r\ndied in Whitechapel Workhouse.\r\n\r\n~Billy-Cock~, a soft felt hat of the Jim Crow or \xe2\x80\x9cwide-awake\xe2\x80\x9d\r\ndescription.\r\n\r\n~Bingo~, brandy.\xe2\x80\x94_Old Cant._\r\n\r\n~Bingy~, a term largely used in the butter trade to denote bad, ropy\r\nbutter; nearly equivalent to VINNIED.\r\n\r\n~Bird-Cage~, a four-wheeled cab.\r\n\r\n~Birthday Suit~, the suit in which Adam and Eve first saw each other,\r\nand \xe2\x80\x9cwere not ashamed.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n~Bishop~, a warm drink composed of materials similar to those used in\r\nthe manufacture of \xe2\x80\x9cflip\xe2\x80\x9d and \xe2\x80\x9cpurl.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n~Bit~, fourpence; in America a 12-1/2 cent piece is called a BIT, and a\r\ndefaced 20 cent piece is termed a LONG BIT. A BIT is the smallest coin\r\nin Jamaica, equal to 6d. BIT usually means the smallest silver coin in\r\ncirculation; also a piece of money of any kind. Charles Bannister, the\r\nwitty singer and actor, one day meeting a Bow Street runner with a man\r\nin custody, asked what the prisoner had done; and being told that he had\r\nstolen a bridle, and had been detected in the act of selling it, said,\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, then, he wanted to touch the BIT.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n~Bitch~, tea; \xe2\x80\x9ca BITCH party,\xe2\x80\x9d a tea-drinking. Probably because\r\nundergraduates consider tea only fit for old women.\xe2\x80\x94_Oxford._\r\n\r\n~Bite~, a cheat; \xe2\x80\x9ca Yorkshire BITE,\xe2\x80\x9d a cheating fellow from that county.\r\nThe term BITE is also applied to a hard bargainer.\xe2\x80\x94_North_; also _old\r\nslang_\xe2\x80\x94used by _Pope_. Swift says it originated with a nobleman in his\r\nday.\r\n\r\n~Bite~, to cheat; \xe2\x80\x9cto be BITTEN,\xe2\x80\x9d to be taken in or imposed upon.\r\nOriginally a Gipsy term. CROSS-BITER, for a cheat, continually\r\noccurs in writers of the sixteenth century. Bailey has CROSS-BITE, a\r\ndisappointment, probably the primary sense; and BITE is very probably a\r\ncontraction of this.\r\n\r\n~Bit-Faker~, or TURNER OUT, a coiner of bad money.\r\n\r\n~Bit-of-Stuff~, overdressed man; a man with full confidence in his\r\nappearance and abilities; a young woman, who is also called a BIT OF\r\nMUSLIN.\r\n\r\n~Bitter~, diminutive of bitter beer; \xe2\x80\x9cto do a BITTER,\xe2\x80\x9d to drink\r\nbeer.\xe2\x80\x94Originally _Oxford_, but now general.\r\n\r\n~Bittock~, a distance of very undecided length. If a North countryman be\r\nasked the distance to a place, he will most probably reply, \xe2\x80\x9ca mile and\r\na BITTOCK.\xe2\x80\x9d The latter may be considered any distance from one hundred\r\nyards to ten miles.\r\n\r\n~Bivvy~, or GATTER, beer; \xe2\x80\x9cshant of BIVVY,\xe2\x80\x9d a pot or quart of beer. In\r\nSuffolk the afternoon refreshment of reapers is called BEVER. It is also\r\nan old English term.\r\n\r\n    \xe2\x80\x9cHe is none of those same ordinary eaters, that will devour three\r\n    breakfasts, and as many dinners, without any prejudice to their\r\n    BEVERS, drinkings, or suppers.\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94_Beaumont and Fletcher\xe2\x80\x99s Woman\r\n    Hater_, i. 3.\r\n\r\nBoth words are probably from the _Italian_, BEVERE, BERE. _Latin_,\r\nBIBERE. _English_, BEVERAGE.\r\n\r\n~Biz~, contraction of the word business; a phrase much used in America\r\nin writing as well as in conversation.\r\n\r\n~B. K. S.~ Military officers in _mufti_, when out on a spree, and not\r\nwishing their profession to be known, speak of their barracks as the\r\nB.\xc2\xa0K.\xc2\xa0S.\r\n\r\n~Black and White~, handwriting or print. \xe2\x80\x9cLet\xe2\x80\x99s have it in BLACK AND\r\nWHITE,\xe2\x80\x9d is often said with regard to an agreement when it is to the\r\nadvantage of one or both that it should be written.\r\n\r\n~Black-a-vised~, having a very dark complexion.\r\n\r\n~Blackberry-Swagger~, a person who hawks tapes, boot-laces, &c.\r\n\r\n~Blackbirding~, slave-catching. Term most applied nowadays to the\r\nPolynesian coolie traffic.\r\n\r\n~Black Diamonds~, coals; talented persons of dingy or unpolished\r\nexterior; rough jewels.\r\n\r\n~Blackguard~, a low or dirty fellow; a rough or a hulking fellow,\r\ncapable of any meanness or cowardice.\r\n\r\n    \xe2\x80\x9cA cant word amongst the vulgar, by which is implied a dirty fellow\r\n    of the meanest kind, Dr. Johnson says, and he cites only the modern\r\n    authority of Swift. But the introduction of this word into our\r\n    language belongs not to the vulgar, and is more than a century prior\r\n    to the time of Swift. Mr. Malone agrees with me in exhibiting the\r\n    two first of the following examples:\xe2\x80\x94The _black-guard_ is evidently\r\n    designed to imply a fit attendant on the devil. Mr. Gifford,\r\n    however, in his late edition of Ben Jonson\xe2\x80\x99s works, assigns an\r\n    origin of the name different from what the old examples which I have\r\n    cited seem to countenance. It has been formed, he says, from those\r\n    \xe2\x80\x98mean and dirty dependants, in great houses, who were selected to\r\n    carry coals to the kitchen, halls, &c. To this smutty regiment, who\r\n    attended the progresses, and rode in the carts with the pots and\r\n    kettles, which, with every other article of furniture, were then\r\n    moved from palace to palace, the people, in derision, gave the name\r\n    of _black guards_; a term since become sufficiently familiar, and\r\n    never properly explained.\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94_Todd\xe2\x80\x99s Johnson\xe2\x80\x99s Dictionary._\r\n\r\nBlackguard as an adjective is very powerful.\r\n\r\n~Blackleg~, a rascal, swindler, or card cheat. The derivation of this\r\nterm was solemnly argued before the full Court of Queen\xe2\x80\x99s Bench upon a\r\nmotion for a new trial for libel, but was not decided by the learned\r\ntribunal. Probably it is from the custom of sporting and turf men\r\nwearing black _top-boots_. Hence BLACKLEG came to be the phrase for a\r\nprofessional sporting man, and thence for a professional sporting cheat.\r\nThe word is now in its worst sense diminished to \xe2\x80\x9cleg.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n~Black Maria~, the sombre van in which prisoners are conveyed from the\r\npolice court to prison.\r\n\r\n~Black Monday~, the Monday on which boys return to school after the\r\nholidays. Also a low term for the Monday on which an execution took\r\nplace.\r\n\r\n~Black Sheep~, a \xe2\x80\x9cbad lot,\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9c_mauvais sujet_;\xe2\x80\x9d sometimes \xe2\x80\x9cscabby sheep;\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nalso a workman who refuses to join in a strike.\r\n\r\n~Black Strap~, port wine; especially that which is thick and sweet.\r\n\r\n~Blackwork~, undertaking. The waiters met at public dinners are often\r\nemployed during the day as mutes, etc. Omnibus and cab drivers regard\r\nBLACKWORK as a _dernier ressort_.\r\n\r\n~Bladder-of-Lard~, a coarse, satirical nickname for a bald-headed\r\nperson. From similarity of appearance.\r\n\r\n~Blade~, a man\xe2\x80\x94in ancient times the term for a soldier; \xe2\x80\x9cknowing\r\nBLADE,\xe2\x80\x9d a wide-awake, sharp, or cunning man.\r\n\r\n~Blarney~, flattery, powers of persuasion. A castle in the county of\r\nCork. It is said that whoever kisses a certain stone in this castle will\r\nbe able to persuade others of whatever he or she pleases. The name of\r\nthe castle is derived from BLADH, a blossom, _i.e._, the flowery or\r\nfertile demesne. BLADH is also flattery; hence the connexion. A more\r\nthan ordinarily persuasive Irishman is said to have \xe2\x80\x9ckissed the BLARNEY\r\nstone.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n~Blast~, to curse. Originally a _Military_ expression.\r\n\r\n~Blaze~, to leave trace purposely of one\xe2\x80\x99s way in a forest or unknown\r\npath by marking trees or other objects.\r\n\r\n~Blazes~, a low synonym for the infernal regions, and now almost for\r\nanything. \xe2\x80\x9cLike BLAZES\xe2\x80\x9d is a phrase of intensification applied without\r\nany reference to the original meaning. Also applied to the brilliant\r\nhabiliments of flunkeys, since the episode of Sam Weller and the\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cswarry.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n~Bleed~, to victimize, or extract money from a person, to sponge on, to\r\nmake suffer vindictively.\r\n\r\n~Blest~, a vow; \xe2\x80\x9cBLEST if I\xe2\x80\x99ll do it,\xe2\x80\x9d _i.e._, I am determined not to do\r\nit; euphemism for CURST.\r\n\r\n~Blether~, to bother, to annoy, to pester. \xe2\x80\x9cA BLETHERING old nuisance\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nis a common expression for a garrulous old person.\r\n\r\n~Blew~, or BLOW, to inform, or peach, to lose or spend money.\r\n\r\n~Blewed~, a man who has lost or spent all his money is said to have\r\nBLEWED it. Also used in cases of robbery from the person, as, \xe2\x80\x9cHe\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nBLEWED his red \xe2\x80\x99un,\xe2\x80\x9d _i.e._, he\xe2\x80\x99s been eased of his watch.\r\n\r\n~Blewed~, got rid of, disposed of, spent.\r\n\r\n~Blind~, a pretence, or make-believe.\r\n\r\n~Blind-Half-Hundred~, the Fiftieth Regiment of Foot; so called through\r\ntheir great sufferings from ophthalmia when serving in Egypt.\r\n\r\n~Blind-Hookey~, a game at cards which has no recommendation beyond the\r\nrapidity with which money can be won and lost at it; called also WILFUL\r\nMURDER.\r\n\r\n~Blind-Man\xe2\x80\x99s-Holiday~, night, darkness. Sometimes applied to the period\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cbetween the lights.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n~Blind Monkeys~, an imaginary collection at the Zoological Gardens,\r\nwhich are supposed to receive care and attention from persons fitted by\r\nnature for such office and for little else. An idle and useless person\r\nis often told that he is only fit to lead the BLIND MONKEYS to evacuate.\r\nAnother form this elegant conversation takes, is for one man to tell\r\nanother that he knows of a suitable situation for him. \xe2\x80\x9cHow much a week?\r\nand what to do?\xe2\x80\x9d are natural questions, and then comes the scathing and\r\nsarcastic reply, \xe2\x80\x9cFive bob a week at the doctor\xe2\x80\x99s\xe2\x80\x94you\xe2\x80\x99re to stand\r\nbehind the door and make the patients sick. They wont want no physic\r\nwhen they sees your mug.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n~Blinker~, a blackened eye.\xe2\x80\x94_Norwich._ Also a hard blow in the eye.\r\nBLINKERS, spectacles.\r\n\r\n~Blink-Fencer~, a person who sells spectacles.\r\n\r\n~Bloated Aristocrat~, a street term for any decently dressed person.\r\nFrom the persistent abuse lavished on a \xe2\x80\x9cbloated and parasitical\r\naristocracy\xe2\x80\x9d by Hyde Park demagogues and a certain unpleasant portion of\r\nthe weekly press.\r\n\r\n~Bloater.~\xe2\x80\x94_See_ MILD.\r\n\r\n~Blob~ (from BLAB), to talk. Beggars are of two kinds\xe2\x80\x94those who SCREEVE\r\n(introducing themselves with a FAKEMENT, or false document) and those\r\nwho BLOB, or state their case in their own truly \xe2\x80\x9cunvarnished\xe2\x80\x9d language.\r\n\r\n~Block~, the head. \xe2\x80\x9cTo BLOCK a hat,\xe2\x80\x9d is to knock a man\xe2\x80\x99s hat down over\r\nhis eyes.\xe2\x80\x94_See_ BONNET. Also a street obstruction.\r\n\r\n~Block Ornaments~, the small dark-coloured and sometimes stinking pieces\r\nof meat which used to be exposed on the cheap butchers\xe2\x80\x99 blocks or\r\ncounters; matters of interest to all the sharp-visaged women in poor\r\nneighbourhoods. Since the great rise in the price of meat there has been\r\nlittle necessity for butchers to make block ornaments of their odds and\r\nends.
