From \xe2\x80\x9cnab,\xe2\x80\x9d a hat, cap, or head.\xe2\x80\x94_Old Cant._\r\n\r\n~Nap nix~, a person who works at his trade, and occasionally goes on the\r\nstage to act minor parts without receiving any pay. The derivation is\r\nobvious. _See_ NAP and NIX, _i.e._, NICHTS.\r\n\r\n~Nap one\xe2\x80\x99s bib~, to cry, shed tears, or carry one\xe2\x80\x99s point.\r\n\r\n~Nap the regulars~, to divide the booty.\r\n\r\n~Nap the teaze~, to be privately whipped in prison.\r\n\r\n~Nark~, a person in the pay of the police; a common informer; one who\r\ngets his living by laying traps for publicans, &c. Sometimes called a\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cnose.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n~Nark~, to watch, or look after; \xe2\x80\x9cNARK the titter,\xe2\x80\x9d watch the girl.\r\n\r\n~Narp~, a shirt.\xe2\x80\x94_Scotch._\r\n\r\n~Narrow~, mean, sordid.\xe2\x80\x94_Scotch._ In common slang, dull of\r\ncomprehension, as distinguished from wide awake.\r\n\r\n~Nasty~, ill-tempered, cross-grained. \xe2\x80\x9cHe was very NASTY,\xe2\x80\x9d _i.e._, he\r\nwas ill-humoured.\r\n\r\n~Nation~, or TARNATION, very, or exceedingly. Corruption of damnation.\r\n\r\n~Natty~, pretty, neat, tidy.\xe2\x80\x94_Old._\r\n\r\n~Natural~, an idiot, a simpleton. Sometimes HALF-NATURAL.\r\n\r\n~Navvy~, an excavator employed in making railways, canals, &c.\r\nOriginally slang, but now a recognised term. Short for navigator, a term\r\nhumorously applied to excavators when their chief work was that of\r\ncutting and banking canals, making dykes to rivers, &c.\r\n\r\n~N. C.~, \xe2\x80\x9cenough said,\xe2\x80\x9d being the initials of NUF CED. A certain\r\ntheatrical manager spells, it is said, in this style.\r\n\r\n~Near~, mean and stingy.\r\n\r\n~Neardy~, a person in authority over another; master, parent, or\r\nforeman.\xe2\x80\x94_North._\r\n\r\n~Neat~, unmixed with water. \xe2\x80\x9cTwo half goes of gin, one NEAT, the other\r\ncold,\xe2\x80\x9d meaning one as drawn, the other diluted with cold water. The\r\nAmericans use the word \xe2\x80\x9cstraight\xe2\x80\x9d instead of NEAT: \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ll take mine\r\nstraight.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n~Neck~, to swallow. Neck-oil, drink of any kind.\r\n\r\n~Neck and crop~, entirely, completely; \xe2\x80\x9che chuck\xe2\x80\x99d him NECK AND CROP out\r\nof window.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n~Neck and neck.~ Horses run NECK AND NECK in a race when they are so\r\nperfectly equal that one cannot be said to be before the other.\r\n\r\n~Neck or nothing~, desperate. Originally a steeplechase phrase.\r\n\r\n~Neck beef~, a synonym for coarseness. \xe2\x80\x9cAs coarse as neck ends of beef.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n~Neckinger~, a cravat. _See_ MUCKENGER.\r\n\r\n~Ned~, a guinea. HALF-NED, half-a-guinea.\r\n\r\n~Neddy~, a considerable quantity, as \xe2\x80\x9ca NEDDY of fruit,\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9ca NEDDY of\r\nfish,\xe2\x80\x9d &c.\xe2\x80\x94_Irish slang._\r\n\r\n~Neddy~, a donkey. On Sunday, when a costermonger, if at all well to do,\r\ntakes his family out for an airing in his \xe2\x80\x9cshallow,\xe2\x80\x9d the donkey is\r\ncalled \xe2\x80\x9cEddard.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n~Neddy~, a life preserver. Possibly contraction of Kennedy, the name of\r\nthe first man, it is said in St. Giles\xe2\x80\x99s, who had his head broken by a\r\npoker.\r\n\r\n~Ned Stokes~, the four of spades.\xe2\x80\x94_North Hants._ _See Gentleman\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nMagazine_ for 1791, p. 141.\r\n\r\n~Needful~, money, cash; the \xe2\x80\x9cone thing NEEDFUL\xe2\x80\x9d for the accomplishment\r\nof most pet designs.\r\n\r\n~Needle~, to annoy. To \xe2\x80\x9ccop the NEEDLE\xe2\x80\x9d is to become vexed or annoyed.\r\n\r\n~Needy mizzler~, a shabby person; a tramp who runs away without paying\r\nfor his lodging.\r\n\r\n~Never trust me~, an ordinary phrase with low Londoners, and common in\r\nShakspeare\xe2\x80\x99s time, _vide Twelfth Night_. It is generally used instead of\r\nan oath, calling vengeance on the asseverator, if such-and-such does\r\nnot come to pass.\r\n\r\n~Newgate fringe~, or FRILL, the collar of beard worn under the chin; so\r\ncalled from its occupying the position of the rope when Jack Ketch\r\noperates. Another name for it is a TYBURN COLLAR.\r\n\r\n~Newgate Knocker~, the term given to the lock of hair which\r\ncostermongers and thieves usually twist back towards the ear. The shape\r\nis supposed to resemble the knocker on the prisoners\xe2\x80\x99 door at Newgate\xe2\x80\x94a\r\nresemblance that carries a rather unpleasant suggestion to the wearer.\r\nSometimes termed a COBBLER\xe2\x80\x99S KNOT, or COW-LICK.\r\n\r\n~Newmarket~, in tossing, when the game is \xe2\x80\x9ctwo out of three,\xe2\x80\x9d that is,\r\nwhen he who gains the first two tosses wins. When the first toss is\r\ndecisive, the game is termed \xe2\x80\x9csudden death.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n~Nibble~, to take, or steal. NIBBLER, a petty thief.\r\n\r\n~Nib-cove~, a gentleman. NIBSOMEST CRIBS, best or gentlemen\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nhouses.\xe2\x80\x94_Beggar\xe2\x80\x99s Cant._\r\n\r\n~Nib-like~, gentlemanly.\r\n\r\n~Nibs~, self. His NIBS, means any one who may be referred to. As, \xe2\x80\x9cI\r\ntold his NIBS,\xe2\x80\x9d or \xe2\x80\x9cstag his NIBS.\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9cYour NIBS,\xe2\x80\x9d yourself.\r\n\r\n~Nick~, or OLD NICK, the devil.\xe2\x80\x94_Scandinavian_, KNICKAR, one of the\r\nnames of Odin, as the destroying or evil principle.\r\n\r\n~Nick~, to hit the mark; \xe2\x80\x9che\xe2\x80\x99s NICKED it,\xe2\x80\x9d _i.e._, won his point. Also\r\nto steal. To be \xe2\x80\x9cout on the NICK,\xe2\x80\x9d is to be out thieving. Sometimes\r\ndescribed as being \xe2\x80\x9con the pinch.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n~Nick-nack~, a trifle.\xe2\x80\x94Originally _Cant_.\r\n\r\n~Niggling~, trifling, or idling; taking short steps in\r\nwalking.\xe2\x80\x94_North._\r\n\r\n~Nightcap~, a glass of \xe2\x80\x9cwarm with\xe2\x80\x9d taken the last thing at night.\r\n\r\n~Night-hunter~, a poacher.\xe2\x80\x94_North._ Also a London prostitute. Sometimes\r\nin the latter capacity varied to night-hawk.\r\n\r\n~Nil~, half; half profits, &c.\r\n\r\n~Nilly-willy~, _i.e._, NILL YE, WILL YE, whether you will or no; a\r\nfamiliar version of the _Latin_, NOLENS VOLENS. Generally written now,\r\nWILLY-NILLY.\r\n\r\n~Nimming~, stealing. _Old English_, NIM, to take. Motherwell, the Scotch\r\npoet, thought the old word NIM (to snatch or pick up) was derived from\r\n_nam, nam_, the tiny words or cries of an infant, when eating anything\r\nwhich pleases its little palate. A negro proverb has the word:\xe2\x80\x94\r\n\r\n    \xe2\x80\x9cBuckra man NAM crab,\r\n    Cram NAM buckra man.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nOr, in the buckra man\xe2\x80\x99s language\xe2\x80\x94\r\n\r\n    \xe2\x80\x9cWhite man eat [or steal] the crab,\r\n    And then crab eat the white man.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\r\nShakspeare evidently had the word NIM in his head when he portrayed Nym.\r\n\r\n~Nincompoop~, a fool, a hen-pecked husband, a \xe2\x80\x9cJerry Sneak.\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94Corruption\r\nof _non compos mentis_.\r\n\r\n~Nine corns~, a pipeful of tobacco.\r\n\r\n~Ninepence~, \xe2\x80\x9cnice as NINEPENCE,\xe2\x80\x9d all right, right to a nicety. A\r\ncorrespondent says:\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cThis most undoubtedly should be NINE-PINS. For at\r\nthe game of that name, in fairness to both parties, the nine pins must\r\nalways be set up with great accuracy. There is no nicety in NINEPENCE!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nEvidently this correspondent does not know how nice it is to have\r\nninepence, after being without money. At all events the phrase _is_\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cnice as NINEPENCE.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n~Nines~, \xe2\x80\x9cdressed up to the NINES,\xe2\x80\x9d in a showy or _recherch\xc3\xa9_ manner. Up\r\nto the NINES, up to the dodges and \xe2\x80\x9cwrinkles\xe2\x80\x9d of life.\r\n\r\n~Nine Shillings~, cool audacity; most probably derived from the\r\n_French_, NONCHALANCE.\r\n\r\n~Ning-nang~, horse-coupers\xe2\x80\x99 term for a worthless thoroughbred.\r\n\r\n~Ninnyhammer~, a foolish, ignorant person. Generally shortened to NINNY.\r\nNINNY is also short for nincompoop.\r\n\r\n~Nip~, to steal, to take up quickly. _See_ NAP and NIB.\r\n\r\n~Nipcheese~, a purser.\xe2\x80\x94_Old Sea Slang._\r\n\r\n~Nipper~, a sharp lad. Originally a superior grade among cut-purses.\r\n\r\n~Nix~, nothing. _German_, NICHTS. _See_ MUNGARLY.\r\n\r\n~Nix!~ the signal word of schoolboys and workpeople to each other that\r\nthe master, or other person in authority, is approaching.\r\n\r\n~Nix my dolly~, once a very popular slang song, beginning\xe2\x80\x94\r\n\r\n    \xe2\x80\x9cIn a box of a stone jug I was born,\r\n        Of a hempen widow all forlorn;\r\n    And my old dad, as I\xe2\x80\x99ve heard say,\r\n        Was a famous merchant in capers gay;\r\n            NIX MY DOLLY, pals, fake away!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCapers\xe2\x80\x9d of course here refers to the mode of the old gentleman\xe2\x80\x99s\r\ndecease.\r\n\r\n~Niz-priz~, a writ of nisi-prius.\xe2\x80\x94_Legal._\r\n\r\n~Nizzie~, a fool, a coxcomb.\xe2\x80\x94_Old Cant, vide Triumph of Wit_.\r\n\r\n~Nob~, the head.\xe2\x80\x94_Pugilistic_; \xe2\x80\x9cbob a NOB,\xe2\x80\x9d a shilling a head. _Ancient\r\nCant_, NEB. NOB is an early English word, and is used in the romance of\r\n_Kynge Alinaunder_ (thirteenth century) for a head; originally, no\r\ndoubt, the same as _knob_.\r\n\r\n~Nob~, a person of high position, a \xe2\x80\x9cswell,\xe2\x80\x9d a NOBleman,\xe2\x80\x94of which word\r\nit may be an abbreviation, or of NOBILIS. _See_ SNOB.\r\n\r\n~Nob.~ When the knave of trumps is held at the game of cribbage, the\r\nholder counts \xe2\x80\x9cone for his NOB.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n~Nobba~, nine. _Italian_, NOVE; _Spanish_, NOVA,\xe2\x80\x94the _b_ and _v_ being\r\ninterchangeable, as in sa_b_e and sa_vv_ey. Slang introduced by the\r\n\xe2\x80\x9corgan-grinders\xe2\x80\x9d from Italy.\r\n\r\n~Nobba saltee~, ninepence. _Lingua Franca_, NOVE SOLDI.\r\n\r\n~Nobbing cheat~, the gallows.\xe2\x80\x94_Old Cant._\r\n\r\n~Nobbing~, collecting money; \xe2\x80\x9cwhat NOBBINGS?\xe2\x80\x9d _i.e._, how much have you\r\ngot or collected from the crowd? This term is much used by \xe2\x80\x9cbuskers.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n~Nobble~, to cheat, to overreach; to discover. In the racing world, to\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNOBBLE\xe2\x80\x9d a horse, is to \xe2\x80\x9cget at,\xe2\x80\x9d and lame or poison him.\r\n\r\n~Nobbler~, a blow on the NOB, a finishing stroke; \xe2\x80\x9cthat\xe2\x80\x99s a NOBBLER for\r\nhim,\xe2\x80\x9d _i.e._, a settler.\xe2\x80\x94_Pugilistic._\r\n\r\n~Nobbler~, a confederate of thimble-riggers and card-sharpers, who plays\r\nearnestly, as if a stranger to the \xe2\x80\x9crig,\xe2\x80\x9d and thus draws unsuspecting\r\npersons into a game. The same as a \xe2\x80\x9cbonnet\xe2\x80\x9d or \xe2\x80\x9cbearer-up.\xe2\x80\x9d In the North\r\nof England, a low, cunning lawyer.\r\n\r\n~Nobby~, or NOBBISH, fine or showy; NOBBILY, showily. _See_ SNOB for\r\nderivation.\r\n\r\n~No flies~, an emphatic addition made to an assertion for the purpose of\r\ngiving it weight. It really means \xe2\x80\x9cno error\xe2\x80\x9d or \xe2\x80\x9cno mistake.\xe2\x80\x9d Both of\r\nthem popular; as, \xe2\x80\x9cA jolly fine girl, and NO FLIES!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n~No-fly~, artful, designing. Term much used among printers, who shorten\r\nit to \xe2\x80\x9cN.F.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n~Noli-me-tangere~, the Scotch fiddle, or other contagious disease.\r\n\r\n~Non-com~, a non-commissioned officer in the army.\r\n\r\n~No odds~, no matter, of no consequence.\xe2\x80\x94_Latimer\xe2\x80\x99s Sermon before\r\nEdward VI._\r\n\r\n~Nooning~, an interval for rest and refreshment, taken at midday by\r\ntravellers in hot countries.\r\n\r\n~Norfolk-Howards~, bugs; a person named Ephraim Bug some few years back\r\nadvertised, that for the future he would call himself by the more\r\naristocratic appellation of NORFOLK HOWARD.\r\n\r\n~North~, cunning. The inhabitants of Yorkshire and the Northern counties\r\nare supposed, like the canny Scots, to get the better of other people in\r\ndealing; hence the phrase, \xe2\x80\x9cHe\xe2\x80\x99s too far NORTH for me,\xe2\x80\x9d _i.e._, too\r\ncunning for me to deal with.\r\n\r\n~North country compliment~, to give or offer anything that is not wanted\r\nby either giver or receiver is to pass a NORTH COUNTRY COMPLIMENT.\r\n\r\n~Norwicher~, more than one\xe2\x80\x99s share; said of a person who leaves less\r\nthan half the contents of a tankard for his companion. In what way the\r\nterm originated, or why Norwich was selected before any other city is\r\nnot known. Most likely from the slanders which the inhabitants of one\r\ntown are always inventing about their neighbours.\r\n\r\n~Nose~, a thief who turns informer; a paid spy; generally called a\r\npoliceman\xe2\x80\x99s NOSE; \xe2\x80\x9con the NOSE,\xe2\x80\x9d on the look-out.\r\n\r\n~Nose~, to give information to the police, to turn approver.\r\n\r\n~Nose~, \xe2\x80\x9cto pay through the NOSE,\xe2\x80\x9d to pay an extravagant price.\r\n\r\n~Nose-bag~, a visitor at a watering-place, or house of refreshment, who\r\ncarries his own victuals. Term applied by waiters.\r\n\r\n~Nose \xe2\x80\x99em~, or FOGUS, tobacco. NOSE \xe2\x80\x99EM is but a contraction of the\r\nrhyming slang, which _see_.\r\n\r\n~Nose-ender~, a straight blow delivered full on the nasal promontory.\r\n\r\n~Nose in the manger~, TO PUT ONE\xe2\x80\x99S, to sit down to eat. To \xe2\x80\x9cput on the\r\nnose-bag\xe2\x80\x9d is to eat hurriedly, or to eat while continuing at work.\r\n\r\n~Nose out of joint~, TO PUT ONE\xe2\x80\x99S; to supplant, supersede, or mortify a\r\nperson by excelling him.\r\n\r\n~Noser~, a hard blow, leading to a bloody or contused nose.\xe2\x80\x94_Pugilistic._\r\n\r\n~Notional~, imaginative, full of ideas. Used in America to express a\r\nwife\xe2\x80\x99s imaginations with regard to her husband\xe2\x80\x99s doings.\r\n\r\n~Nouse~, comprehension, perception.\xe2\x80\x94_Old_, apparently from the _Greek_,\r\n\xce\xbd\xce\xbf\xe1\xbf\xa6\xcf\x82. _Gaelic_ and _Irish_, NOS, knowledge, perception.\r\n\r\n~Nowhere~, horses not placed in a race\xe2\x80\x94that are neither first, second,\r\nnor third\xe2\x80\x94are said to be NOWHERE, especially when this lack of position\r\nhappens to favourites.\r\n\r\n~Number of his mess~, when a man dies in the army or navy, he is said to\r\n\xe2\x80\x9close the NUMBER OF HIS MESS.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n~Nurse~, a curious term applied to competition in omnibuses. Two\r\nomnibuses are placed on the road to NURSE, or take care of, each\r\nopposition \xe2\x80\x9cbus,\xe2\x80\x9d one before, the other behind. Of course the central or\r\nNURSED bus has very little chance, unless it happens to be a favourite\r\nwith the public. Recent legislation and tramways have done much to do\r\naway with NURSING. NURSE also means to cheat or swindle; trustees are\r\nsometimes said to NURSE property, _i.e._, gradually eat it up\r\nthemselves.\r\n\r\n~Nut~, the head, in pugilistic slang. Used as an exclamation at a fight,\r\nit means to strike on the head. In tossing it is a direction to hide the\r\nhead; to be \xe2\x80\x9coff one\xe2\x80\x99s NUT,\xe2\x80\x9d to be crazed or idiotic.\r\n\r\n~Nut-cut~, roguish, mischievous. A good-natured term of\r\nreproach.\xe2\x80\x94_Anglo-Indian._\r\n\r\n~Nuts~, to be NUTS on anything or person is to be pleased with or fond\r\nof it or him; a self-satisfied man is said to be NUTS on himself.\r\nNUTTED, taken in by a man who professed to be NUTS on you.\r\n\r\n~Nux~, the \xe2\x80\x9cplant,\xe2\x80\x9d or object in view. \xe2\x80\x9cStoll up to the NUX?\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9cDo you\r\nfully comprehend what is wanted?\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94_North Country Cant._\r\n\r\n~Oaf~, a lumbering, awkward fellow.\r\n\r\n~Oak~, the outer door of college rooms; to \xe2\x80\x9csport one\xe2\x80\x99s OAK,\xe2\x80\x9d to be \xe2\x80\x9cnot\r\nat home\xe2\x80\x9d to visitors. _See_ SPORT.\xe2\x80\x94_University._\r\n\r\n[Illustration: A \xe2\x80\x9cSporting Door,\xe2\x80\x9d or \xe2\x80\x9cOak.\xe2\x80\x9d]\r\n\r\n~Oar~, \xe2\x80\x9cto put in an OAR,\xe2\x80\x9d to interfere.\r\n\r\n    \xe2\x80\x9cI put my OAR in no man\xe2\x80\x99s boat.\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94_Thackeray._\r\n\r\n~Oat~, an atom. Probable corruption of iota, or perhaps from the small\r\nsize of an oat. \xe2\x80\x9cI never got an OAT of it,\xe2\x80\x9d I never received the\r\nsmallest portion.\r\n\r\n~Oat-stealer~, an ostler.\r\n\r\n~Obfuscated~, intoxicated.\r\n\r\n~Obliquitous~, oblivious of distinction between right and\r\nwrong.\xe2\x80\x94_American._\r\n\r\n~Obstropolous~, Cockney corruption of obstreperous.\r\n\r\n~Ochre~, money, generally applied to gold, for a very obvious reason.\r\n\r\n~O\xe2\x80\x99clock~, \xe2\x80\x9clike ONE O\xe2\x80\x99CLOCK,\xe2\x80\x9d a favourite comparison with the lower\r\norders, implying briskness; otherwise \xe2\x80\x9clike winkin\xe2\x80\x99.\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9cTo know what\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nO\xe2\x80\x99CLOCK\xe2\x80\x9d is to be wide-awake, sharp, and experienced.\r\n\r\n~Odd man out~, a street or public-house game at tossing. The number of\r\nplayers is three or more. Each tosses up a coin, and if two come down\r\nhead, and one comes tail, or _vice vers\xc3\xa2_, the ODD MAN loses or wins, as\r\nmay have been agreed upon. Frequently used to victimize a \xe2\x80\x9cflat.\xe2\x80\x9d If all\r\nbe alike, then the toss goes for nothing, and the coppers are again\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cskied.\xe2\x80\x9d It is easy for two men to arrange matters beforehand at this\r\ngame, and so swindle a third.\r\n\r\n~Odd man~, a man who trains in company with a boat\xe2\x80\x99s crew, so that in\r\nthe event of any one falling ill the seat will be fairly occupied.\r\n\r\n~Odds~, a phrase equivalent to \xe2\x80\x9cconsequence;\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9cwhat\xe2\x80\x99s the ODDS?\xe2\x80\x9d _i.e._,\r\nwhat is the expected result? \xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s no ODDS,\xe2\x80\x9d _i.e._, of no consequence.\r\nODDS, in sporting phraseology, refers to the proportions or differences\r\nof a bet. One bookmaker will lay ODDS of \xe2\x80\x9csix to one\xe2\x80\x9d against such a\r\nhorse winning; whilst another, more speculative, or in the receipt of a\r\nfirst-rate \xe2\x80\x9ctip\xe2\x80\x9d (information about the horse in question) will lay\r\n\xe2\x80\x9ceight,\xe2\x80\x9d or even \xe2\x80\x9cten to one.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n~Od rot it~ (_Colman\xe2\x80\x99s Broad Grins_), DRAT IT, OD\xe2\x80\x99S BLOOD, and all other\r\nexclamations commencing with OD, are nothing but softened or suppressed\r\noaths. OD is a corruption of GOD, and DRAT of ROT.\r\n\r\n~Off and on~, vacillating; \xe2\x80\x9can OFF AND ON kind of a chap,\xe2\x80\x9d one who is\r\nalways undecided.\r\n\r\n~Off at the head~, crazy.\xe2\x80\x94_Oxfordshire._\r\n\r\n~Off one\xe2\x80\x99s chump.~ To be crazy is to be OFF ONE\xe2\x80\x99S CHUMP; this is varied\r\nby the word CHUMPY. A mild kind of lunatic is also said to be \xe2\x80\x9coff his\r\nhead,\xe2\x80\x9d which means of course exactly the same as the first phrase.\r\n\r\n~Off one\xe2\x80\x99s feed.~ To be unable to eat is to be OFF ONE\xe2\x80\x99S FEED.\r\nOriginally stable slang.\r\n\r\n~Off the horn~, a term used in reference to very hard steak, which is\r\nfancifully said to be OFF THE HORN.\r\n\r\n~Office~, \xe2\x80\x9cto give the OFFICE,\xe2\x80\x9d to give a hint dishonestly to a\r\nconfederate, thereby enabling him to win a game or bet, the profits\r\nbeing shared. Also in sporting phraseology to give any information worth\r\nhaving.\r\n\r\n~Offish~, distant, not familiar. Corruption of STAND-OFFISH.\r\n\r\n~Ogle~, to look, or reconnoitre.\r\n\r\n~Ogles~, eyes.\xe2\x80\x94_Old Cant. French_, \xc5\x92IL.\r\n\r\n~Oil of palms~, or PALM OIL, money.\r\n\r\n~Ointment~, medical student slang for butter.\r\n\r\n~O. K.~, a matter to be O. K. (OLL KORRECT, _i.e._, all correct), must\r\nbe on the \xe2\x80\x9csquare,\xe2\x80\x9d and perfectly in order. This is an Americanism, and\r\nis derived from the initials O. K., said to have been marked on a\r\ndocument by an official to signify that all was right and proper.\r\n\r\n~Old boots~, a simile as general in its application as it is irrelevant.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLike OLD BOOTS\xe2\x80\x9d means like anything. \xe2\x80\x9cAs cheeky as OLD BOOTS;\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9cAs\r\nquick as OLD BOOTS,\xe2\x80\x9d seem a little more reasonable, new boots being\r\nsomewhat unfavourable to speedy locomotion.\r\n\r\n~Old dog~, a knowing blade, an experienced person. Butler uses the\r\nphrase, _Hudibras_, part ii. canto iii. 208, where it was said of\r\nSidrophel, \xe2\x80\x9cAnd was OLD DOG at physiology.\xe2\x80\x9d An Irish proverb says, \xe2\x80\x9cOLD\r\nDOG for hard road,\xe2\x80\x9d meaning that it requires an experienced person to\r\nexecute a difficult undertaking.\r\n\r\n~Old gentleman~, the devil. Also a card almost imperceptibly longer than\r\nthe rest of the pack, used by sharpers for the purpose of cheating.\r\n\r\n~Old gooseberry~ (_see_ GOOSEBERRY), OLD HARRY (_Old Hairy_), OLD\r\nSCRATCH, all synonyms for the devil.\r\n\r\n~Old gown~, smuggled tea.\r\n\r\n~Old horse~, salt junk, or beef.\xe2\x80\x94_Sea._\r\n\r\n~Old hoss~, a term of endearment, originally an Americanism, but now in\r\ncommon use here among friends.\r\n\r\n~Old Lady in Threadneedle Street~, the Bank of England.\r\n\r\n~Old man~, in American merchant ships, the master. The phrase is\r\nbecoming common in English ships.\r\n\r\n~Old salt~, a thorough sailor.\r\n\r\n~Old Tom~, extra strong gin; sometimes termed CAT\xe2\x80\x99S WATER. Various\r\nreasons are given for the use of the words OLD TOM. The distillers have\r\nthe sign of a tom cat on their illuminated placards. The origin of the\r\nphrase is, however, in the fact that the managing clerk of a once\r\ncelebrated \xe2\x80\x9cgin-spinning\xe2\x80\x9d firm, who was known as OLD TOM, used to keep a\r\nspecial bottle of extra good stuff with which to regale customers when\r\nthey settled their accounts. To get a drink of OLD TOM\xe2\x80\x99S was then a\r\ngreat favour. Gradually the title became popular as representing very\r\ngood strong gin.\r\n\r\n~Oliver~, the moon; \xe2\x80\x9cOLIVER don\xe2\x80\x99t widdle,\xe2\x80\x9d _i.e._, the moon does not\r\nshine. _Nearly obsolete._\r\n\r\n~Ollapod~, a country apothecary. From George Coleman\xe2\x80\x99s comedy of _The\r\nPoor Gentleman_.\r\n\r\n~Omee~, a master or landlord; \xe2\x80\x9cthe OMEE of the carsey\xe2\x80\x99s a nark on the\r\npitch,\xe2\x80\x9d the master of the house will not let us perform. _Italian_,\r\nUOMO, a man; \xe2\x80\x9cUOMO DELLA CASA,\xe2\x80\x9d the master of the house. _Latin_,\r\nHOMO.\xe2\x80\x94_Lingua Franca._\r\n\r\n~Omnium gatherum~, an indiscriminate collection of articles; a numerous\r\nand by no means select assemblage.\r\n\r\n~On~, \xe2\x80\x9cto be ON,\xe2\x80\x9d in public-house or vulgar parlance, is synonymous with\r\ngetting \xe2\x80\x9ctight\xe2\x80\x9d or tipsy; \xe2\x80\x9cit\xe2\x80\x99s St. Monday with him, I see he\xe2\x80\x99s ON\r\nagain,\xe2\x80\x9d _i.e._, drunk as usual, or on the road to it. \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m ON\xe2\x80\x9d also\r\nexpresses a person\xe2\x80\x99s acceptance of an offered bet. To GET ON a horse or\r\na man is to make bets on it or him. \xe2\x80\x9cTry it ON,\xe2\x80\x9d a defiant challenge to\r\na person.\r\n\r\n~On the fly~, getting one\xe2\x80\x99s living by thieving or other illegitimate\r\nmeans; the phrase is applied to men the same as \xe2\x80\x9con the loose\xe2\x80\x9d is to\r\nwomen. ON THE FLY also means on the drink.\r\n\r\n~On the loose~, obtaining a living by prostitution; in reality, on the\r\nstreets. The term is applied to females only, excepting in the case of\r\n\xe2\x80\x9csprees,\xe2\x80\x9d when men carousing are sometimes said to be ON THE LOOSE.\r\n\r\n~On the nose~, on the watch or look-out. _See_ NOSE.\r\n\r\n~On the shelf~, transported. With old maids it has another and very\r\ndifferent meaning.\r\n\r\n~On the tiles~, out all night \xe2\x80\x9con the spree,\xe2\x80\x9d or carousing,\xe2\x80\x94in allusion\r\nto the London cats on their amatory excursions. _See_ CATERWAULING.\r\n\r\n~One-er~, that which stands for ONE, a blow that requires no repeating.\r\nIn _The Old Curiosity Shop_, the \xe2\x80\x9cMarchioness\xe2\x80\x9d tells Dick Swiveller that\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cher missus is a ONE-ER\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94there a variation of \xe2\x80\x9cstunner.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n~One in ten~, a parson. In allusion to the tithing system.\r\n\r\n~Onion~, a watch-seal.\r\n\r\n~O. P.~ Publishers\xe2\x80\x99 reply to an inquiry for a book or paper that is OUT\r\nOF PRINT.\r\n\r\n~Open the ball~, to commence anything.\r\n\r\n~Oracle~, \xe2\x80\x9cto work the ORACLE,\xe2\x80\x9d to plan, man\xc5\x93uvre, to succeed by a wily\r\nstratagem.\r\n\r\n~Orate~, an Americanism, which means, to speak in public, or make an\r\noration.\r\n\r\n~Organ-grinder~, an itinerant who is supposed to \xe2\x80\x9cGRIND\xe2\x80\x9d music out of a\r\nbarrel-organ.\r\n\r\n~Originator~, an inventor of plans for the formation of joint-stock\r\ncompanies. The originator submits his schemes to the promoter, who\r\naccepts or rejects them.\r\n\r\n~Otter~, eightpence. _Italian_, OTTO, eight.\xe2\x80\x94_Lingua Franca._\r\n\r\n~Ottomy~, a thin man, a skeleton, a dwarf. Vulgar pronunciation of\r\nANATOMY. Shakspeare has ATOMY.\r\n\r\n~Out~, a dram glass. These glasses are two-OUT (half-quartern),\r\nthree-OUT, and four-OUT. An _habitu\xc3\xa9_ of a gin-shop, desirous of\r\ntreating a brace of friends, calls for \xe2\x80\x9ca quartern of gin and three\r\nOUTS,\xe2\x80\x9d by which he means three glasses which will exactly contain the\r\nquartern. Really, the word glasses is understood. The man actually\r\nmeans, and one or more three-OUT glasses.\r\n\r\n~Out~, in round games, where several play, and there can be but one\r\nloser, the winners in succession STAND OUT, while the others PLAY OFF.\r\n\r\n~Out and out~, prime, excellent, of the first quality; beyond measure.\r\nOUT-AND-OUTER, one who is of an OUT-AND-OUT description, \xe2\x80\x9cup\xe2\x80\x9d to\r\nanything.\r\n\r\nAn ancient MS. has this couplet, which shows the antiquity of the\r\nphrase:\xe2\x80\x94\r\n\r\n    \xe2\x80\x9cThe Kyng was good alle aboute,\r\n    And she was wycked OUTE AND OUTE.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n~Outcry~, an auction.\xe2\x80\x94_Anglo-Indian._\r\n\r\n~Outing~, a day\xe2\x80\x99s holiday. The Oxford and Cambridge boatrace, the Derby,\r\nand other events of a like character, are each said to be simply excuses\r\nto the Cockneys for a day\xe2\x80\x99s OUTING.\r\n\r\n~Out of collar~, out of place,\xe2\x80\x94in allusion to servants. When in place,\r\nthe term is IN COLLAR. Most likely from \xe2\x80\x9chead in the COLLAR,\xe2\x80\x9d said of\r\nhorses when hard at work.\r\n\r\n~Out on the loose~, \xe2\x80\x9con the spree,\xe2\x80\x9d in search of adventures. _See_ ON\r\nTHE LOOSE.\r\n\r\n~Out on the pickaroon.~ PICARONE is Spanish for a thief, but this phrase\r\ndoes not necessarily mean anything dishonest, but is often used to mean\r\nreadiness for anything in the way of excitement. It also means to be in\r\nsearch of anything profitable, without much care as to honesty or\r\notherwise.\r\n\r\n~Outsider~, a person who does not habitually bet, or is not admitted to\r\nthe \xe2\x80\x9cring,\xe2\x80\x9d a duffer or good-for-nothing fellow. Also, a horse whose\r\nname does not appear among the \xe2\x80\x9cfavourites.\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94_Sporting._\r\n\r\n~Over!~ or OVER THE LEFT, _i.e._, the left shoulder\xe2\x80\x94a common\r\nexclamation of disbelief in what is being narrated,\xe2\x80\x94sometimes implying\r\nthat the results of a proposed plan will be OVER THE LEFT, _i.e._, in\r\nthe wrong direction, loss instead of gain.\r\n\r\n~Over~, generally used in connexion with come, as, \xe2\x80\x9cHe came it rather\r\nstrong OVER me,\xe2\x80\x9d _i.e._, tried to intimidate or compel me. The same\r\nphrase would also be used to imply that an excess of flattery or praise\r\nwas being employed for a similar purpose, but that the adulation was\r\nbeing \xe2\x80\x9claid on a little too thick\xe2\x80\x9d to be considered genuine. Also used\r\nthus sometimes: \xe2\x80\x9cYou mustn\xe2\x80\x99t come Shakspeare OVER me,\xe2\x80\x9d _i.e._, \xe2\x80\x9cyou\r\nmustn\xe2\x80\x99t assume an air of immeasurable literary superiority OVER me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou mustn\xe2\x80\x99t come Rothschild OVER me,\xe2\x80\x9d &c.\r\n\r\n~Over~, in cricket, four balls delivered from one end to another. After\r\nan OVER has been bowled, the fielders, wicket-keepers, &c., change ends,\r\nand the bowling goes on from the recent batting wicket. A MAIDEN-OVER is\r\nan OVER from which no runs are obtained. Four balls is the regulation\r\nnumber to an OVER in all important matches; but little clubs and\r\npractice elevens suit their own convenience.\r\n\r\n~Overs~, the odd money remaining after the daily accounts are made up at\r\na banking-house,\xe2\x80\x94usually divided amongst the clerks. _See_ MENAVELINGS\r\nand SHORTS.\r\n\r\n~Owned~, a slang expression used by the ultra-Evangelicals when a\r\npopular preacher makes many converts. The converts themselves are called\r\nhis \xe2\x80\x9cseals.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n~P. P.~, an expression much in use among racing men, which means play or\r\npay, _i.e._, either go on with the arrangement or forfeit the money. The\r\nfollowing is a law of the turf on the subject:\xe2\x80\x94\r\n\r\n    The following races shall be considered \xe2\x80\x9cplay or pay\xe2\x80\x9d:\xe2\x80\x94The Derby\r\n    and Oaks at Epsom, the St. Leger at Doncaster, the Two Thousand\r\n    Guineas, the One Thousand Guineas, the Cesarewitch and\r\n    Cambridgeshire, at Newmarket, the Ascot, Goodwood, and Doncaster\r\n    Cups, and all handicaps above 200 sovs. value with two forfeits, the\r\n    minor of which shall not be less than 5 sovs.; and the Committees of\r\n    Tattersall\xe2\x80\x99s, and of the Subscription Room at Newmarket, will take\r\n    no cognisance of any disputes respecting \xe2\x80\x9cplay or pay\xe2\x80\x9d bets on any\r\n    other races, or of any bets made upon handicap races before the\r\n    weights are published.\r\n\r\nThis is the exact law on the subject, but as a rule all bets on\r\nhorse-racing are considered P. P. unless otherwise arranged. In all\r\nmatches, though, whether turf, pedestrian, aquatic, or otherwise, a run\r\nis given for the money in ordinary betting transactions.\r\n\r\n~P\xe2\x80\x99s and q\xe2\x80\x99s~, particular points, precise behaviour; \xe2\x80\x9cmind your P\xe2\x80\x99S and\r\nQ\xe2\x80\x99S,\xe2\x80\x9d be very careful. Originating, according to some, from the\r\nsimilarity of P\xe2\x80\x99S and Q\xe2\x80\x99S in the hornbook alphabet, and therefore the\r\nwarning of an old dame to her pupils, or, according to others, of a\r\nFrench dancing-master to his pupils, to mind their _pieds_ (feet) and\r\n_queues_ (wigs) when bowing.\r\n\r\n~Pack~, to go away; \xe2\x80\x9cnow, then, PACK off there,\xe2\x80\x9d _i.e._, be off, don\xe2\x80\x99t\r\nstop here any longer.\xe2\x80\x94_Old._ \xe2\x80\x9cMake speede to flee, be PACKING\r\nawaie.\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94_Baret\xe2\x80\x99s Alvearie_, 1580. Contraction of \xe2\x80\x9cPACK up and be off.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nSometimes the term \xe2\x80\x9csent PACKING\xe2\x80\x9d is used to indicate a sudden\r\ndischarge, as of a servant or mistress.\r\n\r\n~Packets~, hoaxing lies. Sometimes used as an exclamation of\r\nincredulity.\xe2\x80\x94_North._\r\n\r\n~Pad~, \xe2\x80\x9cto stand PAD,\xe2\x80\x9d to beg with a small piece of paper pinned on the\r\nbreast, inscribed, \xe2\x80\x9cI am starving.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n~Pad~, the highway; also a tramp or itinerant musician.\r\n\r\n~Pad the hoof~, to walk; \xe2\x80\x9cPADDING THE HOOF, on the high toby,\xe2\x80\x9d tramping\r\nor walking on the high road.\r\n\r\n    \xe2\x80\x9cTrudge, plod away o\xe2\x80\x99 the HOOF.\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94_Merry Wives_, i. 3.\r\n\r\n~Padding~, the light articles in the monthly magazines, of which the\r\nserial stories are the main attraction. Publishers of magazines seem to\r\nthink that if they get a serial story from a popular novelist they can\r\npack any amount of rubbish into the remaining pages. This is not so in\r\nAmerica, as magazines like the _Atlantic Monthly_ and the _Overland\r\nMonthly_ show.\r\n\r\n~Padding-ken~, or CRIB, tramps\xe2\x80\x99 and boys\xe2\x80\x99 lodging-house.\r\n\r\n~Paddle~, to go or run away.\xe2\x80\x94_American._\r\n\r\n~Paddy~, PAT, or PADDY WHACK, an Irishman. A nickname of PATRICK.\r\n\r\n    \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m PADDY WHACK, from Ballyhack,\r\n      Not long ago turn\xe2\x80\x99d soldier;\r\n    In storm and sack, in front attack,\r\n      None other can be boulder.\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94_Irish Song._\r\n\r\n~Paddy\xe2\x80\x99s goose~, the sign of the White Swan, a noted flash public-house\r\nin the east of London, supposed to be Paddy\xe2\x80\x99s idea of a GOOSE.\r\n\r\n~Paddy\xe2\x80\x99s land~, \xe2\x80\x9could Ireland.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n~Padre~, a clergyman. From the Portuguese.\r\n\r\n~Pal~, a partner, acquaintance, friend, an accomplice. _Gipsy_, a\r\nbrother.\r\n\r\n~Palampo~, a quilt or bed-cover. Probably from PALANPORE, a town in\r\nIndia, renowned for its manufacture of chintz\r\ncounterpanes.\xe2\x80\x94_Anglo-Indian._\r\n\r\n~Palaver~, to ask, or talk\xe2\x80\x94deceitfully or otherwise, as occasion\r\nrequires; \xe2\x80\x9cPALAVER to his nibs for a shant of bivvy,\xe2\x80\x9d ask the master for\r\na pot of beer. NANTEE PALAVER (pronounced PERLARVER), cease talking. In\r\nthis sense used by tramps. Derived from the Portuguese.\r\n\r\n~Pall~, to stop; \xe2\x80\x9cPALL that,\xe2\x80\x9d spoken authoritatively, means, cease what\r\nyou are doing. From PALL, a small instrument which is used to stop the\r\nwindlass or capstan at sea. When a man says, \xe2\x80\x9cI am PALLED,\xe2\x80\x9d he\r\nmeans he cannot or dare not say any more. A sailor, on receiving any\r\nextraordinary intelligence, will say, \xe2\x80\x9cYou PALL me,\xe2\x80\x9d _i.e._, you\r\nconfound me. Most likely from the order frequently given on board ship,\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cEase and PALL.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n~Palm~, to impose upon. \xe2\x80\x9cYou can\xe2\x80\x99t PALM that off upon me,\xe2\x80\x9d is said when\r\nan intending purchaser is suspicious of the quality of the article\r\noffered.\r\n\r\n~Palm oil~, or PALM SOAP, money; also, a bribe.\r\n\r\n~Palmer~, a swindler who used to visit shops under the pretence of\r\ncollecting harp halfpence. To induce shopkeepers to search for them, he\r\noffered thirteenpence for one shilling\xe2\x80\x99s-worth, when many persons were\r\nsilly enough to empty a large quantity of copper on their counters. The\r\nPALMER, a proficient with his fingers, generally contrived to conceal\r\nsome before he left the shop.\r\n\r\n~Palming~, robbing shops by pairs\xe2\x80\x94one thief bargaining with apparent\r\nintent to purchase, whilst the other watches his opportunity to steal.\r\nThe following anecdote will give an idea of their _modus operandi_. A\r\nman once entered a \xe2\x80\x9cready-made\xe2\x80\x9d boot and shoe shop, and desired to be\r\nshown a pair of boots\xe2\x80\x94his companion staying outside and amusing himself\r\nby looking in at the window. The one who required to be fresh shod was\r\napparently of a humble and deferential turn, for he placed his hat on\r\nthe floor directly he stepped into the shop. Boot after boot was tried\r\non until at last a fit was obtained, when in rushed a man, snatched up\r\nthe customer\xe2\x80\x99s hat left near the door, and ran down the street as fast\r\nas his legs could carry him. Away went the customer after his hat, and\r\nCrispin, standing at the door, clapped his hands, and shouted, \xe2\x80\x9cGo it,\r\nyou\xe2\x80\x99ll catch him!\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94little thinking that it was a concerted trick, and\r\nthat neither his boots nor the customer would ever return. Instances of\r\nthis kind of work frequently occur. PALMING sometimes refers to\r\nsecreting money or rings in the hand, as well as to bribing. PALMING is\r\nalso the generic term for all that kind of conjuring which depends on\r\nmanual dexterity, and which is totally distinct from the\r\nmechanical-contrivance department.\r\n\r\n~Pam~, the knave of clubs at the game of loo; or, in street phraseology,\r\nwhile the \xe2\x80\x9cJudicious Bottleholder\xe2\x80\x9d was alive, Lord Palmerston.\r\n\r\n~Pannikin~, a small pan.\r\n\r\n~Pannum~, food, bread.\xe2\x80\x94_Lingua Franca_, PANNEN; _Latin_, PANIS;\r\n_Ancient Cant_, YANNAM.\r\n\r\n~Pannum-bound~, said of a pauper or prisoner when his food is stopped.\r\nPANNUM-STRUCK, very hungry, starving.\r\n\r\n~Panny~, a house\xe2\x80\x94public or otherwise; \xe2\x80\x9cflash PANNY,\xe2\x80\x9d a public-house\r\nused by thieves; PANNY-MEN, housebreakers. PANNY, in thieves\xe2\x80\x99 cant, also\r\nsignifies a burglary.\r\n\r\n~Pantalettes~, the drawers worn in America by little girls.\r\n\r\n~Pantile~, a hat. The term PANTILE is properly applied to the mould into\r\nwhich the sugar is poured which is afterwards known as \xe2\x80\x9cloaf sugar.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nThus, PANTILE, from whence comes the phrase, \xe2\x80\x9ca sugar-loaf hat,\xe2\x80\x9d\r\noriginally signified a tall, conical hat, in shape similar to that\r\nusually represented as the head-gear of a bandit. From PANTILE the more\r\nmodern slang term TILE has been derived. Halliwell gives PANTILE SHOP, a\r\nmeeting-house, from the steeple-crowned or PANTILE hats of its\r\nfrequenters. PANTILE also means a flat cake with jam on it, given to\r\nboys at boarding-schools instead of pudding.\r\n\r\n~Pantiler~, a Dissenting preacher. Probably from the practice of the\r\nQuakers, and many Dissenters, of not removing their hats in a place of\r\nworship; or from the sugar-loaf hats originally worn by Puritans.\r\nAnother derivation is from the earthen tiles, technically PANTILES\r\n(tiles hollowed in the middle, as distinguished from \xe2\x80\x9cpintiles,\xe2\x80\x9d the\r\nolder sort, which are flat, smaller, and pinned or nailed to the\r\nrafters), with which meeting-houses of Dissenters are usually covered;\r\nhence the meeting-house came to be called a PANTILE, and its frequenters\r\nPANTILERS.\r\n\r\n~Pants~, American term for trousers. Here used to represent the long\r\ndrawers worn underneath.\r\n\r\n~Panupetaston~, a loose overcoat with wide sleeves, now out of\r\nfashion.\xe2\x80\x94_Oxford University._\r\n\r\n~Paper-maker~, a rag-gatherer, or gutter-raker\xe2\x80\x94similar to the\r\nchiffonnier of Paris. Also, a man who tramps through the country, and\r\ncollects rags on the pretence that he is an agent to a paper mill.\r\n\r\n~Paper-Worker~, a wandering vendor of street literature; one who sells\r\nballads, dying speeches, and confessions, sometimes termed a \xe2\x80\x9crunning\r\nstationer.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n~Parachute~, a parasol.\r\n\r\n~Paradise~, French slang for the gallery of a theatre, \xe2\x80\x9cup amongst the\r\nGODS,\xe2\x80\x9d which _see_.\r\n\r\n~Parish lantern~, the moon.\r\n\r\n~Parish prig~, or PARISH BULL, a parson.\xe2\x80\x94_Thieves\xe2\x80\x99 cant._\r\n\r\n~Parney~, rain; \xe2\x80\x9cdowry of PARNEY,\xe2\x80\x9d a quantity of rain. _Anglo-Indian_\r\nslang from the _Hindoo_, PANI, water; _Gipsy_, PANE. Old Indian officers\r\nalways call brandy-and-water \xe2\x80\x9cbrandy PAWNEE.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n~Parson~, a signpost. Common term in the north, where they say that the\r\nPARSON points, but does not lead. This is given, as the lawyers say,\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cwithout prejudice.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n~Parson Trulliber~, a rude, vulgar, country clergyman, devoted to\r\nagricultural pursuits; the race is most probably now extinct. From the\r\npig-feeding and pig-headed parson in _Joseph Andrews_.\r\n\r\n~Parson\xe2\x80\x99s nose~, the hind part of a goose\xe2\x80\x94a savoury mouthful. Sometimes\r\ncalled the POPE\xe2\x80\x99S NOSE.\r\n\r\n~Part~, to pay, restore, or give up; \xe2\x80\x9che\xe2\x80\x99s a right un, he is; I know\xe2\x80\x99d\r\nhe\xe2\x80\x99d PART,\xe2\x80\x9d _i.e._, he is a liberal (or punctual) person, and pays his\r\ndebts, or bestows gratuities. The term is in general use in sporting\r\ncircles, and is very commonly employed when speaking of the settlement\r\nof bets after a race. It is probably derived from the very common\r\nreference to stingy people, who are described as not liking to PART with\r\ntheir money.\r\n\r\n~Parter~, a free, liberal person. Sometimes called a \xe2\x80\x9cgood PARTER.\xe2\x80\x9d Any\r\none who looks twice at his money, or who doesn\xe2\x80\x99t pay it at all, is\r\ncalled a \xe2\x80\x9cbad PARTER.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n~Party~, a person\xe2\x80\x94term in very general use, similar in application to\r\nthe German pronoun, MAN, a person, people; \xe2\x80\x9cwhere\xe2\x80\x99s the PARTY as \xe2\x80\x99ad a\xe2\x80\x99\r\norter be lookin\xe2\x80\x99 after this \xe2\x80\x99ere \xe2\x80\x99oss?\xe2\x80\x9d policeman\xe2\x80\x99s inquiry of the wrong\r\ncabman; \xe2\x80\x9cold PARTY,\xe2\x80\x9d an elderly person. The term is said to have arisen\r\nin our old justice courts, where, to save \xe2\x80\x9chis worship\xe2\x80\x9d and the clerk of\r\nthe court any trouble in exercising their memories with the names of the\r\ndifferent plaintiffs, defendants, and witnesses, the word PARTY was\r\ngenerally employed. Dean Alford remarked:\xe2\x80\x94\r\n\r\n    \xe2\x80\x9cThe word PARTY for a man is especially offensive. Strange to say,\r\n    the use is not altogether modern. It occurs in the English version\r\n    of the Apocryphal book of Tobit, vi. 7. \xe2\x80\x98If an evil spirit trouble\r\n    any, one must make a smoke thereof before the man or the woman, and\r\n    the PARTY shall be no more vexed.\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nIn Shakspeare we find the term:\xe2\x80\x94\r\n\r\n    \xe2\x80\x9c_Stephano._ How now shall this be compassed? Canst thou bring me to\r\n    the PARTY?\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94_Tempest_, iii. 2.\r\n\r\nThis is not the only instance of the word being used by the immortal\r\nbard. \xe2\x80\x9cI once heard,\xe2\x80\x9d said the Dean just quoted, \xe2\x80\x9ca venerable dignitary\r\npointed out by a railway porter as an old PARTY in a shovel.\xe2\x80\x9d The last\r\nword is the vulgar term applied to the peculiar hat worn by clerical\r\ndignitaries.\r\n\r\n~Pash~, to strike; now corrupted to BASH, which _see_.\xe2\x80\x94_Shakspeare._\r\n\r\n~Paste~, to beat, to thrash vigorously.\r\n\r\n~Pasteboard~, a visiting card; \xe2\x80\x9cto PASTEBOARD a person,\xe2\x80\x9d to drop a card\r\nat an absent person\xe2\x80\x99s house.\r\n\r\n~Paste-horn~, the nose. Shoemakers nickname any shopmate with a large\r\nnose \xe2\x80\x9cold PASTE-HORN,\xe2\x80\x9d from the shape of the horn in which they keep\r\ntheir paste.\r\n\r\n~Pasty~, a bookbinder.\r\n\r\n~Patch.~ This old English term of reproach, long obsolete in polite\r\nlanguage, may yet occasionally be heard in sentences like these:\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cWhy,\r\nhe\xe2\x80\x99s not a PATCH upon him,\xe2\x80\x9d _i.e._, he is not to be compared with him;\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cone\xe2\x80\x99s not a PATCH on the other,\xe2\x80\x9d &c. Shakspeare uses the word in the\r\nsense of a paltry fellow:\xe2\x80\x94\r\n\r\n    \xe2\x80\x9cWhat a pied ninny\xe2\x80\x99s this? thou scurvy PATCH!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nIn old English PATCH meant a fool, a wearer of patched clothes of\r\nmotley.\r\n\r\n~Patent coats~, the first coat, with the pockets inside the skirt, were\r\nso termed.\r\n\r\n~Patter~, a speech or discourse, a pompous street oration, a judge\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nsumming up, a trial. Ancient word for muttering. Probably from the\r\n_Latin_, PATERNOSTER, or Lord\xe2\x80\x99s Prayer. This was said, before the\r\nReformation, in a \xe2\x80\x9clow voice\xe2\x80\x9d by the priest, until he came to \xe2\x80\x9cand lead\r\nus not into temptation,\xe2\x80\x9d to which the choir responded, \xe2\x80\x9cbut deliver us\r\nfrom evil.\xe2\x80\x9d In the reformed Prayer Book this was altered, and the Lord\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nPrayer directed to be said \xe2\x80\x9cwith a _loud voice_.\xe2\x80\x9d Dr. Pusey takes this\r\nview of the derivation in his _Letter to the Bishop of London_, p. 78,\r\n1851. Scott uses the word twice, in _Ivanhoe_ and the _Bride of\r\nLammermoor_.\r\n\r\n~Patter~, to talk. PATTER FLASH, to speak the language of thieves, talk\r\ncant.\r\n\r\n~Patteran~, a gipsy trail, made by throwing down a handful of grass\r\noccasionally, especially where they have turned off from the main road.\r\n\r\n~Patter-crib~, a flash house.\r\n\r\n~Patterer~, one of a race now nearly defunct, who cried last dying\r\nspeeches, &c., in the streets. The term is also applied to those who\r\nhelp off their wares by long harangues in the public thoroughfares.\r\nThese men, to use their own term, \xe2\x80\x9care the aristocracy of the street\r\nsellers,\xe2\x80\x9d and despise the costermongers for their ignorance, boasting\r\nthat they live by their intellect, which, as they do not live\r\nwonderfully well, is no particularly wise boast.\r\n\r\n~Pattern~, a common vulgar phrase for \xe2\x80\x9cpatent.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n~Paul Pry~, an inquisitive person. From the well-known comedy.\r\n\r\n~Paw~, the hand. PAW-CASES, gloves. Boots are in some parts of Ireland\r\ncalled \xe2\x80\x9cgloves for the feet.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n~Pay~, to beat a person, or \xe2\x80\x9cserve him out.\xe2\x80\x9d Originally a nautical term,\r\nmeaning to stop the seams of a vessel with pitch (_French_, POIX);\r\n\xe2\x80\x9chere\xe2\x80\x99s the d\xe2\x80\x91\xe2\x80\x91\xe2\x80\x91\xe2\x80\x91l to PAY, and no pitch hot,\xe2\x80\x9d said when any catastrophe\r\noccurs which there is no means of averting; \xe2\x80\x9cto PAY over face and eyes,\r\nas the cat did the monkey;\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9cto PAY through the nose,\xe2\x80\x9d to give a\r\nridiculous price,\xe2\x80\x94an expressive phrase of which no one seems to know\r\nthe origin. Shakspeare uses PAY in the sense of to beat or thrash.\r\n\r\n~Pay~, to deliver. \xe2\x80\x9cPAY that letter to Mr. So-and-so\xe2\x80\x9d is a very common\r\ndirection to a Chinese servant.\xe2\x80\x94_Anglo-Chinese._\r\n\r\n~Pay-away~, \xe2\x80\x9cgo on with your story, or discourse.\xe2\x80\x9d From the nautical\r\nphrase PAY-AWAY, meaning to allow a rope to run out of a vessel. When\r\nthe hearer considers the story quite long enough, he, carrying out the\r\nsame metaphor, exclaims \xe2\x80\x9chold on.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n~Peach~, an informer against omnibus conductors and drivers, one\r\nespecially hired by the proprietors to count passengers and stoppages.\r\nThe term is in frequent use amongst omnibus-men. This is about the only\r\ninstance known of the verb being used as a substantive.\r\n\r\n~Peach~, to inform against or betray. Webster states that the word\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cimpeach\xe2\x80\x9d is now mostly used, and that PEACH is confined principally to\r\nthe conversation of thieves and the lower orders. The word was\r\noriginally \xe2\x80\x9cimpeach,\xe2\x80\x9d though it was never until lately used in the same\r\nway as its abridgment.\r\n\r\n~Peacock horse~, amongst undertakers, is one with a showy tail and mane,\r\nwhich holds its head up well. PEACOCKY refers to an objectionable high\r\naction among racehorses.\r\n\r\n~Peaking~, remnants of cloth. Term amongst drapers and cloth\r\nwarehousemen.\r\n\r\n~Peaky~, sickly, delicate.\r\n\r\n~Pec~, a term used by the Eton boys for money, an abbreviation, of\r\ncourse, of the _Latin_ PECUNIA.\r\n\r\n~Peck~, food; \xe2\x80\x9cPECK and boose,\xe2\x80\x9d meat and drink.\xe2\x80\x94_Lincolnshire._\r\n_Ancient Cant_, PEK, meat.\r\n\r\n~Peck~, to eat voraciously. A hearty eater is generally called \xe2\x80\x9ca rare\r\nPECKER.\xe2\x80\x9d Originally PECK was to eat delicately, \xe2\x80\x9cbut we have changed all\r\nthat now.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n~Peck-alley~, the throat.\r\n\r\n~Pecker~, \xe2\x80\x9ckeep your PECKER up,\xe2\x80\x9d _i.e._, don\xe2\x80\x99t get down in the\r\nmouth,\xe2\x80\x94literally, keep your beak or head well up, \xe2\x80\x9cnever say die!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n~Peckham~, a facetious usage of the name of this district, implying a\r\ndinner; \xe2\x80\x9call holiday at PECKHAM,\xe2\x80\x9d _i.e._, nothing to eat.\r\n\r\n~Peckish~, hungry. _Old Cant_, PECKIDGE, meat.\r\n\r\n~Peel~, to strip, or disrobe.\xe2\x80\x94_Sporting._\r\n\r\n~Peeler~, a policeman; so called from Sir Robert Peel (_see_ BOBBY);\r\nproperly applied to the Irish Constabulary rather than the Metropolitan\r\nPolice, the former force having been established by Sir Robert Peel.\r\n\r\n~Peepers~, eyes; \xe2\x80\x9cpainted PEEPERS,\xe2\x80\x9d eyes bruised or blackened from a\r\nblow.\xe2\x80\x94_Pugilistic._\r\n\r\n~Peery~, suspicious, or inquisitive.\r\n\r\n~Peg~, brandy and soda-water. A PEG by which to pull oneself up again.\r\nAlso, a shilling.\xe2\x80\x94_Scotch._\r\n\r\n~Peg~, \xe2\x80\x9cto PEG away,\xe2\x80\x9d to strike, run, or drive away; \xe2\x80\x9cPEG a hack,\xe2\x80\x9d to\r\ndrive a cab; \xe2\x80\x9cto take him down a PEG or two,\xe2\x80\x9d to check an arrogant or\r\nconceited person,\xe2\x80\x94possibly derived from the use of PEG tankards. _See_\r\nPIN.\r\n\r\n~Peg~, to drink frequently; generally used in reference to devotees of\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cS. and B.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n~Peggers~, people who constantly stimulate themselves by means of brandy\r\nand soda-water.\r\n\r\n~Pegtops~, the loose trousers in fashion some years back, small at the\r\nankle and swelling upwards, in imitation of the Zouave costume.\r\n\r\n~Penang-lawyer~, a long cane, sometimes carried by a footman.\r\nPENANG-LAWYERS are also bludgeons which are carried by all classes in\r\nSingapore.\r\n\r\n~Pencil-fever~, a supposititious disease among racehorses, the\r\npreliminary symptoms of which show that an animal has been pretty\r\nconsiderably \xe2\x80\x9cmilked.\xe2\x80\x9d PENCIL-FEVER sets in when, despite the efforts of\r\nthe \xe2\x80\x9cmarketeers,\xe2\x80\x9d a horse can no longer be kept at a short price in the\r\nlists, through his actual condition being discovered, and when every\r\nlayer of odds is anxious to write his name down. This disorder is also\r\ncalled \xe2\x80\x9cmilk-fever,\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9cmarket-fever,\xe2\x80\x9d and other suggestive names.\r\n\r\n~Penny-a-liner~, a contributor of local news, accidents, fires, and\r\nscandals to a newspaper; a man not regularly \xe2\x80\x9con the paper;\xe2\x80\x9d one who is\r\npopularly believed to be paid for each contribution at the rate of a\r\npenny a line, and whose interest is, therefore, that his articles should\r\nbe stuffed with fine words and long sentences. This wonderful person, to\r\nwhom so much is daily attributed, is now generally called a LINER.\r\n\r\n~Penny dreadfuls~, an expressive term for those penny publications which\r\ndepend more upon sensationalism than upon merit, artistic or literary,\r\nfor success.\r\n\r\n~Penny gaff~, a shop turned into a temporary theatre (admission one\r\npenny), at which dancing and singing take place every night. Sometimes\r\nrude pictures of the performers are arranged outside to give the front a\r\ngaudy and attractive look, and at night-time coloured lamps and\r\ntransparencies are displayed to draw an audience. Zest is given to these\r\nentertainments by the fact that now and again the police make raids upon\r\nthe houses, and carry off both actors and spectators. These places are\r\nalso called \xe2\x80\x9cdukeys,\xe2\x80\x9d for no reason that can be discovered. _See_ GAFF.\r\n\r\n~Penny starver~, a penny roll. _See_ BUSTER.\r\n\r\n~Pen\xe2\x80\x99orth~, value for money; as, \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ll have my PEN\xe2\x80\x99ORTH,\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94given\r\nirrespective of the actual amount.\r\n\r\n~Pensioner~, a man of the most degraded condition who lives off the\r\nmiserable earnings of a prostitute. There is an unmentionable prefix to\r\nthe word PENSIONER. _See_ PONCE.\r\n\r\n~Pepper~, to thrash, or strike.\xe2\x80\x94_Pugilistic_, but used by\r\nShakspeare.\xe2\x80\x94_Eastern Counties._\r\n\r\n~Pepper-boxes~, the buildings of the Royal Academy and National Gallery\r\nin Trafalgar Square. The name was first given by a wag, in allusion to\r\nthe cupolas erected by Wilkins, the architect, upon the roof, which,\r\nfrom their form and awkward appearance, at a distance suggest to the\r\nstranger the fact of their being enlarged PEPPER-BOXES. _See_ BOILERS.\r\n\r\n~Perch~, or ROOST, a resting-place; \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m off to PERCH,\xe2\x80\x9d _i.e._, I am\r\ngoing to bed.\r\n\r\n    \xe2\x80\x9cNor yet a single perch, for which my lucky stars to thank,\r\n    Except the _perch_ I\xe2\x80\x99ve taken on this damp rheumatic bank.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n        _Lay of the Unsuccessful Angler._\r\n\r\n~Perform~, to carry out a design, generally a dishonest one. To \xe2\x80\x9cPERFORM\r\non a flat\xe2\x80\x9d is to cozen a fool.\r\n\r\n~Perkin~, beer. Dandy or affected shortening of the widely-known firm,\r\nBarclay and Perkins.\r\n\r\n~Perpendicular~, a lunch taken standing-up at a tavern bar. It is usual\r\nto call it lunch, often as the PERPENDICULAR may take the place of\r\ndinner.\r\n\r\n~Persuaders~, spurs.\r\n\r\n~Pesky~, an intensitive expression, implying annoyance; as, \xe2\x80\x9cA PESKY,\r\ntroublesome fellow.\xe2\x80\x9d Corruption of PESTILENT; or, _Irish_, PEASGACH,\r\nrough, rugged. PESKY has now become more American than English. _Pesky\r\nIke_ is the name of a popular American drama.\r\n\r\n~Peter~, a partridge.\xe2\x80\x94_Poacher\xe2\x80\x99s term._\r\n\r\n~Peter~, a bundle, or valise. Also, a cash-box.\r\n\r\n~Peter~, to run short, or give out.\xe2\x80\x94_American._\r\n\r\n~Peter Funk~, an American term for a spurious auction or \xe2\x80\x9cknock-out.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n~Peter Grievous~, a miserable, melancholy fellow; a croaker.\r\n\r\n~Petticoat~, a woman.\r\n\r\n~Pewter~, money, like \xe2\x80\x9ctin,\xe2\x80\x9d used generally to signify silver; also a\r\ntankard. \xe2\x80\x9cLet me have my beer in the PEWTER,\xe2\x80\x9d is a common request to\r\nwaiters, made by \xe2\x80\x9cCity\xe2\x80\x9d men, and others who affect habits of rude\r\nhealth. The pots for which rowing men contend are often called PEWTERS.\r\n\r\n~Philadelphia-lawyer~, a Transatlantic limb of the law considered to be\r\nthe very acme of acuteness. Sailors relate many stories of his artful\r\nabilities, none, however, short enough to find a place here. The phrase,\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cEnough to puzzle a PHILADELPHIA-LAWYER,\xe2\x80\x9d means, enough to puzzle the\r\nsharpest man in the world.\r\n\r\n~Philander~, to ramble on incoherently; to write discursively and\r\nweakly.\r\n\r\n~Philip~, a policeman. The word is loudly given as a signal that the\r\npolice are approaching.\r\n\r\n~Philiper~, a thief\xe2\x80\x99s accomplice, one who stands by and looks out for\r\nthe police while the others commit a robbery, and who calls out\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPhilip!\xe2\x80\x9d when any one approaches.\r\n\r\n~Philistine~, a policeman. The German students call all townspeople not\r\nof their body \xe2\x80\x9cPhilister,\xe2\x80\x9d as ours say \xe2\x80\x9ccads.\xe2\x80\x9d The departing student\r\nsays, mournfully, in one of the Burschenlieder\xe2\x80\x94\r\n\r\n    \xe2\x80\x9cMuss selber nun PHILISTER sein!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n_i.e._, \xe2\x80\x9cI must now myself PHILISTINE be!\xe2\x80\x9d Also, a man who is of a set\r\nopposed to one\xe2\x80\x99s own. Society is supposed to regard all outside its\r\nbounds as belonging to the PHILISTINE world. Bohemians regard all\r\ncleanly, orderly people who conform to conventionality as PHILISTINES.\r\n\r\n~Physog~, or PHIZ, the face. Swift uses the latter word. Corruption of\r\nPHYSIOGNOMY.\r\n\r\n~Picaroon~, a pirate or buccaneer originally; now an ordinary thief.\r\n\r\n~Piccadilly butchers~, a satirical name applied by the crowd to the\r\nregiment of Horse Guards, known as the \xe2\x80\x9cRoyal Blues,\xe2\x80\x9d from their savage\r\nonslaught upon the crowd on the occasion of the arrest of Sir Francis\r\nBurdett at his house in Piccadilly, by order of the Speaker of the House\r\nof Commons. _See_ CHEESEMONGERS.\r\n\r\n~Piccadilly weepers~, long carefully combed-out whiskers of the\r\nDundreary fashion.\r\n\r\n~Pick~, \xe2\x80\x9cto PICK oneself up,\xe2\x80\x9d to recover after a beating or illness,\r\nsometimes varied to \xe2\x80\x9cPICK up one\xe2\x80\x99s crumbs;\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9cto PICK a man up,\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9cto do,\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nor cheat him.\r\n\r\n~Pickaninny~, a young child is thus styled by the West Indian negroes.\r\nThe word is now completely naturalized among sailors and water-side\r\npeople in England.\r\n\r\n~Pickers~, the hands.\xe2\x80\x94_Shakspeare._\r\n\r\n~Pickle~, a miserable or comical position; \xe2\x80\x9che is in a sad PICKLE,\xe2\x80\x9d said\r\nof any one who has fallen into the gutter, or got besmeared. \xe2\x80\x9cA PICKLE\r\nherring,\xe2\x80\x9d a comical fellow, a merry-andrew.\xe2\x80\x94_Old._ Also, a mischievous\r\nboy; \xe2\x80\x9cwhat a PICKLE he is, to be sure!\xe2\x80\x9d Derived from his always getting\r\ninto a PICKLE, or mess.\r\n\r\n~Pickles!~ gammon; also a jeering and insulting exclamation.\r\n\r\n~Pick-me-up~, a revivifying drink taken after a debauch; a tonic.\r\n\r\n~Piece~, a contemptuous term for a woman; a strumpet.\xe2\x80\x94_Shakspeare._ Not\r\nalways objectionable nowadays. A \xe2\x80\x9cbarber\xe2\x80\x99s clerk\xe2\x80\x9d does not object to\r\nhear his sweetheart or wife called \xe2\x80\x9ca nice PIECE;\xe2\x80\x9d and gentlemen of the\r\ncounter-jumping fraternity describe their \xe2\x80\x9cyoung ladies\xe2\x80\x9d as \xe2\x80\x9cnice PIECES\r\nof goods.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n~Pieman.~ In tossing, the man who cries is called the PIEMAN. In the old\r\ndays when the itinerant PIEMAN\xe2\x80\x99S duty was to toss or sell, and his call\r\nwas, \xe2\x80\x9cHot pies, toss or buy, toss or buy,\xe2\x80\x9d he was always supposed to be\r\nentitled to the cry, the intending eater \xe2\x80\x9cskying the copper.\xe2\x80\x9d An active\r\nand efficient police have, however, improved tossing\xe2\x80\x94so far, at all\r\nevents, as PIEMEN and poor people are concerned\xe2\x80\x94off the face of the\r\nearth, and gaming of all descriptions is now a luxury confined to the\r\nrich.\r\n\r\n~Pig~, a mass of metal,\xe2\x80\x94so called from its being poured in a fluid\r\nstate from a SOW, which _see_.\xe2\x80\x94_Workman\xe2\x80\x99s term._\r\n\r\n~Pig~, a policeman; an informer. The word is now almost exclusively\r\napplied by London thieves to a plain-clothes man, or a \xe2\x80\x9cnose.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n~Pig~, a pressman in a printing office. _See_ DONKEY.\r\n\r\n~Pig~, or SOW\xe2\x80\x99S BABY, a sixpence.\r\n\r\n~Pig~, to live in a crowded, filthy manner. The lower orders of Irish\r\nare said to PIG together. A suggestive, if not elegant, expression.\r\n\r\n~Pig and Tinder-box~, the vulgar rendering of the well-known tavern\r\nsign, \xe2\x80\x9cElephant and Castle.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n~Pigeon~, a gullible or soft person. The _French_ cant, or _Argot_, has\r\nthe word PIGEON, dupe\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cPECHON, PESCHON DE RUBY, apprenti gueux, enfant\r\n(sans doute d\xc3\xa9rob\xc3\xa9)\xe2\x80\x9d. The vagabonds and brigands of Spain also used the\r\nword in their _Germania_, or robbers\xe2\x80\x99 language, PALOMO (PIGEON),\r\nignorant, simple. In the sporting world sharps and flats are often\r\ncalled \xe2\x80\x9crooks and PIGEONS\xe2\x80\x9d respectively\xe2\x80\x94sometimes \xe2\x80\x9cspiders and flies.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n~Pigeon~, business, simply the Chinese pronunciation of the English\r\nword.\xe2\x80\x94_Anglo-Chinese._\r\n\r\n~Pigeon-English~, the English spoken by the natives of Canton and other\r\nparts of China.\r\n\r\n~Pigeon-flying~, or BLUEY CRACKING, breaking into empty houses and\r\nstealing lead.\r\n\r\n~Pigeon\xe2\x80\x99s milk~, an imaginary fluid for which boys and simpletons are\r\nfrequently sent on the 1st of April.\r\n\r\n~Pig-headed~, obstinate.\r\n\r\n~Pig\xe2\x80\x99s eye~, the ace of diamonds in cards.\r\n\r\n~Pig\xe2\x80\x99s whisper~, a low or inaudible whisper; also a short space of time,\r\nsynonymous with \xe2\x80\x9ccockstride,\xe2\x80\x9d _i.e._, cock\xe2\x80\x99s tread.\r\n\r\n~Pike~, a turnpike; \xe2\x80\x9cto bilk a PIKE,\xe2\x80\x9d to cheat the keeper of the\r\ntoll-gate. Mr. Tony Weller makes many amusing remarks on PIKES and\r\nPIKE-keepers. Since the first edition of this work was published, PIKES\r\nand PIKE-keepers have departed from amongst us, so far as London and its\r\nimmediate vicinity are concerned.\r\n\r\n~Pike~, to run, to be off with speed.\r\n\r\n~Pike it~, is said as a hasty and contemptuous, if not angry, dismissal,\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cif you don\xe2\x80\x99t like it, take a short stick and PIKE it.\xe2\x80\x9d This is but a\r\nform of the attempts at rhyming smartness common in London.\r\n\r\n    \xe2\x80\x9cJoe quickly his sand had sold, sir,\r\n      And Bess got a basket of rags;\r\n    Then up to St. Giles\xe2\x80\x99s they roll\xe2\x80\x99d, sir;\r\n      To every bunter Bess brags.\r\n    Then unto the gin-shop they PIKE IT,\r\n      And Bess was admitted, we hear;\r\n    For none of the crew dare but like it,\r\n      As Joey, her kiddy, was there,\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n        _The Sand-man\xe2\x80\x99s Wedding_, a Cantata.\r\n\r\n    \xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x99Twas not our fault, dear Jack; we saw the watch going into the\r\n    house the moment we came there, and we thought it proper to PIKE\r\n    OFF.\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94_The Prison Breaker_, a Farce.\r\n\r\n~Pikey~, a tramp or gipsy. A PIKEY-cart is in various parts of the\r\ncountry one of those habitable vehicles suggestive of a wandering life.\r\nPossibly the term has reference to one who constantly uses the PIKE, or\r\nturnpike road.\r\n\r\n~Pile~, a sum of money; generally the whole of a man\xe2\x80\x99s private means. A\r\nterm originally peculiar to Californian miners, in reference to their\r\naccumulated dust and nuggets. American gamblers speak of \xe2\x80\x9cputting all\r\nthe PILE on\xe2\x80\x9d when they fancy anything very much. \xe2\x80\x9cTo go the whole PILE\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nruns level with our sporting phrase, \xe2\x80\x9cTo go a raker.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n~Pill~, a doctor.\xe2\x80\x94_Military._ PILL-DRIVER, a peddling apothecary.\r\n\r\n~Pill~, to blackball a man at a club. Sometimes a man who is blackballed\r\nis described as having received too much medicine.\r\n\r\n~Pill-box~, a doctor\xe2\x80\x99s carriage.\r\n\r\n~Pin~, \xe2\x80\x9cto put in the PIN,\xe2\x80\x9d to refrain from drinking. From the ancient\r\npeg tankard, which was furnished with a row of PINS, or pegs, to\r\nregulate the amount which each person was to drink. Drunken people are\r\noften requested to \xe2\x80\x9cput in the PIN,\xe2\x80\x9d from some remote connexion between\r\ntheir unsteadiness and that of a carriage wheel which has lost its\r\nlinch-PIN. The popular cry, \xe2\x80\x9cPut in the PIN,\xe2\x80\x9d can have no connexion with\r\nthe drinking PIN or peg now, whatever it may originally have had. A\r\nMERRY PIN, a roysterer. _See_ PEG.\r\n\r\n~Pinch~, to steal or cheat; also, to catch, or apprehend.\r\n\r\n~Pinchbeck~, inferior, deteriorated. Anything pretending to more than\r\nits proper value is said to be PINCHBECK.\r\n\r\n    \xe2\x80\x9cWhere, in these PINCHBECK days, can we hope to find the old\r\n    agricultural virtue in all its purity?\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94_Framley Parsonage._\r\n\r\nPINCHBECK was an inferior metal, compounded of copper and zinc, to\r\nresemble gold. It was very fashionable in the last century, and derived\r\nits name from a Mr. PINCHBECK, a well-known London tradesman, who\r\nmanufactured watches, buckles, and other articles out of it. PINCHBECK\r\nfirst obtained his notoriety by the invention of an ingenious\r\ncandle-snuffers, which the author of _The Heroic Epistle to Sir William\r\nChambers_ made the vehicle of a facetious Ode that went through eight\r\neditions. The title of this _jeu d\xe2\x80\x99esprit_ ran thus:\xe2\x80\x94\r\n\r\n    \xe2\x80\x9c_Ode to Mr. Pinchbeck, upon his Newly-invented Candle-Snuffers, by_\r\n    MALCOLM M\xe2\x80\x99GREGOR, Esq., 1776.\r\n\r\n    \xe2\x80\x9cIllustrious PINCHBECK! condescend,\r\n    Thou well-beloved, and best king\xe2\x80\x99s friend,\r\n    These lyric lines to view;\r\n    Oh, may they prompt thee, ere too late,\r\n    To snuff the candle of the State,\r\n    That burns a little blue!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nPINCHBECK published a poetical reply, and the two pamphlets were for a\r\nlong time the talk of the town.\r\n\r\n~Pink~, the acme of perfection. The scarlet garb worn in the\r\nhunting-field.\r\n\r\n~Pink~, to stab, or pierce. In the days of rapier-wearing a professed\r\nduellist was said to be \xe2\x80\x9ca regular PINKER and driller.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n~Pinnel~, or PENNEL,\xe2\x80\x94corruption of penal servitude. As, \xe2\x80\x9cfour-year\r\nPINNEL.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n~Pinner-up~, a seller of old songs, pinned against a wall or framed\r\ncanvas. Formerly many of these street salesmen carried on their little\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cpaper trade\xe2\x80\x9d in London. There are but one or two now left.\r\n\r\n~Pins~, legs.\r\n\r\n~Pipe~, to follow or dog a person; to watch, to notice.\r\n\r\n~Pipe~, to shed tears, or bewail; \xe2\x80\x9cPIPE one\xe2\x80\x99s eye.\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94_Sea term._\r\n\r\n    \xe2\x80\x9cHe first began to eye his pipe.\r\n    And then to PIPE his eye.\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94_Hood._\r\n\r\nMetaphor from the boatswain\xe2\x80\x99s pipe, which calls to duty.\r\n\r\n~Pipe~, \xe2\x80\x9cto put one\xe2\x80\x99s PIPE out,\xe2\x80\x9d to traverse his plans, \xe2\x80\x9cto take a rise\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nout of him. When any one meets with a rebuff or a sharp answer, he is\r\noften told to \xe2\x80\x9cput that in his PIPE and smoke it,\xe2\x80\x9d _i.e._, to digest it\r\ncarefully.\r\n\r\n~Piper~, a person employed by an omnibus proprietor to act as a spy on\r\nthe conductor.\r\n\r\n~Piper~, a broken-winded hack horse.\r\n\r\n~Pipkin~, the stomach,\xe2\x80\x94properly, an earthen round-bottomed\r\npot\xe2\x80\x94_Norwich._\r\n\r\n~Pips~, the marks, no matter of what suit, on playing cards. The ace is\r\noften called \xe2\x80\x9csingle PIP.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n~Pit~, a breast-pocket.\r\n\r\n~Pitch~, a fixed locality where a patterer can hold forth to a gaping\r\nmultitude for at least some few minutes continuously; \xe2\x80\x9cto do a PITCH in\r\nthe drag,\xe2\x80\x9d to perform in the street. An itinerant is said to \xe2\x80\x9cmake a\r\nPITCH\xe2\x80\x9d whenever he attempts to do any business.\r\n\r\n~Pitch~, to utter base coin. Smashers are known to themselves and their\r\nfriends, the rest of the dangerous classes, as \xe2\x80\x9csnide PITCHERS.\xe2\x80\x9d The\r\nconfederacy is divided into makers, buyers, holders, and pitchers. The\r\nmaker probably never sees the actual passers of base money, the buyer\r\nbeing generally the intercommunicating medium. The holder is generally a\r\nman who carries the bulk of the \xe2\x80\x9csnides,\xe2\x80\x9d and waits about; while the\r\npitcher, often a woman\xe2\x80\x94indeed, more often than not\xe2\x80\x94runs the actual\r\nrisk.\r\n\r\n~Pitch~, to go to bed for less than the ordinary period. Journeymen\r\nbakers, and others whose work is disjointed, call any short interval of\r\nsleep a PITCH. Probably from the action.\r\n\r\n~Pitch into~, to fight; \xe2\x80\x9cPITCH INTO him, Bill,\xe2\x80\x9d _i.e._, give him a\r\nthrashing.\r\n\r\n~Pitch the fork~, to tell a pitiful tale.\r\n\r\n~Pitch the nob~, PRICK THE GARTER, which _see_.\r\n\r\n~Place~, to name the first three horses in a race. This is the duty of\r\nthe judge, who sees nothing of the race but the finish. Sometimes an\r\nofficial will place more than the first three, but this in no way\r\ninterferes with the meaning of the word as generally received. To run\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cnowhere\xe2\x80\x9d is to be unplaced.\r\n\r\n~Place~, first, second, or third position in a race. Sometimes a PLACE\r\nis called a \xe2\x80\x9csituation\xe2\x80\x9d or a \xe2\x80\x9cshop.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n~Plant~, a dodge, a preconcerted swindle; a position in the street to\r\nsell from. All bearings-up, bonnetings, and such like arrangements, are\r\nthe results of preconcerted schemes or PLANTS.\r\n\r\n~Plant~, to mark a person out for plunder or robbery; to conceal or hide\r\nmoney, &c.\xe2\x80\x94_Old Cant._ In the sense of conceal, there is a similar word\r\nin _Argot_, PLANQUER.\r\n\r\n~Plant~, a hidden store of money or variables. To \xe2\x80\x9cspring a PLANT\xe2\x80\x9d is to\r\nunearth another person\xe2\x80\x99s hoard.\r\n\r\n~Platform~, a standpoint in an argument, a statement of political or\r\ngeneral opinion. \xe2\x80\x9cHome rule\xe2\x80\x99s my PLATFORM!\xe2\x80\x9d Originally _American_, but\r\nnow general.\r\n\r\n~Play~, to strike for higher wages, to be out of work.\xe2\x80\x94_North._\r\n\r\n~Plebs~, a term used to stigmatize a tradesman\xe2\x80\x99s son at Westminster\r\nSchool. _Latin_, PLEBS, the vulgar.\r\n\r\n~Plough.~ To be PLOUGHED is to fail to pass an examination. About\r\ntwenty years ago \xe2\x80\x9cpluck,\xe2\x80\x9d the word then used, began to be superseded\r\nby PLOUGH. It is said to have arisen from a man who could not supply\r\nthe examiner with any quotation from Scripture, until at last he\r\nblurted out, \xe2\x80\x9cAnd the ploughers ploughed on my back, and made long\r\nfurrows.\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94_University._\r\n\r\n~Ploughed~, drunk.\r\n\r\n~Pluck~, the heart, liver, and lungs of an animal,\xe2\x80\x94all that is PLUCKED\r\naway in connexion with the windpipe, from the chest of a sheep or hog.\r\n\r\n~Pluck~, to turn back at a University examination. The supposed origin\r\nof PLUCK is, that when, on degree day, the proctor, after having read\r\nthe name of a candidate for a degree, walks down the hall and back, it\r\nis to give any creditor the opportunity of plucking his sleeve, and\r\ninforming him of the candidate\xe2\x80\x99s being in debt.\r\n\r\n~Pluck~, courage, valour, stoutness. _See following._\r\n\r\n~Plucked un~, a stout or brave fellow; \xe2\x80\x9che\xe2\x80\x99s a rare PLUCKED UN,\xe2\x80\x9d _i.e._,\r\nhe dares face anything.\r\n\r\nDuring the Crimean War and the Indian Mutiny PLUCKY, signifying\r\ncourageous, became a favourite term even among ladies; and the term\r\nBritish PLUCK will probably live\xe2\x80\x94slangy as is its origin\xe2\x80\x94as long as\r\nthe language into which it has been adopted, for the history of the\r\ndeeds with which it is associated can never die, while, indeed, a\r\nhistory remains to this country. The word met with great disfavour at\r\nfirst from the \xe2\x80\x9cgenteel,\xe2\x80\x9d but of course they followed when aristocracy\r\ndeigned to use it.\r\n\r\n~Plum~, \xc2\xa3100,000, usually applied to the dowry of a rich heiress, to a\r\nlegacy, or to a sum made in business or by a lucky speculation.\r\n\r\n~Plum-cash~, prime cost.\xe2\x80\x94_Anglo-Chinese._\r\n\r\n~Plummy~, round, sleek, jolly, or fat; excellent, very good, first-rate.\r\n\r\n~Plumper~, a single vote at an election, not a \xe2\x80\x9csplit ticket.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n~Plunder~, a common word in the horse trade to express profit. Also an\r\nAmerican term for baggage, luggage. In Lower Canada the French packmen\r\ncall luggage \xe2\x80\x9cbutin.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n~Plunger~, a heavy cavalry-man.\xe2\x80\x94_Military slang._\r\n\r\n~Plutocracy~, the wealthy classes. The Manchester merchants are often\r\ntermed a millocracy, and words of a similar character are mobocracy and\r\nmoneyocracy.\r\n\r\n~Pocket~, to put up with. A man who does not resent an affront is said\r\nto POCKET it.\r\n\r\n~Pocket-pistol~, a dram-flask.\r\n\r\n~Podgy~, drunk; dumpy, short, and fat.\r\n\r\n~Pogram~, a Dissenter, a fanatic, formalist, or humbug. So called from a\r\nwell-known enthusiast of this name.\r\n\r\n~Poke~, a bag, or sack; \xe2\x80\x9cto buy a pig in a POKE,\xe2\x80\x9d to purchase anything\r\nwithout seeing it. POKE was originally a pocket. Shakspeare says\xe2\x80\x94\r\n\r\n    \xe2\x80\x9cAnd then he pulled a dial from his POKE.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n~Poke.~ \xe2\x80\x9cCome, none of your POKING fun at me,\xe2\x80\x9d _i.e._, you must not\r\nlaugh at me.\r\n\r\n~Poker.~ \xe2\x80\x9cBy the holy POKER and the tumbling Tom!\xe2\x80\x9d an Irish oath.\r\n\r\n~Pokers~, or SILVER POKERS, the Bedels of the Vice-Chancellor, who carry\r\nsilver maces, and accompany him through the streets. They are also\r\nofficers of his court.\xe2\x80\x94_University._\r\n\r\n    \xe2\x80\x9cAround, around, all, all around.\r\n      On seats with velvet lined,\r\n    Sat Heads of Houses in a row,\r\n      And Deans and College Dons below,\r\n    With a POKER or two behind.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n        _Rime of the New-made Baccalere_, 1841.\r\n\r\n~Poky~, confined or cramped; \xe2\x80\x9cthat corner is POKY and narrow.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nHousewives describe a small uncomfortable room as \xe2\x80\x9ca POKY hole.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n_Saxon_, POKE, a sack.\r\n\r\n~Policeman~, a fly\xe2\x80\x94more especially the kind known as \xe2\x80\x9cblue bottle.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nAlso, among the dangerous classes, a man who is unworthy of confidence,\r\na sneak or mean fellow.\r\n\r\n~Polish off~, to finish off anything quickly\xe2\x80\x94a dinner, for instance;\r\nalso to finish off an adversary.\xe2\x80\x94_Pugilistic._\r\n\r\n~Poll~, at Cambridge, the \xe2\x80\x9cordinary degree\xe2\x80\x9d candidates for the B.A.\r\nExamination, who do not aspire to the \xe2\x80\x9cHonours\xe2\x80\x9d list. From the _Greek_,\r\n\xce\xbf\xe1\xbc\xb1 \xcf\x80\xe1\xbd\xb9\xce\xbb\xce\xbb\xce\xbf\xce\xb9, \xe2\x80\x9cthe many.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n~Poll~, to beat or distance, as in a race; to utterly vanquish in\r\ncompetition. Term much used by printers.\r\n\r\n~Poll~, a female of unsteady character; \xe2\x80\x9cPOLLED up,\xe2\x80\x9d means living with a\r\nwoman in a state of unmarried impropriety. Also, if a costermonger sees\r\none of his friends walking with a strange woman, he will say to him on\r\nthe earliest opportunity, \xe2\x80\x9cI saw yer when yer was POLLED up.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n~Poll~, or POLLING, one thief robbing another of part of the booty. In\r\nuse in ancient times, _vide Hall\xe2\x80\x99s Union_, 1548.\r\n\r\n~Poll parrot~, a talkative, gossiping woman. A term much used about\r\nRatcliff Highway.\r\n\r\n~Polony~, Cockney shortening and vulgar pronunciation of Bologna\r\n(sausage). The sausages which are sold under the name of POLONIES have,\r\nhowever, no nearer connexion with Bologna sausages than that of the\r\nword\xe2\x80\x99s derivation.\r\n\r\n~Pompadours~, the Fifty-sixth Regiment of Foot in the British army.\r\n\r\n~Ponce~, a degraded man who lives upon a woman\xe2\x80\x99s prostitution. Low-class\r\nEast-end thieves even will \xe2\x80\x9cdraw the line\xe2\x80\x9d at PONCES, and object to\r\ntheir presence in the boozing-kens.\r\n\r\n~Pond~, or HERRING-POND, the sea; so called by those who were sent\r\nacross it at the national expense.\r\n\r\n~Ponge~, or PONGELOW, beer, half-and-half; the term is also used as a\r\nverb, as in the Cockney phrase, \xe2\x80\x9clet\xe2\x80\x99s PONGELOW, shall we?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n~Pony~, twenty-five pounds.\xe2\x80\x94_Sporting._\r\n\r\n~Poona~, a sovereign. Corruption of \xe2\x80\x9cpound;\xe2\x80\x9d or from the _Lingua\r\nFranca_.\r\n\r\n~Pop~, to pawn or pledge; \xe2\x80\x9cto POP up the spout,\xe2\x80\x9d to pledge at the\r\npawnbroker\xe2\x80\x99s,\xe2\x80\x94an allusion to the spout up which the brokers send the\r\nticketed articles until such times as they shall be redeemed. The spout\r\nruns from the ground-floor to the wareroom at the top of the house.\r\nGinger-beer is also known as POP.\r\n\r\n~Pop the question~, to make an offer of marriage.\r\n\r\n~Pope\xe2\x80\x99s-eye~, a peculiar little part in a leg of mutton, much esteemed\r\nby lovers of that joint.\r\n\r\n~Pope\xe2\x80\x99s nose~, the extremity of the rump of a roast fowl, sometimes\r\ndevilled as a dainty for epicures. Also known as \xe2\x80\x9cthe parson\xe2\x80\x99s NOSE.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n~Pops~, pocket-pistols.\r\n\r\n~Porterhouse steak~, an American term for a steak which contains a small\r\nbone. In the States, tender-loin steaks are much eaten. These are from\r\nwhat we call the undercut of the sirloin.\r\n\r\n~Portrait~, a sovereign. Modification of \xe2\x80\x9cQueen\xe2\x80\x99s picture.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n~Posa~, a treasurer. A corruption of \xe2\x80\x9cpurser,\xe2\x80\x9d the name given\r\nto the treasurer in the large Anglo-Chinese mercantile\r\nestablishments.\xe2\x80\x94_Anglo-Chinese._\r\n\r\n~Posh~, a halfpenny, or trifling coin. Also a generic term for money.\r\n\r\n~Post~, to pay down; \xe2\x80\x9cPOST the pony\xe2\x80\x9d signifies to place the stakes\r\nplayed for on the table.\r\n\r\n~Post-horn~, the nose. _See_ PASTE-HORN.\r\n\r\n~Post-mortem~, at Cambridge, the second examination which men who have\r\nbeen \xe2\x80\x9cplucked\xe2\x80\x9d have to undergo.\xe2\x80\x94_University._\r\n\r\n~Posted up~, well acquainted with the subject in question, \xe2\x80\x9cup to the\r\nmark,\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94metaphor drawn from the counting-house.\r\n\r\n~Pot~, a favourite in the betting for a race. Probably so called because\r\nit is usual to say that a heavily-backed horse carries \xe2\x80\x9ca POT of money.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nWhen a favourite is beaten the POT is said to be upset.\r\n\r\n~Pot~, a sixpence, _i.e._, the price of a POT or quart of half-and-half.\r\nA half-crown, in medical student slang, is a FIVE-POT piece.\r\n\r\n~Pot~, TO GO TO POT, to die; from the classic custom of putting the\r\nashes of the dead in an urn; also, to be ruined or broken up,\xe2\x80\x94often\r\napplied to tradesmen who fail in business. \xe2\x80\x9cGo to POT!\xe2\x80\x9d _i.e._, go and\r\nhang yourself, shut up and be quiet.\xe2\x80\x94_L\xe2\x80\x99Estrange._ \xe2\x80\x9cTo put the POT on,\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nto overcharge or exaggerate. \xe2\x80\x9cTo go to POT\xe2\x80\x9d most probably means to go\r\nout of all shape, as metal in the melting-pot.\r\n\r\n~Pot~, to finish; \xe2\x80\x9cdon\xe2\x80\x99t POT me,\xe2\x80\x9d term used at billiards, when a player\r\nholes his adversary\xe2\x80\x99s ball\xe2\x80\x94generally considered shabby play. This word\r\nwas much used by our soldiers in the Crimea in reference to shots from a\r\nhole or ambush. These were called POT-SHOTS. The term is still used to\r\ndenote a shot taken sitting or at ease.\r\n\r\n~Pot-boiler~, a picture hurriedly painted for the purpose of \xe2\x80\x9ckeeping\r\nthe POT BOILING.\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94_Artistic slang._\r\n\r\n~Pot-faker~, a hawker of crockery and general earthenware.\r\n\r\n~Pot-hat~, a low-crowned hat, as distinguished from the soft wideawake\r\nand the stove-pipe.\r\n\r\n~Pot-hunter~, a sportsman who shoots anything he comes across, having\r\nmore regard to filling his bag than to the rules which regulate the\r\nsport.
