Corrupt form of _Gaelic_, CAILLE, a young woman.\r\n\r\n~Shalley-gonahey~, a smock-frock.\xe2\x80\x94_Cornish._\r\n\r\n~Shallow~, the peculiar barrow used by costermongers.\r\n\r\n~Shallow~, a weak-minded country justice of the peace.\xe2\x80\x94_Shakspeare._\r\n\r\n~Shallow-cove~, a begging rascal, who goes about the country half naked,\r\nwith the most limited amount of rags upon his person, wearing neither\r\nshoes, stockings, nor hat.\r\n\r\n~Shallow-mot~, a ragged woman,\xe2\x80\x94the frequent companion of the\r\nSHALLOW-COVE.\r\n\r\n~Shallows~, \xe2\x80\x9cto go on the SHALLOWS,\xe2\x80\x9d to go half naked.\r\n\r\n~Sham~, contraction of champagne. In general use among the lower class\r\nof sporting men. Sometimes extended to SHAMMY.\r\n\r\n~Sham Abraham~, to feign sickness. _See_ ABRAHAM.\r\n\r\n~Shandrydan~, an old-fashioned or rickety conveyance of the \xe2\x80\x9cshay\xe2\x80\x9d\r\norder.\r\n\r\n~Shandy-gaff~, ale and gingerbeer. Origin unknown, but use very common.\r\n\r\n~Shanks~, legs.\r\n\r\n~Shanks\xe2\x80\x99s mare~, \xe2\x80\x9cto ride SHANK\xe2\x80\x99S MARE,\xe2\x80\x9d to go on foot.\r\n\r\n~Shant~, a pot or quart; \xe2\x80\x9cSHANT of bivvy,\xe2\x80\x9d a quart of beer.\r\n\r\n~Shanty~, a rude, temporary habitation. The word is principally employed\r\nto designate the huts inhabited by navigators, when constructing large\r\nlines of railway far distant from towns. It is derived from the _French_\r\nCHANTIER, used by the Canadians for a log hut, and has travelled from\r\nthence, by way of the United States, to England.\r\n\r\n~Shanty~, a song. A term in use among sailors. From CHANTER.\r\n\r\n~Shapes~, \xe2\x80\x9cto cut up\xe2\x80\x9d or \xe2\x80\x9cshow SHAPES,\xe2\x80\x9d to exhibit pranks, or\r\nflightiness.\r\n\r\n~Shark~, a sharper, a swindler. Bow Street term in 1785, now in most\r\ndictionaries.\xe2\x80\x94_Friesic_ and _Danish_, SCHURK. _See_ LAND-SHARK.\r\n\r\n~Sharp~, or SHARPER, a cunning cheat, a rogue,\xe2\x80\x94the opposite of FLAT.\r\n\r\n~Sharp~, a similar expression to \xe2\x80\x9cTWO PUN\xe2\x80\x99 TEN\xe2\x80\x9d (which _see_), used by\r\nassistants in shops to signify that a customer of suspected honesty is\r\namongst them. The shopman in this case would ask one of the assistants,\r\nin a voice loud enough to be generally heard, \xe2\x80\x9cHas Mr. SHARP come in\r\nyet?\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9cNo,\xe2\x80\x9d would probably be the reply; \xe2\x80\x9cbut he is expected every\r\nminute.\xe2\x80\x9d The signal is at once understood, and a general look-out kept\r\nupon the suspected party.\r\n\r\n~Sharp\xe2\x80\x99s-alley blood-worms~, beef sausages and black puddings. Sharp\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nAlley was, until City improvements caused it to be destroyed, a noted\r\nslaughtering-place near Smithfield.\r\n\r\n~Shave~, a false alarm, a hoax, a sell. This term was much in vogue in\r\nthe Crimea during the Russian campaign,\xe2\x80\x94that is, though much used by\r\nthe military before then, the term did not, until that period, become\r\nknown to the general public.\r\n\r\n~Shave~, a narrow escape. At Cambridge, \xe2\x80\x9cjust SHAVING through,\xe2\x80\x9d or\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cmaking a SHAVE,\xe2\x80\x9d is just escaping a \xe2\x80\x9cpluck\xe2\x80\x9d by coming out at the bottom\r\nof the list.\r\n\r\n    \xe2\x80\x9cMy terms are anything but dear,\r\n    Then read with me, and never fear;\r\n    The examiners we\xe2\x80\x99re sure to queer,\r\n    And get through, if you make a SHAVE on\xe2\x80\x99t.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n        _The Private Tutor._\r\n\r\n~Shave;~ \xe2\x80\x9cto SHAVE a customer,\xe2\x80\x9d charge him more for an article than the\r\nmarked price. Used in the drapery trade. When the master sees an\r\nopportunity of doing this, he strokes his chin, as a signal to his\r\nassistant who is serving the customer.\r\n\r\n~Shaver~, a sharp fellow; there are young and old SHAVERS.\xe2\x80\x94_Sea._\r\n\r\n~Shebeen~, an unlicensed place where spirituous liquors are illegally\r\nsold. A word almost peculiar to Ireland.\r\n\r\n~Shed a tear~, to take a dram, or glass of neat spirits; jocular phrase\r\nused, with a sort of grim earnestness, by old topers to each other. \xe2\x80\x9cNow\r\nthen, old fellow, come and SHED A TEAR!\xe2\x80\x9d an invitation to take \xe2\x80\x9csummat\r\nshort.\xe2\x80\x9d The origin may have been that ardent spirits, taken neat by\r\nyounger persons, usually bring water to their eyes. With confirmed\r\ndrinkers, however, the phrase is used with an air of mingled humour and\r\nregret at their own position. A still more pathetic phrase is\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cputting\r\na NAIL IN ONE\xe2\x80\x99S COFFIN,\xe2\x80\x9d which _see_. The term SHED A TEAR is probably\r\nderived from \xe2\x80\x9ceye-water.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n~Sheen~, bad money.\xe2\x80\x94_Scotch._\r\n\r\n~Sheeny~, a Jew. This word is used by both Jew and Gentile at the\r\nEast-end of London, and is not considered objectionable on either side.\r\n\r\n~Sheep\xe2\x80\x99s eyes~, loving looks, \xe2\x80\x9cto make SHEEP\xe2\x80\x99S EYES at a person,\xe2\x80\x9d to\r\ncast amorous glances towards one on the sly.\r\n\r\n    \xe2\x80\x9cBut he, the beast, was casting SHEEP\xe2\x80\x99S EYES at her\r\n      Out of his bullock head.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n        _Colman, Broad Grins._\r\n\r\n~Shelf~, \xe2\x80\x9con the SHELF,\xe2\x80\x9d not yet disposed of; young ladies are said to\r\nbe so situated when they cannot meet with husbands. \xe2\x80\x9cOn the SHELF\xe2\x80\x9d also\r\nmeans pawned, or laid by in trust.\r\n\r\n~Shell out~, to pay or count out money. Also a game played on a billiard\r\ntable, a variation of pool.\r\n\r\n~Shepherd~, to look after carefully, to place under police surveillance.\r\n\r\n~Shice~, nothing; \xe2\x80\x9cto do anything for SHICE,\xe2\x80\x9d to get no payment. The\r\nterm was first used by the Jews in the last century. Grose gives the\r\nphrase CHICE-AM-A-TRICE, which has a synonymous meaning. _Spanish_,\r\nCHICO, little; _Anglo-Saxon_, CHICHE, niggardly; or perhaps connected\r\nwith the _German_, SCHEISSEN.\r\n\r\n~Shicer~, a mean man, a humbug, a \xe2\x80\x9cduffer,\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94a worthless person, one who\r\nwill not work. This is the worst term one Jew can use to another. At the\r\ndiggings it means a hole which yields nothing.\r\n\r\n~Shickery~, shabby, bad. From SHAKY, SHAKERY.\r\n\r\n~Shickster~, a lady. _See_ SHAKESTER.\r\n\r\n~Shickster-crabs~, ladies\xe2\x80\x99 shoes.\xe2\x80\x94_Tramps\xe2\x80\x99 term._\r\n\r\n~Shigs~, money, silver.\xe2\x80\x94_East London._\r\n\r\n~Shikaree~, a hunter, a sportsman.\xe2\x80\x94_Anglo-Indian._ An English sportsman\r\nwho has seen many ups and downs in jungles of the East styles himself\r\n\xe2\x80\x9can OLD SHIKAREE.\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94_Anglo-Indian._ Also spelt SHEKARRY.\r\n\r\n~Shilly-shally~, to trifle or fritter away time; to be irresolute.\r\nCorruption of \xe2\x80\x9cShall I, shall I?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n~Shin~, an Americanism for walking. \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m tired of SHINNING around.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n~Shindy~, a row, or noise. A SHINDY generally means a regular m\xc3\xaal\xc3\xa9e.\r\n\r\n~Shine~, a row, or disturbance.\r\n\r\n~Shine~, \xe2\x80\x9cto take the SHINE out of a person,\xe2\x80\x9d to surpass or excel him.\r\n\r\n~Shiners~, sovereigns, or money.\r\n\r\n~Shiney rag~, \xe2\x80\x9cto win the SHINEY RAG,\xe2\x80\x9d to be ruined,\xe2\x80\x94said in gambling,\r\nwhen any one continues betting after \xe2\x80\x9cluck has set in against him.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n~Shin-plaster~, a bank-note. Originally an Americanism.\r\n\r\n~Shins.~ \xe2\x80\x9cTo break one\xe2\x80\x99s SHINS,\xe2\x80\x9d figurative expression meaning to borrow\r\nmoney.\r\n\r\n~Ship-shape~, proper, in good order; sometimes the phrase is varied to\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSHIP-SHAPE and Bristol fashion.\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94_Sea._ The latter portion of the\r\nexpression went out with Bristol\xe2\x80\x99s fame as a seaport.\r\n\r\n~Shirty~, ill-tempered, or cross. When one person makes another in an\r\nill-humour he is said to have \xe2\x80\x9cgot his SHIRT out.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n~Shivering Jemmy~, the name given by street-folk to any cadger who\r\nexposes himself, half naked, on a cold day, to obtain alms. The \xe2\x80\x9cgame\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nis unpleasant, but was, before exposure of a different kind spoilt it,\r\nexceedingly lucrative.\r\n\r\n~Shockhead~, a head of long, unkempt, and rough hair.\r\n\r\n~Shoddy~, old cloth worked up into new; made from soldiers\xe2\x80\x99 and\r\npolicemen\xe2\x80\x99s coats. The old cloth is pulled to pieces, the yarn\r\nunravelled and carded over again. This produces shoddy, which is very\r\nshort in the fibre, and from it are produced, on again twisting and\r\nweaving, cloth fabrics used for ladies\xe2\x80\x99 mantles, &c. Also, a term of\r\nderision applied to workmen in woollen factories.\xe2\x80\x94_Yorkshire._\r\n\r\n~Shoddy~, the plutocracy created out of bogus contracts during the civil\r\nwar in the United States. The SHODDYITES enriched themselves at the\r\nexpense of their country in the most shameless manner, having most\r\nlikely studied under those contractors who should have supplied our\r\nsoldiers with necessaries during the Crimean War.\r\n\r\n~Shoe~, to free or initiate a person,\xe2\x80\x94a practice common in most trades\r\nto a new-comer. The SHOEING consists in paying for beer, or other\r\nliquor, which is drunk by the older hands. The cans emptied, and the\r\nbill paid, the stranger is considered properly SHOD. SHOEING is a\r\nvariation of \xe2\x80\x9cpaying one\xe2\x80\x99s footing.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n~Shoe leather!~ a thief\xe2\x80\x99s warning cry when he hears footsteps. This\r\nexclamation is used in the spirit which animated the friend who, when he\r\nsuspected treachery towards Bruce at King Edward\xe2\x80\x99s court, in 1306, sent\r\nhim a purse and a pair of spurs, as a sign that he should use them in\r\nmaking his escape.\r\n\r\n~Shoes~, \xe2\x80\x9cto die in one\xe2\x80\x99s SHOES,\xe2\x80\x9d to be hanged. In the old hanging days\r\na highwayman would often kick off his shoes when the rope was round his\r\nneck, so as\xe2\x80\x94oh, vain and impotent attempt!\xe2\x80\x94to defeat the prophecy that\r\nhad foreshadowed his present position.\r\n\r\n~Shoes, children\xe2\x80\x99s, to make~, to suffer oneself to be made sport of, or\r\ndepreciated. Commonly used in Norfolk.\xe2\x80\x94_Cf._ Mrs. Behn\xe2\x80\x99s comedy, _The\r\nRoundheads_.\r\n\r\n    _Hews._ \xe2\x80\x9cWho, pox! shall we stand MAKING CHILDREN\xe2\x80\x99S SHOES all the\r\n    year? No: let\xe2\x80\x99s begin to settle the nation, I say, and go\r\n    through-stitch with our work.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n~Shoful~, a Hansom cab. This favourite carriage was the invention of a\r\nMr. Hansom, afterwards connected with the _Builder_ newspaper. It has\r\nbeen asserted that the term SHOFUL was derived from \xe2\x80\x9cshovel,\xe2\x80\x9d the\r\nearliest slang term applied to Hansoms by other cab-drivers, who\r\nconceived their shape to be after the fashion of a scoop or shovel. A\r\nlogical friend of the present Editor\xe2\x80\x99s argues thus:\xe2\x80\x94SHOFUL, full of\r\nshow, _ergo_, beautiful\xe2\x80\x94handsome\xe2\x80\x94Hansom. This is clever, but it\r\ncertainly never entered into the heads of those who gave the name of\r\nSHOFUL to the Hansom cabs.\r\n\r\n~Shoful~, bad or counterfeit money. Perhaps, as some think, from the\r\n_Danish_, SKUFFE, to shove, to deceive, cheat; _Saxon_, SCUFAN,\xe2\x80\x94whence\r\nthe _English_, SHOVE. The term, however, is possibly one of the many\r\nstreet words from the _Hebrew_ (through the low Jews); SHEPHEL, in that\r\nlanguage, signifying a low or debased estate. _Chaldee_, SHAPHAL.\xe2\x80\x94_See_\r\nPsalm cxxxvi. 23, \xe2\x80\x9cin our low estate.\xe2\x80\x9d A correspondent suggests a very\r\nprobable derivation, from the _German_, SCHOFEL, trash, rubbish,\xe2\x80\x94the\r\n_German_ adjective, SCHOFELIG, being the nearest possible translation\r\nof our shabby. SHOFUL means anything mock, as SHOFUL jewellery. A SHOFUL\r\nis also a humbug, an impostor.\r\n\r\n~Shoful-pitcher~, a passer of bad money. SHOFUL-PITCHING, passing bad\r\nmoney. \xe2\x80\x9cSnide-pitcher\xe2\x80\x9d and \xe2\x80\x9cSnide-pitching\xe2\x80\x9d are terms exchangeable with\r\nthe preceding.\r\n\r\n~Shoful pullet~, a \xe2\x80\x9cgay\xe2\x80\x9d or unsteady woman, especially a young woman.\r\n\r\n~Sholl~, to bonnet one, or crush a person\xe2\x80\x99s hat over his eyes.\xe2\x80\x94_North._\r\n\r\n~Shool~, to saunter idly, to become a vagabond, to beg rather than\r\nwork.\xe2\x80\x94_Smollett\xe2\x80\x99s Roderick Random_, vol. i., p. 262.\r\n\r\n~Shool~, Jews\xe2\x80\x99 term for their synagogue.\r\n\r\n~Shoot the cat~, to vomit. From a story of a man being sick in the back\r\nyard, and suffocating a cat and all her kittens.\r\n\r\n~Shoot the moon~, to remove furniture from a house in the night without\r\npaying the landlord.\r\n\r\n~Shop.~ In racing slang, to secure first, second, or third position in a\r\nrace, is to get a SHOP. This is also known as a place, and as a\r\nsituation. _See_ PLACE.\r\n\r\n~Shop~, a house. \xe2\x80\x9cHow are they all at your SHOP?\xe2\x80\x9d is a common question\r\namong small tradesmen.\r\n\r\n~Shop~, the House of Commons. The only instance we have met with of the\r\nuse of this word in literature occurs in Mr. Trollope\xe2\x80\x99s _Framley\r\nParsonage:_\xe2\x80\x94\r\n\r\n    \xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x98If we are merely to do as we are bid, and have no voice of our\r\n    own, I don\xe2\x80\x99t see what\xe2\x80\x99s the good of our going to the SHOP at all,\xe2\x80\x99\r\n    said Mr. Sowerby.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n~Shop~, to discharge a shopman. In military slang, to SHOP an officer is\r\nto put him under arrest in the guard-room. In pugilistic slang, to\r\npunish a man severely is \xe2\x80\x9cto knock him all over the SHOP,\xe2\x80\x9d _i.e._, the\r\nring, the place in which the work is done.\r\n\r\n~Shop-bouncer~, or SHOP-LIFTER, a person generally respectably attired,\r\nwho, while being served with a small article at a shop, steals one of\r\nmore value. Shakspeare has the word LIFTER, a thief.\r\n\r\n~Shop-walker~, a person employed to walk up and down a shop, to hand\r\nseats to customers, and see that they are properly served. Contracted\r\nalso to WALKER.\r\n\r\n~Shopping~, purchasing at shops. Termed by Todd a slang word, but used\r\nby Cowper and Byron.\r\n\r\n~Shoppy~, to be full of nothing but one\xe2\x80\x99s own calling or profession; \xe2\x80\x9cto\r\ntalk SHOP,\xe2\x80\x9d to converse of nothing but professional subjects.\r\n\r\n~Short~, when spirit is drunk without any admixture of water, it is said\r\nto be taken \xe2\x80\x9cSHORT;\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9csummat SHORT,\xe2\x80\x9d a dram. A similar phrase is used at\r\nthe counters of banks; upon presenting a cheque, the clerk asks, \xe2\x80\x9cHow\r\nwill you take it?\xe2\x80\x9d _i.e._, in gold, or notes. If in notes, long or\r\nshort? Should it be desired to receive it in notes for the largest\r\npossible amount, the answer is, SHORT. A conductor of an omnibus, or any\r\nother servant, is said to be SHORT when he does not give all the money\r\nhe receives to his master.\r\n\r\n~Short~, hard-up; a polite term for impecuniosity used in clubs and\r\namong military men.\r\n\r\n~Short commons~, short allowance of food. _See_ COMMONS.\r\n\r\n~Shorter~, one who makes a dishonest profit by reducing the coin of the\r\nrealm by clipping and filing. From a crown-piece a SHORTER could gain\r\n5d. Another way was by chemical means: a guinea laid in aquafortis\r\nwould, in twelve hours, precipitate 9d.-worth of sediment; in\r\ntwenty-four, 1s. 6d.-worth.\xe2\x80\x94_Rommany Rye._\r\n\r\n~Shot~, from the modern sense of the word to SHOOT,\xe2\x80\x94a guess, a random\r\nconjecture; \xe2\x80\x9cto make a bad SHOT,\xe2\x80\x9d to expose one\xe2\x80\x99s ignorance by making a\r\nwrong guess, or random answer, without knowing whether it is right or\r\nwrong.\r\n\r\n~Shot~, from the once general, but now provincial word, to SHOOT, to\r\nsubscribe, contribute in fair proportion;\xe2\x80\x94a share, from the\r\n_Anglo-Saxon_ word, SCEAT; \xe2\x80\x9cto pay one\xe2\x80\x99s SHOT,\xe2\x80\x9d _i.e._, share of the\r\nreckoning, &c.\r\n\r\n    \xe2\x80\x9cYet still while I have got\r\n    Enough to pay the SHOT\r\n    Of Boniface, both gruff and greedy O!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n        _Fisher\xe2\x80\x99s Garland_ for 1835.\r\n\r\n~Shot~, \xe2\x80\x9cI wish I may be SHOT, if,\xe2\x80\x9d &c., a common form of mild swearing.\r\n\r\n~Shot~, a term used among horse chaunters. To SHOT a horse, is to give\r\nhim a lot of small shot, which will for a short time effectually \xe2\x80\x9copen\r\nhis pipes,\xe2\x80\x9d and make him appear sound in wind.\r\n\r\n~Shot in the locker~, money in pocket, resource of any kind in\r\nstore.\xe2\x80\x94_Navy._\r\n\r\n~Shoulder~, when a servant embezzles his master\xe2\x80\x99s money, he is said to\r\nSHOULDER his employer.\r\n\r\n~Shout~, to pay for drink round. \xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s my SHOUT,\xe2\x80\x9d says he who pays.\r\nPossibly because the payer originally SHOUTED to the bar-keeper of an\r\nhotel to score the drink to him.\xe2\x80\x94_Australian_, but now general.\r\n\r\n~Shove-halfpenny~, a gambling pot-house pastime, played on a table. A\r\nvery old game, originally called push-penny.\r\n\r\n~Shove in the mouth~, a glass of spirits, which is taken off quickly and\r\nat once.\r\n\r\n~Shovel~, a term applied by the vulgar crowd to the inelegant twisted\r\nhats worn by the dignitaries of the Church. Dean Alford says, \xe2\x80\x9cI once\r\nheard a venerable dignitary pointed out by a railway porter as \xe2\x80\x9can old\r\nparty in a SHOVEL.\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94_Queen\xe2\x80\x99s English._\r\n\r\n~Shrimp~, a diminutive person.\xe2\x80\x94_Chaucer._\r\n\r\n~Shtumer~, a horse against which money may be laid without risk. _See_\r\nSAFE UN.\r\n\r\n~Shunt~, to avoid, to turn aside from. From the railway term.\r\n\r\n~Shut of~, or SHOT OF, _i.e._, rid of. A very common expression amongst\r\nthe London lower orders. One costermonger will say to another:\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cWell,\r\nIke, did yer get SHUT O\xe2\x80\x99 them there gawfs [apples]?\xe2\x80\x9d _i.e._, did you\r\nsell them all?\r\n\r\n~Shut up!~ be quiet, don\xe2\x80\x99t make a noise; to stop short, to cease in a\r\nsummary manner, to silence effectually. The following is from a literary\r\npaper:\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cOnly the other day we heard of a preacher who, speaking of the\r\nscene with the doctors in the Temple, remarked that the Divine disputant\r\ncompletely SHUT THEM UP!\xe2\x80\x9d SHUT UP, utterly exhausted, done for.\r\n\r\n~Shy~, a throw. _See_ the following:\xe2\x80\x94\r\n\r\n~Shy~, to fling; COCK-SHY, a game at fairs, consisting of throwing short\r\nsticks at trinkets or cocoanuts set upon other sticks,\xe2\x80\x94both name and\r\npractice derived from the old game of throwing or SHYING at live cocks.\r\nThis game is best known to the London public as \xe2\x80\x9cthree shies a penny.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n~Shy.~ \xe2\x80\x9cTo fight SHY of a person,\xe2\x80\x9d to avoid his society either from\r\ndislike, fear, or other reason. SHY has also the sense of flighty,\r\nunsteady, untrustworthy.\r\n\r\n~Shy~, to stop suddenly, or turn off, as a horse does when frightened.\r\n\r\n~Shyster~, a duffer, a vagabond. Variation of \xe2\x80\x9cshicer.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n~Sices~, or SIZES, a throw of sixes at dice.\r\n\r\n~Sick as a horse~, a popular simile,\xe2\x80\x94curious, because a horse never\r\nvomits.\r\n\r\n~Sickener~, a dose too much of anything. Too much of even a good thing\r\nwill make a man sick.\r\n\r\n~Side~, an affirmative expression in the cant language of the northern\r\ntowns. \xe2\x80\x9cDo you stoll the gammy?\xe2\x80\x9d (Do you understand cant?) \xe2\x80\x9cSIDE, cove\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n(yes, mate).\r\n\r\n~Side-boards~, or STICK-UPS, shirt collars. Name applied some years ago,\r\nbefore the present style of collars came into fashion.\r\n\r\n~Sift~, to embezzle small coins, those which might pass through a\r\nsieve\xe2\x80\x94as threepennies and fourpennies\xe2\x80\x94and which are, therefore, not\r\nlikely to be missed.\r\n\r\n~Sight~, \xe2\x80\x9cto take a SIGHT at a person,\xe2\x80\x9d a vulgar action employed by boys\r\nand others to denote incredulity, or contempt for authority, by placing\r\nthe thumb against the nose and extending the fingers, which are agitated\r\nin token of derision.\r\n\r\n    \xe2\x80\x9cThe sacristan he says no word that indicates a doubt,\r\n    But he puts his finger to his nose, and spreads his fingers out.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n        _Nell Cook._\r\n\r\n~Silly season~, the period when nobody is supposed to be in London, when\r\nthere are no parliamentary debates to publish, and when editors are at\r\ntheir wits\xe2\x80\x99-ends to fill their papers with readable matter. All kinds of\r\ncrazes on political and social subjects are then ventilated, gigantic\r\ngooseberries, monstrous births, and strange showers then become\r\nplentiful, columns are devoted to matters which would not at any other\r\ntime receive consideration, and, so far as the newspapers are concerned,\r\nsilliness is at a premium.\r\n\r\n~Silver beggar~, or LURKER, a vagabond who travels through the country\r\nwith \xe2\x80\x9cbriefs\xe2\x80\x9d containing false statements of losses by fire, shipwrecks,\r\naccidents, &c. Forged documents are exhibited with signatures of\r\nmagistrates and clergymen. Accompanying these are sham subscription\r\nbooks. The former, in beggar parlance, is termed \xe2\x80\x9ca sham,\xe2\x80\x9d whilst the\r\nlatter is denominated \xe2\x80\x9ca delicate.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n~Sim~, one of a Methodistical turn in religion; a Low Churchman;\r\noriginally a follower of the late Rev. Charles Simeon.\xe2\x80\x94_Cambridge._\r\n\r\n~Simon~, a sixpenny-piece.\r\n\r\n~Simon~, or SIMPLE SIMON, a credulous, gullible person. A character in a\r\nsong, but now common.\r\n\r\n~Simon Pure~, \xe2\x80\x9cthe real SIMON PURE,\xe2\x80\x9d the genuine article. Those who have\r\nwitnessed Mr. Charles Mathews\xe2\x80\x99s performance in Mrs. Centlivre\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nadmirable comedy of _A Bold Stroke for a Wife_, and the laughable\r\ncoolness with which he, the false SIMON PURE, assuming the Quaker dress\r\nand character of the real one, elbows that worthy out of his expected\r\nentertainment, will at once perceive the origin of this phrase.\xe2\x80\x94_See_\r\nact v. scene i.\r\n\r\n~Simpkin~, or SIMKIN, champagne.\xe2\x80\x94_Anglo-Indian._ Derived from the\r\nmanner in which native servants pronounce champagne.\r\n\r\n~Simpson~, water used in the dilution of milk. Term in use among\r\ncow-keepers. From this the parish pump has been called Mrs. SIMPSON.\r\n\r\n~Sing out~, to call aloud.\xe2\x80\x94_Sea._\r\n\r\n~Sing small~, to lessen one\xe2\x80\x99s boasting, and turn arrogance into\r\nhumility.\r\n\r\n~Sing-song~, a harmonic meeting at a pot-house, a free-and-easy.\r\n\r\n~Sinkers~, bad money,\xe2\x80\x94affording a man but little assistance in \xe2\x80\x9ckeeping\r\nafloat.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n~Sinks~, a throw of fives at dice. _French_, CINQ.\r\n\r\n~Si quis~, a candidate for \xe2\x80\x9corders.\xe2\x80\x9d From the notification commencing SI\r\nQUIS\xe2\x80\x94if any one.\r\n\r\n~Sir Harry~, a close stool.\r\n\r\n~Sir Reverence~, a corruption of the old phrase, SAVE YOUR REVERENCE, a\r\nsort of apology for alluding to anything likely to shock one\xe2\x80\x99s sense of\r\ndecency. _Latin_, SALV\xc3\x82 REVERENTI\xc3\x82. _See_ Shakspeare\xe2\x80\x99s _Romeo and\r\nJuliet_, act i. scene iv. From this it came to mean the thing\r\nitself\xe2\x80\x94human ordure generally, but sometimes other indecencies.\r\n\r\n~Siserara~, a hard blow.\xe2\x80\x94_Suffolk._ Many derive this term from the\r\nstory of Sisera in the Old Testament, but it is probably a corruption of\r\nCERTIORARI, a Chancery writ reciting a complaint of hard usage.\r\n\r\n~Sit under~, a term employed in Dissenters\xe2\x80\x99 meeting-houses, to denote\r\nattendance on the ministry of any particular preacher.\r\n\r\n~Sit upon~, to overcome or rebuke, to express contempt for a man in a\r\nmarked manner. Also, to chaff or \xe2\x80\x9croast\xe2\x80\x9d a man consumedly.\r\n\r\n~Sit-upons~, trousers. _See_ INEXPRESSIBLES.\r\n\r\n~Sivvy~, \xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x99pon my SIVVY,\xe2\x80\x9d _i.e._, upon my soul or honour. Corruption of\r\n\xe2\x80\x9casseveration,\xe2\x80\x9d like DAVY, which is an abridgment of \xe2\x80\x9caffidavit.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n~Sixes and sevens~, articles in confusion are said to be all SIXES AND\r\nSEVENS. The Deity is mentioned in the _Towneley Mysteries_ as He that\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cset all on seven,\xe2\x80\x9d _i.e._, set or appointed everything in seven days. A\r\nsimilar phrase at this early date implied confusion and disorder, and\r\nfrom these, Halliwell thinks, has been derived the phrase \xe2\x80\x9cto be at\r\nSIXES AND SEVENS.\xe2\x80\x9d A Scotch correspondent, however, states that the\r\nphrase probably came from the workshop, and that amongst needle-makers,\r\nwhen the points and eyes are \xe2\x80\x9cheads and tails\xe2\x80\x9d (\xe2\x80\x9cheeds and thraws\xe2\x80\x9d), or\r\nin confusion, they are said to be SIXES AND SEVENS, because those\r\nnumbers are the sizes most generally used, and in the course of\r\nmanufacture have frequently to be distinguished.\r\n\r\n~Sixty~, \xe2\x80\x9cto go along like SIXTY,\xe2\x80\x9d _i.e._, at a good rate, briskly.\r\n\r\n~Sixty-per-cent~, a bill-discounter. From the rate of interest generally\r\ncharged. If bill-discounters profess to do the business for less, they\r\ngenerally make up the level sixty by extras.\r\n\r\n~Six-water grog~, a sea-term for the weakest grog possible\xe2\x80\x94six portions\r\nof water to one of rum\xe2\x80\x94hardly enough spirit to \xe2\x80\x9cswear by.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n~Size~, to order extras over and above the usual commons at the dinner\r\nin college halls. Soup, pastry, &c., are SIZINGS, and are paid for at\r\na certain specified rate per SIZE, or portion, to the college cook.\r\nPeculiar to Cambridge. Minsheu says, \xe2\x80\x9cSIZE, a farthing which schollers\r\nin Cambridge have at the buttery, noted with the letter _s_.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n~Sizers~, or SIZARS, certain poor scholars at Cambridge, annually\r\nelected, who got their dinners (including \xe2\x80\x9csizings\xe2\x80\x9d) from what was left\r\nat the upper, or Fellows\xe2\x80\x99 table, free, or nearly so. They paid rent of\r\nrooms, and some other fees, on a lower scale than the \xe2\x80\x9cPensioners\xe2\x80\x9d or\r\nordinary students, and were equal with the \xe2\x80\x9cbattlers\xe2\x80\x9d and \xe2\x80\x9cservitors\xe2\x80\x9d at\r\nOxford.\r\n\r\n~Sizings.~ _See_ SIZE.\r\n\r\n~Skedaddle~, to go off in a hurry. The American war introduced this new\r\nand amusing word. A Northerner who retreated \xe2\x80\x9cretired upon his\r\nsupports,\xe2\x80\x9d but a Southerner was said to SKEDADDLE. The _Times_ remarked\r\non the word, and Lord Hill wrote to prove that it was excellent Scotch.\r\nThe Americans only misapply the word, which means, in Dumfries, \xe2\x80\x9cto\r\nspill\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94milkmaids, for example, saying, \xe2\x80\x9cYou are SKEDADDLING all that\r\nmilk.\xe2\x80\x9d The Yankees therefore adopted the term, and altered the\r\napplication.\r\n\r\n~Skid~, a sovereign. Fashionable slang. Occasionally SKIV.\r\n\r\n~Skid~, or SKIDPAN, an instrument for locking the wheel of a coach when\r\ngoing down hill. It is often said that a talkative person might put the\r\nSKID on, with advantage to his listeners, if not to himself.\r\n\r\n~Skied~, or SKYED, thrown upwards, as \xe2\x80\x9ccoppers\xe2\x80\x9d in tossing.\r\n\r\n~Skied.~ Artists say that a picture is SKIED when it is hung on the\r\nupper line at the Exhibition of the Royal Academy. _See_ FLOORED.\r\n\r\n~Skilligolee~, prison gruel. Also sailors\xe2\x80\x99 soup of many ingredients. The\r\nterm is occasionally used in London workhouses.\r\n\r\n~Skilly~, abbreviation of SKILLIGOLEE.\r\n\r\n~Skimmery~, St. Mary Hall, Oxford.\xe2\x80\x94_University._\r\n\r\n~Skin~, a purse. This term is mostly in use among thieves.\r\n\r\n~Skin~, to abate, or lower the value of anything; \xe2\x80\x9cthin-SKINNED,\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nsensitive, touchy, liable to be \xe2\x80\x9craw\xe2\x80\x9d on certain subjects.\r\n\r\n~Skin-the-lamb~, a game at cards, a very expressive corruption of the\r\nterm \xe2\x80\x9clansquenet,\xe2\x80\x9d also a racing term. When a non-favourite wins a race,\r\nbookmakers are said to SKIN THE LAMB, under the supposition that they\r\nwin all their bets, no person having backed the winner. This has been\r\ncorrupted into SKINNER.\r\n\r\n~Skinflint~, an old and popular simile for a \xe2\x80\x9cclose-fisted,\xe2\x80\x9d stingy\r\nperson. Sternberg, in his _Northamptonshire Glossary_, says the Eastern\r\nlanguages have the same expression. Abdul-Malek, one of the Ommeyade\r\nKhaliphs, noted for his extreme avarice, was surnamed Raschal-Hegiarah,\r\nliterally, \xe2\x80\x9cthe SKINNER of a FLINT.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n~Skinner~, a term among bookmakers. \xe2\x80\x9cMay we have a SKINNER,\xe2\x80\x9d _i.e._, may\r\nwe SKIN THE LAMB, which _see_.\r\n\r\n~Skipper~, the master of a vessel. _Germ._, SCHIFFER, from SCHIFF, a\r\nship; sometimes used as synonymous with \xe2\x80\x9cgovernor.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n~Skipper~, a barn.\xe2\x80\x94_Ancient Cant._ From the _Welsh_, YSGUBOR,\r\npronounced SCYBOR, or SCIBOR, the proper word in that language for a\r\nbarn.\r\n\r\n~Skipper-birds~, or KEYHOLE-WHISTLERS, persons who sleep in barns or\r\nouthouses from necessity or in preference to sleeping in lodging-houses.\r\n\r\n~Skipper-it~, to sleep in the open air, or in a rough way.\r\n\r\n~Skit~, a joke, a squib. Term generally used in reference to any pungent\r\nor pointed political allusion.\r\n\r\n~Skittles~, a game similar to that of Ten Pins, which, when interdicted\r\nby the Government, was altered to Nine Pins, or SKITTLES. The pins are\r\nset up in an alley, and thrown (not bowled) at with a round piece of\r\nhard wood, shaped like a small flat cheese. The costers used to consider\r\nthemselves the best players in London, but they have been frequently\r\nundeceived. SKITTLES has within the past few years received an awful\r\nblow\xe2\x80\x94quite a floorer\xe2\x80\x94from \xe2\x80\x9cthe powers that be.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n~Skow-banker~, a fellow who loiters about the premises of any one\r\nwilling to support him, and who objects to the necessity of working for\r\nhis living; a rogue, a rascal. Common in Melbourne, Australia.\r\n\r\n~Skrouge~, to push or squeeze.\xe2\x80\x94_North._\r\n\r\n~Skull-thatcher~, a straw-bonnet-maker,\xe2\x80\x94sometimes called \xe2\x80\x9ca\r\nbonnet-BUILDER.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n~Skunk~, a mean or paltry fellow, one whose name stinks.\r\n\r\n~Sky~, a disagreeable person, an enemy.\xe2\x80\x94_Westminster School._ The word\r\nderived its origin from a corruption of the last syllable of the word\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cVOLSCI:\xe2\x80\x9d Westminster boys being of course understood to be the Romans.\r\n\r\n~Sky~, to toss up towards the SKY. Term used in tossing with halfpence;\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s all right, Jim SKIED the browns,\xe2\x80\x9d _i.e._, threw them up, a proof\r\nthat there could have been no collusion or cheating.\r\n\r\n~Sky-blue~, London milk much diluted with water, or from which the cream\r\nhas been too closely skimmed.\r\n\r\n    \xe2\x80\x9cHence, Suffolk dairy wives run mad for cream,\r\n    And leave their milk with nothing but the name;\r\n    Its name derision and reproach pursue,\r\n    And strangers tell of three-times-skimm\xe2\x80\x99d\xe2\x80\x94SKY-BLUE.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n        _Bloomfield\xe2\x80\x99s Farmer\xe2\x80\x99s Boy._\r\n\r\nThe recent Adulteration Act has done away with SKY-BLUE, and made\r\nSimpson a relic of the past. SKY-BLUE formerly meant gin.\r\n\r\n~Sky-lark.~ _See under_ LARK.\r\n\r\n~Sky-parlour~, the garret.\r\n\r\n~Sky-scraper~, a tall man; \xe2\x80\x9cAre you cold up there, old SKY-SCRAPER?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nProperly a sea-term. The light sails, which some adventurous skippers\r\nset above the royals in calm latitudes, are termed SKY-SCRAPERS and\r\nMOON-RAKERS.\r\n\r\n~Sky-wannocking~, unsteady frolicking.\xe2\x80\x94_Norfolk._\r\n\r\n~Slab~, thick, as gruel, porridge, &c.\r\n\r\n~Slack~, \xe2\x80\x9cto hold on the SLACK,\xe2\x80\x9d to skulk; a slack rope not requiring to\r\nbe held.\xe2\x80\x94_Sea._\r\n\r\n~Slam~, a term at the game of whist. When two partners gain the whole\r\nthirteen tricks, they win a SLAM, which is considered equal to a\r\nrubber.\r\n\r\n~Slam~, to talk fluently. \xe2\x80\x9cHe\xe2\x80\x99s the bloke to SLAM.\xe2\x80\x9d From a term in use\r\namong birdsingers at the East-end, by which they denote a certain style\r\nof note in chaffinches.\r\n\r\n~Slammock~, a slattern or awkward person.\xe2\x80\x94_West_, and _Norfolk_.\r\n\r\n~Slang~, low, vulgar, unwritten, or unauthorized language. _Gipsy_,\r\nSLANG, the secret language of the gipsies, synonymous with GIBBERISH,\r\nanother gipsy word. The word is only to be found in the dictionaries of\r\nWebster and Ogilvie. It is given, however, by Grose, in his _Dictionary\r\nof the Vulgar Tongue_, 1785. SLANG, since it has been adopted as an\r\nEnglish word, generally implies vulgar language not known or recognised\r\nas CANT; and latterly, when applied to speech, it has superseded the\r\nword FLASH. Latterly, however, SLANG has become the generic term for all\r\nunauthorized language. The earliest instance of the use of the word that\r\ncan be found, is the following:\xe2\x80\x94\r\n\r\n    \xe2\x80\x9cLet proper nurses be assigned, to take care of these babes of\r\n    grace, [young thieves].... The master who teaches them should be a\r\n    man well versed in the cant language commonly called the SLANG\r\n    patter, in which they should by all means excel.\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94_Jonathan Wild\xe2\x80\x99s\r\n    Advice to his Successor._ LONDON, _J. Scott_, 1758.\r\n\r\n~Slang~, a travelling show.\r\n\r\n~Slang~, to cheat, to abuse in foul language.\r\n\r\n~Slang~, counterfeit or short weights and measures. A SLANG quart is a\r\npint and a half. SLANG measures are lent out at 2d. per day to street\r\nsalesmen. The term is used principally by costermongers.\r\n\r\n~Slang~, a watch-chain. SUPER and SLANG, a watch and chain.\r\n\r\n~Slang~, \xe2\x80\x9cout on the SLANG,\xe2\x80\x9d _i.e._, to travel with a hawker\xe2\x80\x99s licence.\r\n\r\n~Slang-whanger~, a long-winded speaker.\xe2\x80\x94_Parliamentary._\r\n\r\n~Slangy~, flashy, vulgar; loud in dress, manner, and conversation.\r\n\r\n~Slantingdicular~, oblique, awry,\xe2\x80\x94as opposed to PERPENDICULAR.\r\nOriginally an Americanism, now a part of the vocabulary of London \xe2\x80\x9chigh\r\nlife below stairs.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n~Slap~, paint for the face, rouge.\r\n\r\n~Slap~, exactly, precisely; \xe2\x80\x9cSLAP in the wind\xe2\x80\x99s eye,\xe2\x80\x9d _i.e._, exactly to\r\nwindward.\r\n\r\n~Slap-bang~, suddenly, violently. From the strike of a ball being felt\r\nbefore the report reaches the ear,\xe2\x80\x94the SLAP first, the BANG afterwards.\r\n\r\n~Slap-bang-shops~, originally low eating-houses where the ready-money\r\nwas paid down with a SLAP-BANG.\xe2\x80\x94_Grose._ A SLAP-BANG-SHOP is now a very\r\npretentious eating-house.\r\n\r\n~Slap-dash~, immediately, or quickly; at a great rate.\r\n\r\n~Slap-up~, first-rate, excellent, very good.\r\n\r\n~Slasher~, a powerful roysterer, a game and clever pugilist.\r\n\r\n~Slashers~, the Twenty-eighth Regiment of Foot in the British army.\r\n\r\n~Slate~, \xe2\x80\x9che has a SLATE loose,\xe2\x80\x9d _i.e._, he is slightly crazy.\r\n\r\n~Slate~, to pelt with abuse, to beat, to \xe2\x80\x9click;\xe2\x80\x9d or, in the language of\r\nthe reviewers, to \xe2\x80\x9ccut up.\xe2\x80\x9d Also, among bettors, to lay heavily against\r\na particular man or animal in a race.\r\n\r\n~Slate~, to knock the hat over one\xe2\x80\x99s eyes, to bonnet.\xe2\x80\x94_North._\r\n\r\n~Slavey~, a maid-servant.\r\n\r\n~Slawmineyeux~, a Dutchman. Probably a corruption of the Dutch, _ja,\r\nmynheer_; or German, _ja, mein Herr_.\xe2\x80\x94_Sea._\r\n\r\n~Sleepless-hats~, those of a napless character, better known as\r\nWIDE-AWAKES.\r\n\r\n~Slender~, a simple country gentleman.\xe2\x80\x94_Shakspeare._\r\n\r\n~Slewed~, drunk, or intoxicated.\xe2\x80\x94_Sea term._ When a vessel changes the\r\ntack, she, as it were, staggers, the sails flap, she gradually heels\r\nover, and the wind catching the waiting canvas, she glides off at\r\nanother angle. The course pursued by an intoxicated, or SLEWED, man, is\r\nsupposed to be analogous to that of the ship.\r\n\r\n~Slick~, an Americanism, very prevalent in England since the publication\r\nof Judge Haliburton\xe2\x80\x99s facetious stories, which means rapidly,\r\neffectually, utterly.\r\n\r\n~Slick~, smooth, unctuous; abbreviation of sleek.\r\n\r\n~Sling~, a drink peculiar to Americans, generally composed of gin,\r\nsoda-water, ice, and slices of lemon. At some houses in London\r\nGIN-SLINGS may be obtained.\r\n\r\n~Sling~, to pass from one person to another. To blow the nose with the\r\nnaked fingers.\r\n\r\n~Sling your hook~, a polite invitation to move-on. \xe2\x80\x9cSling your Daniel\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nhas the same meaning. The pronouns may be altered to suit the context.\r\n\r\n~Slip~, \xe2\x80\x9cto give the SLIP,\xe2\x80\x9d to run away, or elude pursuit. Shakspeare\r\nhas, \xe2\x80\x9cYou gave me the counterfeit,\xe2\x80\x9d in _Romeo and Juliet_. Giving the\r\nSLIP, however, is a sea phrase, and refers to fastening an anchor and\r\nchain cable to a floating buoy, or water-cask, until a time arrives when\r\nit is convenient to return and take them on board. In fastening the\r\ncable, the home end is SLIPPED through the hawse-pipe. Weighing anchor\r\nis a noisy task, so that giving the SLIP infers leaving quietly.\r\n\r\n~Slip~, or let SLIP; \xe2\x80\x9cto SLIP into a man,\xe2\x80\x9d to give him a sound beating,\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cto let SLIP at a cove,\xe2\x80\x9d to rush violently upon him, and assault with\r\nvigour.\r\n\r\n~Slipping~, a trick of card-sharpers, in the performance of which, by\r\ndexterous manipulation, they place the cut card on the top, instead of\r\nat the bottom of the pack. It is the _faire sauter la coupe_ of the\r\nFrench. In pugilistic parlance, \xe2\x80\x9cto SLIP a man,\xe2\x80\x9d is to \xe2\x80\x9cduck and get\r\naway\xe2\x80\x9d with great dexterity.\r\n\r\n~Slips~, the sides of the gallery in a theatre are generally so called.\r\n\r\n~Slog~, to beat or baste, to fight. _German_, SCHLACHTEN; or perhaps\r\nfrom some connexion with the _Gaelic_ SLOGAN. The pretended _Greek_\r\nderivation from \xcf\x83\xce\xbb\xce\xbf\xce\xb3\xcf\x89 is humbug, there being no such word in the\r\nlanguage.\r\n\r\n~Slogdollager~, an Americanism, meaning the same as our STOCKDOLLAGER,\r\nwhich _see_.\r\n\r\n~Sloggers~, _i.e._, SLOW-GOERS, the second division of race-boats at\r\nCambridge. At Oxford they are called TORPIDS.\xe2\x80\x94_University._ A hard\r\nhitter at cricket is termed a SLOGGER; so is a pugilist.\r\n\r\n~Slogging~, a good beating.\r\n\r\n~Slop~, a policeman. At first back slang, but now modified for general\r\nuse.\r\n\r\n~Slop~, cheap, or ready-made, as applied to clothing, is generally\r\nsupposed to be a modern appropriation; but it was used in this sense in\r\n1691, by Maydman, in his _Naval Speculations_; and by Chaucer two\r\ncenturies before that. SLOPS properly signify sailors\xe2\x80\x99 working clothes,\r\nwhich are of a very cheap and inexpensive character.\r\n\r\n~Slope~, to decamp, to run, or rather slip away. Some persons think it\r\ncame originally from LOPE, to make off; and that the _s_ probably became\r\naffixed as a portion of the preceding word, as in the case of \xe2\x80\x9cLet\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nlope,\xe2\x80\x9d let us run. It is purely an Americanism, and is possibly but an\r\nemendation of our own word elope. Lope, leap, and elope are kindred. A\r\nhumorous correspondent says that Tennyson is decidedly partial to slang,\r\nand instances amongst other proofs a passage from the laureate\xe2\x80\x99s famous\r\n_Locksley Hall_:\xe2\x80\x94\r\n\r\n    \xe2\x80\x9cMany a night, from yonder ivied casement, ere I went to rest,\r\n    Did I look on great Orion SLOPING slowly to the west.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThough this correspondent may not have intended it, his joke has given\r\nthe key to the situation, and has shown how our cousins most probably\r\ncame to use the word in its present sense. \xe2\x80\x9cThe sun is SLOPING fast.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n~Slops~, any weak, wet, and warm mixture. Hard drinkers regard all\r\neffeminate beverages as SLOPS.\r\n\r\n~Slops~, chests or packages of tea; \xe2\x80\x9che shook a slum of SLOPS,\xe2\x80\x9d _i.e._,\r\nstole a chest of tea. Also ready-made clothes\xe2\x80\x94the substantive of SLOP.\r\n\r\n~Slops~, liquid house-refuse.\r\n\r\n~Slopshop~, a tailor\xe2\x80\x99s shop where inferior work is done, and where cheap\r\ngoods are sold.\r\n\r\n~Slour~, to lock, or fasten.\xe2\x80\x94_Prison Cant._\r\n\r\n~Sloured~, buttoned up; SLOURED HOXTER, an inside pocket buttoned up.\r\n\r\n~Slowcoach~, a lumbering, dull person; one slow of comprehension.\r\n\r\n~Slowed~, to be locked up (in prison).\r\n\r\n~Slubberdegullion~, a paltry, dirty, sorry wretch.\r\n\r\n    \xe2\x80\x9cQuoth she, although thou hast deserved,\r\n    Base SLUBBERDEGULLION, to be served\r\n    As thou didst vow to deal with me,\r\n    If thou hadst got the victory\xe2\x80\x9d----\r\n\r\n        _Hudibras._\r\n\r\n~Sluicery~, a gin-shop or public-house.\r\n\r\n~Sluicing one\xe2\x80\x99s bolt~, drinking.\r\n\r\n~Slum~, a chest, or package. _See_ SLOPS.\r\n\r\n~Slum~, a letter.\xe2\x80\x94_Prison Cant._\r\n\r\n~Slum~, an insinuation, a discreditable innuendo.\r\n\r\n~Slum~, gammon, \xe2\x80\x9cup to SLUM,\xe2\x80\x9d wide awake, knowing.\r\n\r\n    \xe2\x80\x9cAnd this, without more SLUM began,\r\n    Over a flowing pot-house can,\r\n    To settle, without botheration,\r\n    The rigs of this here tip-top nation.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n        _Jack Randall\xe2\x80\x99s Diary_, 1820.\r\n\r\n~Slum~, or BACK SLUM, a dark retreat, a low neighbourhood; as\r\nWestminster and East-end SLUMS, favourite haunts for thieves.\r\n\r\n~Slum~, to hide, to pass to a confederate.\r\n\r\n~Slum~, to saunter about, with a suspicion, perhaps, of immoral\r\npursuits.\xe2\x80\x94_Cambridge University Slang_.\r\n\r\n~Slum the gorger~, to cheat on the sly, to be an eye-servant. SLUM in\r\nthis sense is old cant.\r\n\r\n~Slumgullion~, any cheap, nasty, washy beverage. An Americanism best\r\nknown in the Pacific States.\r\n\r\n~Slumming~, passing bad money.\r\n\r\n~Slush~, the grease obtained from boiling the salt pork eaten by seamen,\r\nand generally the cook\xe2\x80\x99s perquisite.\r\n\r\n~Slushy~, a ship\xe2\x80\x99s cook.\r\n\r\n~Sluter~, butter.\xe2\x80\x94_North._\r\n\r\n~Smack smooth~, even, level with the surface, quickly.\r\n\r\n~Small-beer;~ \xe2\x80\x9che doesn\xe2\x80\x99t think SMALL-BEER of himself,\xe2\x80\x9d _i.e._, he has a\r\ngreat opinion of his own importance. SMALL COALS is also used in the\r\nsame sense.\r\n\r\n~Small hours~, the early hours after midnight.\r\n\r\n~Small potatoes~, a term of contempt. \xe2\x80\x9cHe\xe2\x80\x99s very SMALL POTATOES,\xe2\x80\x9d he\xe2\x80\x99s a\r\nnobody. Yet no one thinks of calling an important personage \xe2\x80\x9clarge\r\nPOTATOES.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n~Smalls~, a University term for the first general examination of the\r\nstudent. It is used at Cambridge, but properly belongs to Oxford. The\r\nCambridge term is \xe2\x80\x9clittle go.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n~Smash~, to become bankrupt, or worthless; \xe2\x80\x9cto go all to SMASH,\xe2\x80\x9d to\r\nbreak, \xe2\x80\x9cgo to the dogs,\xe2\x80\x9d or fall in pieces.\r\n\r\n~Smash~, to pass counterfeit money.\r\n\r\n~Smasher~, one who passes bad coin, or forged notes.\r\n\r\n~Smashfeeder~, a Britannia-metal spoon,\xe2\x80\x94the best imitation shillings\r\nare made from this metal.\r\n\r\n~Smash-man-Geordie~, a pitman\xe2\x80\x99s oath.\xe2\x80\x94_Durham_ and _Northumberland._ _See_\r\nGEORDIE.\r\n\r\n~Smeller~, the nose; \xe2\x80\x9ca blow on the SMELLER\xe2\x80\x9d is often to be found in\r\npugilistic records. Otherwise a NOSE-ENDER.\r\n\r\n~Smish~, a shirt, or chemise.\r\n\r\n~Smithers~, or SMITHEREENS; \xe2\x80\x9call to SMITHEREENS,\xe2\x80\x9d all to smash, SMITHER\r\nis a Lincolnshire word for a fragment.\r\n\r\n~Smock-face~, a white delicate face,\xe2\x80\x94a face without whiskers.\r\n\r\n~Smoke~, London. From the peculiar dense cloud which overhangs London.\r\nThe metropolis is by no means so smoky as Sheffield, Birmingham, &c.;\r\nyet country-people, when going to London, frequently say they are on\r\ntheir way to the SMOKE; and Londoners, when leaving for the country, say\r\nthey are going out of the SMOKE.\r\n\r\n~Smoke~, to detect, or penetrate an artifice. Originally used by London\r\ndetectives, probably on account of their clouded intellects.\r\n\r\n~Smudge~, to smear, obliterate, daub. Corruption of SMUTCH.\r\n\r\n~Smug~, smuggling.\xe2\x80\x94_Anglo-Chinese._\r\n\r\n~Smug~, extremely neat, after the fashion, in order.\r\n\r\n~Smug~, sleek, comfortable. Term often applied to a seemingly pious\r\nhumbug, more of the Chadband than the Stiggins.\r\n\r\n~Smuggings~, snatchings, or purloinings,\xe2\x80\x94shouted out by boys, when\r\nsnatching the tops, or small play property, of other lads, and then\r\nrunning off at full speed.\r\n\r\n    \xe2\x80\x9cTops are in; spin \xe2\x80\x99em agin.\r\n    Tops are out; SMUGGING\xe2\x80\x99S about.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n~Smut~, a copper boiler. Also, the \xe2\x80\x9cblacks\xe2\x80\x9d from a furnace.\r\n\r\n~Smutty~, obscene,\xe2\x80\x94vulgar as applied to conversation. Variation of\r\ndirty.\r\n\r\n~Snack~, a share or division of plunder. To \xe2\x80\x9cgo SNACKS,\xe2\x80\x9d to divide\r\nequally. Also, a light repast.\xe2\x80\x94_Old Cant_ and _Gipsy term_.\r\n\r\n~Snack~, to quiz or chaff with regard to a particular weakness or recent\r\ntransaction. As a substantive in this sense SNACK means an innuendo.\r\n\r\n~Snaffle~, conversation on professional or private subjects which the\r\nrest of the company cannot appreciate. In _East Anglia_, to SNAFFLE is\r\nto talk foolishly.\r\n\r\n~Snaffled~, arrested, \xe2\x80\x9cpulled up,\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94so termed from a kind of horse\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nbit called a SNAFFLE.\r\n\r\n~Snaggle teeth~, those that are uneven, and unpleasant looking.\xe2\x80\x94_West._\r\n\r\n~Snaggling~, angling after geese with a hook and line, the bait being a\r\nworm or snail. The goose swallows the bait, and is quietly landed and\r\nbagged. See Seymour\xe2\x80\x99s _Sketches_.\r\n\r\n~Snaggy~, cross, crotchety, malicious.\r\n\r\n~Snam~, to snatch, or rob from the person. Mostly used to describe that\r\nkind of theft which consists in picking up anything lying about, and\r\nmaking off with it rapidly.\r\n\r\n~Snaps~, share, portion; any articles or circumstances out of which\r\nmoney may be made; \xe2\x80\x9clooking out for SNAPS,\xe2\x80\x9d waiting for windfalls, or\r\nodd jobs.\xe2\x80\x94_Old._ _Scotch_, CHITS, term also used for \xe2\x80\x9ccoppers,\xe2\x80\x9d or\r\nhalfpence.\r\n\r\n~Snapps~, spirits. _Dutch_, SCHNAPPS. The word, as originally\r\npronounced, is used by East-end Jews to describe any kind of spirits,\r\nand the Gentiles get as near as they can.\r\n\r\n~Sneaksman~, a shoplifter; a petty, cowardly thief.\r\n\r\n~Sneeze-lurker~, a thief who throws snuff in a person\xe2\x80\x99s face, and then\r\nrobs him.\r\n\r\n~Sneezer~, a snuff-box; a pocket-handkerchief.\r\n\r\n~Snell-fencer~, a street salesman of needles. SNELLS are needles.\r\n\r\n~Snick-ersnee~, a knife.\xe2\x80\x94_Sea._ Thackeray uses the term in his humorous\r\nballad of _Little Billee_.\r\n\r\n~Snicker~, a drinking-cup. A HORN-SNICKER, a drinking-horn.\r\n\r\n~Snid~, a sixpence.\xe2\x80\x94_Scotch._\r\n\r\n~Snide~, bad, spurious, contemptible. As, \xe2\x80\x9ca SNIDE fellow,\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9cSNIDE\r\ncoin,\xe2\x80\x9d &c. Also used as a substantive, as, \xe2\x80\x9cHe\xe2\x80\x99s a SNIDE,\xe2\x80\x9d though this\r\nseems but a contraction of SNIDE \xe2\x80\x99UN.\r\n\r\n~Snigger~, to laugh in a covert manner. Also a mild form of\r\nswearing,\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m SNIGGERED if you will.\xe2\x80\x9d Another form of this latter is\r\nJIGGERED.\r\n\r\n~Sniggering~, laughing to oneself.\xe2\x80\x94_East._\r\n\r\n~Snip~, a tailor,\xe2\x80\x94apparently from SNIPES, a pair of scissors, or from\r\nthe snipping sound made by scissors in cutting up anything.\r\n\r\n~Snipe~, a long bill or account; also a term for attorneys,\xe2\x80\x94a race with\r\na remarkable propensity for long bills.\r\n\r\n~Snipes~, \xe2\x80\x9ca pair of SNIPES,\xe2\x80\x9d a pair of scissors. They are occasionally\r\nmade in the form of a snipe.\r\n\r\n~Snitch~, to give information to the police, to turn approver. SNITCHING\r\nis synonymous in thieves\xe2\x80\x99 slang with \xe2\x80\x9cnosing\xe2\x80\x9d and \xe2\x80\x9cpeaching.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n~Snitchers~, persons who turn Queen\xe2\x80\x99s evidence, or who tell tales. In\r\n_Scotland_, SNITCHERS signify handcuffs.\r\n\r\n~Snob~, a low, vulgar, or affected person. Supposed to be from the\r\nnickname usually applied to a cobbler or maker of shoes; but believed\r\nby many in its later sense to be a contraction of the _Latin_, SINE\r\nOBOLO. Others go to work for an etymology thus:\xe2\x80\x94They assume that NOBS,\r\n_i.e._, _nobiles_, was appended in lists to the names of persons of\r\ngentle birth, whilst those who had not that distinction were marked down\r\nas S NOB, _i.e._, _sine nobilitate_, without marks of gentility,\xe2\x80\x94thus,\r\nby a simple transposition, quite reversing the meaning. Others, again,\r\nremark that, as at college sons of noblemen wrote after their names in\r\nthe admission lists, _fil. nob._, son of a lord, and hence all young\r\nnoblemen were called NOBS, and what they did NOBBY, so those who\r\nimitated them would be called _quasi-nobs_, \xe2\x80\x9clike a nob,\xe2\x80\x9d which by a\r\nprocess of contraction would be shortened to _si-nob_, and then SNOB,\r\none who pretends to be what he is not, and apes his betters. The short\r\nand expressive terms which many think fitly represent the three great\r\nestates of the realm\xe2\x80\x94NOB, SNOB, and MOB\xe2\x80\x94were all originally slang\r\nwords. The last has safely passed through the vulgar ordeal of the\r\nstreets, and found respectable quarters in the standard dictionaries.\r\nFor fuller particulars of the genus SNOB, in all its ramifications, the\r\nreader cannot do better than apply to the general works of that great\r\nmaster of the subject, William Makepeace Thackeray, though it may be as\r\nwell to remark that the SNOB for whom the novelist had such an aversion\r\nis now very widely known as \xe2\x80\x9ccad.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n~Snobbish~, stuck up, proud, make-believe.\r\n\r\n~Snob-Stick~, a workman who refuses to join in strikes, or trade-unions.\r\nAmplification of KNOB-STICK.\r\n\r\n~Snooks~, an imaginary personage often brought forward as the answer to\r\nan idle question, or as the perpetrator of a senseless joke. Said to be\r\nsimply a shortening or abbreviation of \xe2\x80\x9cSevenoaks,\xe2\x80\x9d the Kentish village.\r\n\r\n~Snooze~, or SNOODGE (vulgar pronunciation), to sleep or doze.\r\n\r\n~Snooze-case~, a pillow-slip.\r\n\r\n~Snorter~, a blow on the nose. A hurry is sometimes called a \xe2\x80\x9creg\xe2\x80\x99lar\r\nSNORTER.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n~Snot~, a term of reproach applied to persons by the vulgar when vexed\r\nor annoyed, meaning really a person of the vilest description and\r\nmeanest capacity. In a Westminster school vocabulary for boys, published\r\nin the last century, the term is curiously applied. Its proper meaning\r\nis the glandular mucus discharged through the nose.\r\n\r\n~Snot~, a small bream, a slimy kind of flat fish.\xe2\x80\x94_Norwich._\r\n\r\n~Snotter~, or WIPE-HAULER, a pickpocket whose chief fancy is for\r\ngentlemen\xe2\x80\x99s pocket-handkerchiefs.\xe2\x80\x94_North._\r\n\r\n~Snottinger~, a coarse word for a pocket-handkerchief. The German\r\n_Schnupftuch_ is, however, nearly as plain. A handkerchief was also\r\nanciently called a \xe2\x80\x9cmuckinger\xe2\x80\x9d or \xe2\x80\x9cmuckender,\xe2\x80\x9d and from that a\r\nneckerchief was called a \xe2\x80\x9cneckinger.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n~Snow~, wet linen, or linen hung out to dry.\xe2\x80\x94_Old Cant._\r\n\r\n~Snow-gatherer~, or SNOW-DROPPER, a rogue who steals linen from hedges\r\nand drying-grounds.\r\n\r\n~Snuff~, \xe2\x80\x9cup to SNUFF,\xe2\x80\x9d knowing and sharp; \xe2\x80\x9cto take SNUFF,\xe2\x80\x9d to be\r\noffended. Shakspeare uses SNUFF in the sense of anger, or passion.\r\n\r\n~Snuff it~, to die. Term very common among the lower orders of London. A\r\nfanciful variation of \xe2\x80\x9cputting one\xe2\x80\x99s light out,\xe2\x80\x9d and used simply in\r\nreference to the action of the person dying. Thus any one threatening to\r\nmurder another says, \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ll put your light out,\xe2\x80\x9d or any one committing\r\nsuicide is said to \xe2\x80\x9cput his own light out;\xe2\x80\x9d but to \xe2\x80\x9cSNUFF IT\xe2\x80\x9d is always\r\nto die from disease or accident. To \xe2\x80\x9clay down one\xe2\x80\x99s knife and fork,\xe2\x80\x9d to\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cpeg out,\xe2\x80\x9d or \xe2\x80\x9cgive up,\xe2\x80\x9d are variations of this form of euphemism.\r\n\r\n~Snuffy~, tipsy, drunk.\r\n\r\n~Snuggle~, to lie closely and cosily.\r\n\r\n~Snyder~, a tailor. _German_, SCHNEIDER.\r\n\r\n~Soaker~, an habitual drunkard.\r\n\r\n~Soap~, flattery. _See_ SOFT SOAP.\r\n\r\n~Sober-water~, a jocular allusion to the uses of soda-water.\r\n\r\n~Social evil~, a name for some years applied to our street-walking\r\nsystem, in consequence of the articles in the newspapers which treat on\r\nthe evils of prostitution being so headed. A good story has been often\r\ntold on this subject, which will bear repeating:\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cA well-known divine\r\nand philanthropist was walking in a crowded street at night in order to\r\ndistribute tracts to promising subjects. A young woman was walking up\r\nand down, and he accosted her. He pointed out to her the error of her\r\nways, implored her to reform, and tendered her a tract with fervent\r\nentreaties to go home and read it. The girl stared at him for a moment\r\nor two in sheer bewilderment; at last it dawned on her what he meant,\r\nand for what he took her, and looking up in his face with simple\r\namazement, she exclaimed, \xe2\x80\x98Lor\xe2\x80\x99 bless you, sir, I ain\xe2\x80\x99t a SOCIAL EVIL;\r\nI\xe2\x80\x99m waitin\xe2\x80\x99 for the \xe2\x80\x99bus!\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d The enthusiasm which was felt in this\r\ndirection a few years back has received considerable modification, as it\r\nhas been proved that the efforts of the promoters of midnight meetings\r\nand other arrangements of a similar nature, praiseworthy though they\r\nare, have little or no effect; and that the early-closing movement in\r\nthe Haymarket has done more to stamp out the SOCIAL EVIL than years of\r\npreaching, even when accompanied by tea and buns, could ever have done.\r\n\r\n~Sock~, the Eton College term for a treat, synonymous with \xe2\x80\x9cchuck\xe2\x80\x9d used\r\nat Westminster and other schools. Believed to be derived from the\r\nmonkish word SOKE. An old writer speaks of a pious man \xe2\x80\x9cwho did not SOKE\r\nfor three days,\xe2\x80\x9d meaning that he fasted. The word is still used by the\r\nboys of Heriot\xe2\x80\x99s Hospital School at Edinburgh, and signifies a\r\nsweetmeat; being derived from the same source as sugar, _suck_, SUCRE,\r\n&c.\r\n\r\n~Sock~, credit. As, \xe2\x80\x9cHe gets his goods on SOCK, while I pay ready.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n~Sock into him~, _i.e._, give him a good drubbing; \xe2\x80\x9cgive him SOCK,\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n_i.e._, thrash him well.\r\n\r\n~Sockdolager.~ _See_ STOCKDOLLAGER.\r\n\r\n~Socket-money~, money extorted by threats of exposure. To be applied to\r\nfor SOCKET-MONEY is perhaps one of the most terrible inflictions that\r\ncan befall a respectable man. SOCKETERS, as the applicants are called,\r\nshould be punished with the utmost possible severity.\r\n\r\n~Sodom~, a nickname for Wadham, due to the similarity of the\r\nsounds.\xe2\x80\x94_Oxford University._\r\n\r\n~Soft~, foolish, inexperienced. A term for bank-notes.\r\n\r\n~Soft-horn~, a simpleton; literally a donkey, whose ears, the\r\nsubstitutes of horns, are soft.\r\n\r\n~Soft-sawder~, flattery easily laid on or received. Probably introduced\r\nby Sam Slick.\r\n\r\n~Soft-soap~, or soft-sawder, flattery, ironical praise.\r\n\r\n~Soft-tack~, bread.\xe2\x80\x94_Sea._\r\n\r\n~Soft-tommy~, loaf-bread, in contradistinction to hard biscuit.\r\n\r\n~Soiled doves~, the \xe2\x80\x9cMidnight Meeting\xe2\x80\x9d term for prostitutes and \xe2\x80\x9cgay\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nladies generally.\r\n\r\n~Sold~, \xe2\x80\x9cSOLD again! and got the money,\xe2\x80\x9d gulled, deceived. _Vide_ SELL.\r\n\r\n~Sold up~, or OUT, broken down, bankrupt.\r\n\r\n~Soldier~, a red herring. Common term in seaport towns, where exchange\r\nis made, a soldier being called by the fishy title.\r\n\r\n~Something damp~, a dram, a drink.\r\n\r\n~Son of a gun~, a familiar term for a man. Sometimes applied\r\neulogistically, never contemptuously. Generally said of an artful\r\nperson, and perhaps, originally, son of a \xe2\x80\x9cgun,\xe2\x80\x9d (or \xe2\x80\x9cgonnof\xe2\x80\x9d). In the\r\narmy it is sometimes applied to an artilleryman.\r\n\r\n~Sonkey~, a clumsy, awkward fellow.\r\n\r\n~Soor~, an abusive term. _Hindostanee_, a pig.\xe2\x80\x94_Anglo-Indian._\r\n\r\n~Soot-bag~, a reticule.\r\n\r\n~Sop~, a soft or foolish man. Abbreviation of MILKSOP.\r\n\r\n~Soph~ (abbreviation of \xe2\x80\x9csophister\xe2\x80\x9d), a title peculiar to the University\r\nof Cambridge. Undergraduates are junior SOPHS before passing their\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLittle Go,\xe2\x80\x9d or first University examination,\xe2\x80\x94senior SOPHS after that.\r\n\r\n~Sort~, used in a slang sense thus\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cThat\xe2\x80\x99s your SORT,\xe2\x80\x9d as a term of\r\napprobation. \xe2\x80\x9cPitch it into him, that\xe2\x80\x99s your SORT,\xe2\x80\x9d _i.e._, that is the\r\nproper kind of plan to adopt.\r\n\r\n~So-so~, not particularly reputable. \xe2\x80\x9cA very SO-SO sort of a person,\xe2\x80\x9d a\r\nperson whom it is no advantage to know. \xe2\x80\x9cIt was very SO-SO\xe2\x80\x9d (said of a\r\npiece of work or an entertainment), it was neither good nor bad.\r\n\r\n~Sound~, to pump, or draw information from a person in an artful manner.\r\n\r\n~Souper~, an Irish Roman Catholic who pretends conversion\xe2\x80\x94or\r\nperversion\xe2\x80\x94so as to obtain a share of the soup and blankets provided\r\nfor Protestants only by Christian missionaries. These recalcitrants are\r\nalso called \xe2\x80\x9cswaddlers.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n~Sou\xe2\x80\x99-wester~, a hat with a projection behind. Much worn at sea in\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cdirty\xe2\x80\x9d weather. A hat similar to that of a dustman or coalheaver, which\r\nis called a \xe2\x80\x9cfantail.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n~Sov~, contraction of sovereign; much used in sporting parlance to\r\ndenote the amount of entrance money, forfeit, and added coin in\r\nconnexion with a race. In the published conditions of a race the word\r\nSOVS is almost invariably used in preference to pounds, though in\r\nreckoning the net value of a big stake, after its decision, the common \xc2\xa3\r\nis used.\r\n\r\n~Sow~, the receptacle into which the liquid iron is poured in a\r\ngun-foundry. The melted metal poured from it is termed PIG.\r\n\r\n~Sow\xe2\x80\x99s baby~, a pig; sixpence.\r\n\r\n~Spanish~, money. Probably a relic of buccaneering days.\r\n\r\n    \xe2\x80\x9cSave its synonyms SPANISH, blunt, stumpy, and rowdy.\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94_Barham._\r\n\r\n~Spank~, a smack, or hard slap.\r\n\r\n~Spank~, to move along quickly; hence a fast horse or vessel is said to\r\nbe \xe2\x80\x9ca SPANKER to go.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n~Spanking~, large, fine, or strong; _e.g._, a SPANKING pace, a SPANKING\r\nbreeze, a SPANKING fellow.\r\n\r\n~Sparks~, diamonds. Term much in use among the lower orders, and\r\ngenerally applied to stones in rings and pins.\r\n\r\n~Specklebellies~, Dissenters. A term used in Worcester and the North,\r\nthough the etymology seems unknown in either place.\r\n\r\n~Specks~, damaged oranges.\xe2\x80\x94_Costermonger\xe2\x80\x99s term._\r\n\r\n~Speech~, a tip or wrinkle on any subject. On the turf a man will wait\r\nbefore investing on a horse until he \xe2\x80\x9cgets the SPEECH,\xe2\x80\x9d as to whether it\r\nis going to try, or whether it has a good chance. To \xe2\x80\x9cgive the SPEECH,\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nis to communicate any special information of a private nature.\r\n\r\n~Speel~, to run away, make off; \xe2\x80\x9cSPEEL the drum,\xe2\x80\x9d to go off with stolen\r\nproperty.\xe2\x80\x94_North._\r\n\r\n~Spell~, a turn of work, an interval of time. \xe2\x80\x9cTake a SPELL at the\r\ncapstern.\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94_Sea._ \xe2\x80\x9cHe took a long SPELL at that tankard.\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9cAfter a long\r\nSPELL.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n~Spell~, \xe2\x80\x9cto SPELL for a thing,\xe2\x80\x9d to hanker after it, to desire\r\npossession.\r\n\r\n~Spell~, to advertise, to put into print. \xe2\x80\x9cSPELT in the leer,\xe2\x80\x9d _i.e._,\r\nadvertised in the newspaper.\r\n\r\n~Spell~, contracted from SPELLKEN. \xe2\x80\x9cPrecious rum squeeze at the SPELL,\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n_i.e._, a good evening\xe2\x80\x99s work at the theatre, might be the remark of a\r\nsuccessful pickpocket.\r\n\r\n~Spellken~, or SPEELKEN, a playhouse. German, SPIELEN. _See_ KEN.\xe2\x80\x94_Don\r\nJuan._\r\n\r\n~Spick and span~, applied to anything that is quite new and\r\nfresh.\xe2\x80\x94_Hudibras._\r\n\r\n~Spidireen~, the name of an imaginary ship, sometimes mentioned by\r\nsailors. If a sailor be asked what ship he belongs to, and does not wish\r\nto tell, he will most probably reply\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cThe SPIDIREEN frigate, with nine\r\ndecks, and ne\xe2\x80\x99er a bottom.\xe2\x80\x9d _See_ MERRY DUN OF DOVER.\r\n\r\n~Spierized~, to have your hair cut and shampooed, from the shop of\r\nSpiers in High Street.\xe2\x80\x94_Oxford University._\r\n\r\n~Spiff~, a well-dressed man, a \xe2\x80\x9cswell.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n~Spiffed~, slightly intoxicated.\xe2\x80\x94_Scotch Slang._\r\n\r\n~Spiffs~, the per-centages allowed by drapers to their young men when\r\nthey effect a sale of old-fashioned or undesirable stock.\r\n\r\n~Spiffy~, spruce, well-dressed, _tout \xc3\xa0 la mode_.\r\n\r\n~Spifflicate~, to confound, silence, annihilate, or stifle. A corruption\r\nof the last word, or of \xe2\x80\x9csuffocate.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n~Spike Park~, the Queen\xe2\x80\x99s Bench Prison. _See_ BURDON\xe2\x80\x99S HOTEL.\r\n\r\n~Spill~, to throw from a horse or chaise. _See_ PURL.\r\n\r\n~Spin~, to reject from an examination.\xe2\x80\x94_Army._\r\n\r\n~Spindleshanks~, a nickname for any one who has thin legs.\r\n\r\n~Spin-\xe2\x80\x99em rounds~, a street game consisting of a piece of brass, wood,\r\nor iron, balanced on a pin, and turned quickly round on a board, when\r\nthe point, arrow-shaped, stops at a number, and decides the bet one way\r\nor the other. The contrivance very much resembles a sea compass, and was\r\nformerly the gambling accompaniment of London piemen. The apparatus then\r\nwas placed on the tin lids of their pie-cans, and the bets were\r\nostensibly for pies, but were frequently for \xe2\x80\x9ccoppers,\xe2\x80\x9d or for beer when\r\ntwo or three apprentices or porters happened to meet. An active and\r\nefficient police have, however, changed all that now.\r\n\r\n~Spiniken~, St. Giles\xe2\x80\x99s Workhouse. \xe2\x80\x9cLump,\xe2\x80\x9d Marylebone Workhouse. \xe2\x80\x9cPan,\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nSt. Pancras. \xe2\x80\x9cPan\xe2\x80\x9d and \xe2\x80\x9cLump\xe2\x80\x9d are now terms applied to all workhouses by\r\ntramps and costers.\r\n\r\n~Spinning-house~, the place in Cambridge where street-walkers are locked\r\nup, if found out after a certain time at night.\r\n\r\n~Spirt~, or SPURT, \xe2\x80\x9cto put on a SPIRT,\xe2\x80\x9d to make an increased exertion\r\nfor a brief space, to attain one\xe2\x80\x99s end; a nervous effort. Abbreviation\r\nor shortening of SPIRIT, or allusion to a SPIRT of water, which dies\r\naway as suddenly as it rises.\r\n\r\n    \xe2\x80\x9cSo here for a man to run well for a SPURT, and then to give over\r\n    ... is enough to annul all his former proceedings, and to make him\r\n    in no better estate than if he had never set foot into the good\r\n    waies of God.\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94_Gataker\xe2\x80\x99s Spirituall Watch_, 4to. 1619, p. 10.\r\n\r\n~Spitalfields\xe2\x80\x99 breakfast.~ At the East-end of London this is understood\r\nas consisting of a tight necktie and a short pipe. Amongst workmen it is\r\nusual to tighten the apron string when no dinner is at hand. Hunters and\r\ntrappers always take in their belts when supplies are short. \xe2\x80\x9cAn\r\nIrishman\xe2\x80\x99s dinner\xe2\x80\x9d is a low East-end term, and means a smoke and a visit\r\nto the urinal. Sometimes the phrase is, \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ll go out and count the\r\nrailings,\xe2\x80\x9d _i.e._, the park or area railings, mental instead of\r\nmaxillary exercise.\r\n\r\n~Spitfire~, a passionate person.\r\n\r\n~Splash~, complexion powder used by ladies to whiten their necks and\r\nfaces. The finest rice flour, termed in France _poudre de riz_, is\r\ngenerally employed. _See_ SLAP.\r\n\r\n~Splendiferous~, sumptuous, first-rate. SPLENDACIOUS sometimes used with\r\nsimilar meanings.\r\n\r\n~Splice~, to marry; \xe2\x80\x9cand the two shall become one flesh.\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94_Sea._ Also,\r\na wife.\r\n\r\n~Splice the main brace~, to take a drink.\xe2\x80\x94_Sea._\r\n\r\n~Split~, to inform against one\xe2\x80\x99s companions, to tell tales. \xe2\x80\x9cTo SPLIT\r\nwith a person,\xe2\x80\x9d to cease acquaintanceship; to quarrel. Also to divide a\r\nbottle of a\xc3\xabrated water; as, \xe2\x80\x9ctwo brandies and a soda SPLIT;\xe2\x80\x9d in which\r\ncase \xe2\x80\x9cto SPLIT with\xe2\x80\x9d a person has a very different meaning from that\r\njust given.\r\n\r\n~Split up~, long in the legs. Among athletes, a man with good length of\r\nlimb is said to be \xe2\x80\x9cwell SPLIT UP.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n~Splodger~, a lout, an awkward countryman.\r\n\r\n~Spoffy~, a bustling busybody is said to be SPOFFY.\r\n\r\n~Sponge~, \xe2\x80\x9cto throw up the SPONGE,\xe2\x80\x9d to submit, to give over the\r\nstruggle,\xe2\x80\x94from the practice of throwing up the SPONGE used to cleanse a\r\ncombatant\xe2\x80\x99s face at a prize-fight, as a signal that the side on which\r\nthat particular SPONGE has been used has had enough\xe2\x80\x94that the SPONGE is\r\nno longer required.\r\n\r\n~Spoon~, synonymous with SPOONEY. A SPOON has been defined to be \xe2\x80\x9ca\r\nthing that touches a lady\xe2\x80\x99s lips without kissing them.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n~Spooney~, a weak-minded and foolish person, effeminate or fond; \xe2\x80\x9cto be\r\nSPOONEY on a girl,\xe2\x80\x9d to be foolishly attached to one.\r\n\r\n~Spoons~, the condition of two persons who SPOON on each other, who are\r\ndeeply in love. \xe2\x80\x9cI see, it\xe2\x80\x99s a case of SPOONS with them,\xe2\x80\x9d is a common\r\nphrase when lovers are mentioned.\r\n\r\n~Spoons~, a method of designating large sums of money, disclosed at the\r\nBankruptcy Court during the examination of the great leather failures of\r\nStreatfield and Laurence in 1860-61. The origin of the phrase was stated\r\nto be the reply of the bankrupt Laurence to an offer of accommodating\r\nhim with \xc2\xa35000,\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cOh, you are feeding me with a TEA-SPOON.\xe2\x80\x9d Hence, \xc2\xa35000\r\ncame to be known in the firm as a TEA-SPOON; \xc2\xa310,000, a DESSERT-SPOON;\r\n\xc2\xa315,000, a TABLE-SPOON; and \xc2\xa320,000, as a GRAVY-SPOON. The public were\r\namused at this TEA-SPOON phraseology, but were disgusted that such\r\nlevity should cover a gigantic swindle of the kind. It came out in\r\nevidence, however, that it was not the ordinary slang of the discount\r\nworld, but it may not improbably become so. To \xe2\x80\x9ctake it with a SPOON,\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nis to take anything in small quantities. The counsel for the defence in\r\nthe Tichborne perjury case was reminded a short time back by one of the\r\njudges that he was using a TEA-SPOON instead of a shovel, to clear\r\nthrough the evidence.\r\n\r\n~Sport~, to exhibit, to wear, &c.,\xe2\x80\x94a word which is made to do duty in a\r\nvariety of senses, especially at the Universities.\xe2\x80\x94_See_ the _Gradus ad\r\nCantabrigiam_. \xe2\x80\x9cTo SPORT a new tile;\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9cto SPORT an _\xc3\x86grotat_\xe2\x80\x9d (_i.e._, a\r\npermission from the Dons to abstain from lectures, &c., on account of\r\nillness); \xe2\x80\x9cto SPORT one\xe2\x80\x99s oak,\xe2\x80\x9d to shut the outer door and exclude the\r\npublic,\xe2\x80\x94especially duns and boring acquaintances. Common also in the\r\nInns of Court. _See Notes and Queries_, 2nd series, vol. viii. p. 492,\r\nand _Gentleman\xe2\x80\x99s Magazine_, December, 1794.\r\n\r\n~Sport~, an American term for a gambler or turfite\xe2\x80\x94more akin to our\r\nsporting man than to our sportsman.\r\n\r\n~Sporting door~, the outer door of chambers, also called the OAK. _See_\r\nunder SPORT.\xe2\x80\x94_University._\r\n\r\n~Spot~, to mark, to recognise. Originally an Americanism, but now\r\ngeneral. \xe2\x80\x9cI SPOTTED him (or it) at once.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n~Spotted~, to be known or marked by the police.\r\n\r\n~Spout~, \xe2\x80\x9cup the SPOUT,\xe2\x80\x9d at the pawnbroker\xe2\x80\x99s; SPOUTING, pawning. _See_\r\nPOP for origin.\r\n\r\n~Spout~, to preach, or make speeches; SPOUTER, a preacher or lecturer.\r\n\r\n~Sprat~, sixpence.\r\n\r\n~Spread~, butter. Term with workmen and schoolboys. _See_ SCRAPE.\r\n\r\n~Spread~, a lady\xe2\x80\x99s shawl, an entertainment, a display of good things.\r\n\r\n~Spread~, a meal. Sporting term for a dinner. A sporting man often\r\nchallenges another to compete with him at any athletic pursuit or\r\npastime, for so much wine and a SPREAD of large or small proportions.\r\n\r\n~Spree~, a boisterous piece of merriment; \xe2\x80\x9cgoing on the SPREE,\xe2\x80\x9d starting\r\nout with intent to have a frolic. _French_, ESPRIT. In the _Dutch_\r\nlanguage, SPREEUW is a jester.\r\n\r\n~Springer-up~, a tailor who sells low-priced ready-made clothing, and\r\ngives starvation wages to the poor men and women who \xe2\x80\x9cmake up\xe2\x80\x9d for him.\r\nThe clothes are said to be SPRUNG-UP, or \xe2\x80\x9cblown together.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n~Sprint race~, a short-distance race, ran at the topmost speed\r\nthroughout. SPRINT is in the North synonymous with SPURT, and hence the\r\nname.\r\n\r\n~Sprung~, inebriated sufficiently to become boisterous.\r\n\r\n~Spry~, active, strong, manly. Much used in America, but originally\r\nEnglish.\r\n\r\n~Spuddy~, a seller of bad potatoes. In lower life, a SPUD is a raw\r\npotato; and roasted SPUDS are those cooked in the cinders with their\r\nskins on.\r\n\r\n~Spun~, when a man has failed in his examination at Woolwich, he is said\r\nto be SPUN; as at the Universities he is said to be \xe2\x80\x9cplucked\xe2\x80\x9d or\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cploughed.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n~Spunge~, a mean, paltry fellow, sometimes called a SPUNGER.\r\n\r\n~Spunge~, to live at another\xe2\x80\x99s expense in a mean and paltry manner.\r\n\r\n~Spunging-house~, the sheriff\xe2\x80\x99s officer\xe2\x80\x99s house, where prisoners, when\r\narrested for debt, used to be taken. As extortionate charges were made\r\nthere for accommodation, the name was far from inappropriate.\r\n\r\n~Spunk~, spirit, fire, courage, mettle, good humour.\r\n\r\n    \xe2\x80\x9cIn that snug room, where any man of SPUNK\r\n    Would find it a hard matter to get drunk.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n        _Peter Pindar_, i. 245.\r\n\r\nCommon in America, and much used in some parts of Scotland.\r\n\r\n~Spunk-fencer~, a lucifer-match seller.\r\n\r\n~Spunks~, lucifer-matches.\xe2\x80\x94_Herefordshire_; _Scotland_. SPUNK, says Urry,\r\nin his MS. notes to Ray, \xe2\x80\x9cis the excrescency of some tree, of which they\r\nmake a sort of tinder to light their pipes with.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n~Spurt.~\xe2\x80\x94_Old._ _See_ SPIRT.\r\n\r\n~Squabby~, flat, short and thick. From SQUAB, a sofa.\r\n\r\n~Square~, honest; \xe2\x80\x9con the SQUARE,\xe2\x80\x9d _i.e._, fair and strictly honest; \xe2\x80\x9cto\r\nturn SQUARE,\xe2\x80\x9d to reform, and get one\xe2\x80\x99s living in an honest manner,\xe2\x80\x94the\r\nopposite of \xe2\x80\x9ccross.\xe2\x80\x9d The expression is, in all probability, derived from\r\nthe well-known masonic emblem the SQUARE, the symbol of evenness and\r\nrectitude.\r\n\r\n    \xe2\x80\x9cYou must keep within the compass, and act upon the square with all\r\n    mankind, for your masonry is but a dead letter if you do not\r\n    habitually perform its reiterated injunctions.\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94_Oliver\xe2\x80\x99s Lectures\r\n    on Signs and Symbols_, p. 190.\r\n\r\n~Square~, \xe2\x80\x9cto be SQUARE with a man,\xe2\x80\x9d to be even with him, or to be\r\nrevenged; \xe2\x80\x9cto SQUARE up to a man,\xe2\x80\x9d to offer to fight him. Shakspeare\r\nuses SQUARE in the sense of to quarrel.\r\n\r\n~Square cove~, an honest man, as distinguished from \xe2\x80\x9ccross cove.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n~Square moll~, an honest woman, one who does not \xe2\x80\x9cbatter.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n~Squaring his nibs~, giving a policeman, or any official, money for an\r\nimmoral or unlawful purpose. The term HIS NIBS has no reference to any\r\nfunctionary, as the words mean simply \xe2\x80\x9chim,\xe2\x80\x9d and may be applied to any\r\none.\r\n\r\n~Square rigged~, well dressed.\xe2\x80\x94_Sea._\r\n\r\n~Square up~, to settle, to pay a debt.\r\n\r\n~Squarum~, a cobbler\xe2\x80\x99s lapstone.\r\n\r\n~Squash~, to crush; \xe2\x80\x9cto go SQUASH,\xe2\x80\x9d to collapse.\r\n\r\n~Squeak~, an escape. Generally used with regard to the avoidance of\r\ncasualties. Among thieves, too, a prisoner acquitted after a hard trial\r\nis said to have had \xe2\x80\x9ca narrow SQUEAK for it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n~Squeak on a person~, to inform against, to peach.\r\n\r\n~Squeal~, to inform, to peach. A North country variation of squeak;\r\nSQUEALER, an informer, also an illegitimate baby.\r\n\r\n~Squeeze~, silk; also, by a very significant figure, a thief\xe2\x80\x99s term for\r\nthe neck.\r\n\r\n~Squib~, a _jeu d\xe2\x80\x99esprit_, which, like the firework of that\r\ndenomination, sparkles, bounces, stinks, and vanishes.\xe2\x80\x94_Grose._\r\nGenerally used in reference to political and electioneering attacks of a\r\nsmart kind, which sting for a moment and are then forgotten.\r\n\r\n~Squibs~, paint-brushes.\r\n\r\n~Squiffy~, slightly inebriated.\r\n\r\n~Squinny-eyed~, said of one given to squinting.\xe2\x80\x94_Shakspeare._\r\n\r\n~Squirt~, a doctor, or chemist.\r\n\r\n~Squish~, common term among University men for marmalade.\r\n\r\n~Stab~, \xe2\x80\x9cSTAB yourself and pass the dagger,\xe2\x80\x9d help yourself and pass the\r\nbottle.\xe2\x80\x94_Theatrical Slang._\r\n\r\n~Stab~, \xe2\x80\x9con the STAB,\xe2\x80\x9d _i.e._, paid by regular weekly wages on the\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cestablishment,\xe2\x80\x9d of which word STAB is an abridgment.\xe2\x80\x94_Printer\xe2\x80\x99s term._\r\n\r\n~Stab-rag~, a regimental tailor.\xe2\x80\x94_Military Slang._\r\n\r\n~Stag~, a shilling.\r\n\r\n~Stag~, a term applied during the railway mania to a speculator without\r\ncapital, who took \xe2\x80\x9cscrip\xe2\x80\x9d in proposed lines, got the shares up to a\r\npremium, and then sold out. Caricaturists represented the house of\r\nHudson, \xe2\x80\x9cthe Railway King,\xe2\x80\x9d at Albert Gate, with a STAG on it, in\r\nallusion to this term.\r\n\r\n~Stag~, to see, discover, or watch,\xe2\x80\x94like a STAG at gaze; \xe2\x80\x9cSTAG the\r\npush,\xe2\x80\x9d look at the crowd. Also, to dun, or demand payment; to beg.\r\n\r\n~Stage-whisper~, one loud enough to be heard. From the stage \xe2\x80\x9casides.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n~Stagger~, to surprise. \xe2\x80\x9cHe quite STAGGERED me with the information.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n~Stagger~, one who looks out, or watches.\r\n\r\n~Staggering-bob~, an animal to whom the knife only just anticipates\r\ndeath from natural disease or accident,\xe2\x80\x94said of meat on that account\r\nunfit for human food. Also a newly-born calf.\r\n\r\n~Stale drunk~, unevaporated fumes of liquor. A man is said to be STALE\r\nDRUNK when he has been drunk overnight, and has doctored himself with\r\nstimulants a little too much in the morning\xe2\x80\x94when he has tried too many\r\nof the \xe2\x80\x9chairs of the dog that bit him.\xe2\x80\x9d If this state of things is long\r\ncontinued, it is often called \xe2\x80\x9csame OLD DRUNK,\xe2\x80\x9d from a well-known nigger\r\nstory. The nigger was cautioned by his master for being too often drunk\r\nwithin a given period, when the \xe2\x80\x9ccullud pusson\xe2\x80\x9d replied, \xe2\x80\x9cSame old\r\ndrunk, massa\xe2\x80\x94same old drunk.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n~Stalking-horse~, originally a horse covered with loose trappings, under\r\nwhich the medi\xc3\xa6val sportsman concealed himself with his bow, so as to\r\napproach his game unobserved. Subsequently a canvas figure, made light,\r\nso as to be easily moved with one hand. Now used to represent any\r\nbugbear persistently paraded; any constant and unpleasant reference to\r\nthe possible consequences of an act.\r\n\r\n~Stall~, to lodge, or put up at a public-house. Also, to act a\r\npart.\xe2\x80\x94_Theatrical._\r\n\r\n~Stall~, to frighten or discourage. In the days of dog-fighting and\r\npugilism, a dog or man who had originally shown great pluck would, after\r\na hard battle or two, show signs of cowardice. In such case he was said\r\nto have been STALLED by his previous encounters.
